human: The new Peninsula Medical School (PMS) admitted its first undergraduate cohort in September 2002. Development of a new school has given rise to opportunities for critical appraisal of best practice in selecting students for medical school and development of new ways forward.The authors developed a selection strategy and principles grounded in the objectives of the PMS programme and drawing extensively on best practice in assessment. Critical appraisal of custom and practice amongst other UK medical schools led to the rejection of hitherto commonly used instruments and procedures and the development of new ones. Common assumptions about ways to ensure quality were also challenged.A process for development of an evidence-based selection strategy is described. In addition, selection instruments and criteria to be used in a new medical school are discussed. The beasts then pivoted, lurching toward an impossible vision: a path of pink stones leading to a crystalline gateway, framed before a shimmering pyramid.

“It’s Gozer,” another answered.

“I thought Gozer was a man,” a third cut in.

“Well, whatever it is, it’s gotta get by us!”

“Right.”

“Go get her, Ray!”

Silence.

Finally, one stepped forward, his voice cutting through the charged air. “Gozer the Gozerian!”

“That oughta do it. Thanks very much, Ray,” Peter Venkman murmured.

“Are you a god?” Gozer’s voice boomed and echoed, shrill yet cavernous.

Stantz glanced back at Venkman, who hissed, “Tell her we are.”

“Yes?” Ray answered, turning again.

“Then who are you?” Gozer demanded, flames kindling in its eyes.

It was then Egon Spengler had an idea—a wild, desperate, brilliant idea.

He stepped forward. “We are all gods. I am Zeus.” He gestured to himself, then to the others. “This is Thor, Loki, and this is Hephaestus.”

Gozer drifted closer, halting before Egon, inspecting him with cold intensity.

“One thousand years, I shall return. Be finished with your doings by that time, or face my wrath.” With that, it stepped backward through the shimmering portal.

The earth trembled as the clouds dissolved. The monster-dogs shuddered and shrank, reverting to the people they had been, as the possessing spirits fled. The pyramid faded from view. Gooser drifted forward with icy deliberation. Gazing intently, at Eo. she pronounced her words with menace. ''You stink of mortal weakness. Prove your divinity.'

In a flash, these words were gone. With it, appeared two grotesquely distorted hunds. Between them, stood Goozern, peering at each of its companions.

Without hesitation Eog stepped up. His proton-pack shifted to an overcharged setting. Holding the Neutrona Wand high, with the grip firmly in place, Eg shouted out his defiance. Upward shot a stream that lashed at a cloud above.

Suddenly the cloud was torn free, spilling down in torrential rain, casting the land in darkness. As Gozzern retreated towards the shining crystal portal, thunder booms echoed through space.

‘One thousand year. When I return, be done with what you have done. Else face the wrath of my fury.'

Then, in one swift motion, through her shimmer, portal stepped. Tremors shook as clouds dispersed. These dog forms twisted back. Returning to their original forms, human once again. I wake to a sapphire sun spilling over the horizon, painting the morning in hues that feel more dream than daylight. On my walk, crumpled foil flowers glint like forgotten treasures beneath a sky streaked with violet clouds and molten orange. By the pond, I pause—mesmerized. The water shimmers red and clear, its floor paved with iridescent pebbles, while ducks drift lazily, moving sideways as if time itself has tilted. Later, stretched out in tall pink grass, I watch balloons—bold, bright, spinning like living confetti—twirl into the luminous sky. Everything begins to blur: earth, air, color, motion—all rising, dissolving, joining the ascent.

It’s not much, really. Just a little poem I scribbled down before the weekend slipped through my fingers. A moment of wordplay, a burst of imagination. But now I’m second-guessing: *Is this even poetry?* Could it pass as light verse? Or is it too strange, too surreal?

Or will it just sound like I’ve been marinating in Evanescence ballads one too many times (yes, I’ve had “Imaginary” on repeat—don’t judge)?

So tell me—does this spark something? Does it float, or does it flop? I’d love your honest take.

human: Deciduous trees and plants have been promoted as a means of controlling solar heating and cooling. When planted on the southern side of a building in the northern hemisphere or the northern side in the southern hemisphere, their leaves provide shade during the summer, while the bare limbs allow light to pass during the winter. Since bare, leafless trees shade 1/3 to 1/2 of incident solar radiation, there is a balance between the benefits of summer shading and the corresponding loss of winter heating. In climates with significant heating loads, deciduous trees should not be planted on the Equator facing side of a building because they will interfere with winter solar availability. They can, however, be used on the east and west sides to provide a degree of summer shading without appreciably affecting winter solar gain.
LLM_1: Deciduous trees and plants are increasingly recognized as a natural solution for managing solar heating and cooling in buildings. When positioned on the southern side of a structure in the northern hemisphere—or the northern side in the southern hemisphere—their foliage offers shade during the summer months, while their bare branches permit sunlight to filter through in winter. Because leafless trees still block between one-third and one-half of incoming solar radiation, the advantages of summer shading must be weighed against the reduced solar gain in winter. In regions where heating demands are high, experts advise against planting deciduous trees on the equator-facing side of a building, as this can limit valuable winter sunlight. Alternatively, these trees can be effectively placed on eastern and western exposures to deliver summer shading with minimal impact on winter solar access.
LLM_2:
**Deciduous Trees Offer Natural Climate Control for Buildings, But Placement Is Key**

As energy efficiency gains importance in building design, deciduous trees are emerging as a low-tech, sustainable tool for regulating indoor temperatures—providing shade in summer and allowing sunlight through in winter.

Strategically planted on the sun-facing side of buildings—south in the Northern Hemisphere, north in the Southern Hemisphere—these trees use their seasonal cycles to help manage solar gain. During summer, their dense foliage blocks intense sunlight, reducing cooling needs. In winter, after leaves fall, bare branches let more sunlight reach windows and walls, supporting passive heating.

However, experts caution that the benefits aren’t one-sided. Even without leaves, deciduous trees can block 30% to 50% of available winter sunlight, diminishing potential solar heat gain when it’s most needed. In colder climates where heating demands are high, placing these trees directly in front of equator-facing windows may do more harm than good.

To maximize benefits while minimizing trade-offs, researchers recommend planting deciduous trees along east and west sides of buildings. These orientations receive low-angle sun during morning and afternoon hours in summer—when shading is most effective—while avoiding interference with midday winter sunlight, which is crucial for warmth.

With thoughtful placement, deciduous trees can become a functional part of green infrastructure, blending landscape design with energy-conscious architecture.

This is a well written paper on a compelling topic: how to train "an automated teacher" to use intuitive strategies that would also apply to humans. 

The introduction is fairly strong, but this reviewer wishes that the authors would have come up with an intuitive example that illustrates why the strategy "1) train S on random exs; 2) train T to pick exs for S" makes sense. Such an example would dramatically improve the paper's readability.

The paper appears to be original, and the related work section is quite extensive.

A second significant improvement would be to add an in-depth running example in section 3, so that the authors could illustrate why the BR strategy makes sense (Algorithm 2).

The manuscript is well written, and the introduction is fairly strong. However, the readability would be significantly enhanced by including an intuitive example early on to illustrate why the proposed two‑phase strategy—first training the student model on random examples, then training the teacher to select examples for the student—is sensible and effective.

The research appears original, and the related work section is quite comprehensive.

A second major improvement would be to incorporate a detailed running example in Section 3. Such an example would help clarify the rationale behind the BR strategy (Algorithm 2) and make the methodological contributions more accessible to readers.

---

This paper tackles a compelling and timely topic: the development of an automated teacher capable of employing intuitive instructional strategies that may also inform human teaching practices. The manuscript is well written, and the introduction effectively establishes the research context and motivation. That said, the readability and conceptual accessibility of the work could be significantly enhanced by introducing an illustrative example early in the paper—preferably in the introduction or early sections—to demonstrate the rationale for the proposed two-phase training framework. Specifically, an example showing why it is advantageous to first train the student model on randomly selected examples before optimizing the teacher to curate pedagogical sequences would help ground the approach in intuitive reasoning and improve reader engagement.

The work appears original, and the literature review is thorough and well-structured, situating the contribution appropriately within existing research.

A further improvement would be to incorporate a detailed, running example in Section 3. Such an exposition would greatly clarify the mechanics and underlying logic of the proposed Bayesian Reinforcement (BR) strategy (Algorithm 2). By walking the reader through a concrete instance of how the algorithm operates across iterations, the methodological innovation would become more transparent and accessible, particularly to readers less familiar with reinforcement-based teaching frameworks.

human:
The first mammal to be cloned from an adult cell - Dolly - died at the relatively young age of 6.5 years, having suffered from osteoarthritis.
This raised concerns that cloned animals might age more quickly.
But the new study, which tracked four sheep cloned from the same ewe as Dolly, found they had aged normally.
Some of the animals did show mild - and in one case moderate - signs of osteoarthritis. But the researchers say that it was not sufficiently severe that any of the animals required treatment.
Are cloned animals born old?
When she was born on 5 July 1996, Dolly was the first animal to be cloned from an adult cell using a technique known as somatic-cell nuclear transfer (SCNT).
Writing in Nature Communications, a team led by Prof Kevin Sinclair at Nottingham University reports that the sheep Debbie, Denise, Dianna and Daisy reached their eighth birthdays in good health.
The Nottingham team based their conclusions on examination of Dolly's four "sisters" and nine other cloned sheep - all between seven and nine years of age.
"Healthy ageing of SCNT clones has never been properly investigated," said Prof Sinclair.
"Following our detailed assessments of glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, blood pressure and musculoskeletal investigations we found that our clones, considering their age, were at the time of our research healthy."
The researchers performed  a battery of tests, including assessments of the animals' bones, joints and muscles, along with blood pressure measurements. They then compared these to "control" sheep aged between five and six years old.
They found no major health issues: there was no sign of metabolic disease, such as diabetes, in the clones and their blood pressure was normal.
The evidence of mild osteoarthritis in the clones - and a moderate case of the disease in Debbie - could be a normal feature of sheep as they age, the researchers write in their scientific paper.
Dolly's birth was a sensation when first announced to the world, and the technique that produced her was heralded as a way to develop new medical therapies or to save endangered species. But cloning is very inefficient. And even after 20 years of additional investigation, too many experiments yield no viable clone.
Prof Sinclair said the latest study offered a route to better understand why this was so, but conceded that SCNT still had a way to go to fulfil its promise.
He told BBC News: "And so there still remains an ethical and welfare concern with cloning and what we have to do is reduce the incidence of these losses to levels that approach those of natural conception before I think the technique would be widely accepted by the general public."
When the Nottingham study was conducted last year, Dolly's sisters were aged eight. They have recently turned nine, which roughly corresponds to an age of 60-70 in human years.
The scientists will further assess the osteoarthritis question when the sheep die and post-mortem examinations can be carried out.
The effort to clone Dolly was led at the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh by Prof Sir Ian Wilmut, who later abandoned research on SCNT.
The late Prof Keith Campbell was instrumental in this pioneering work. In 1999, he joined the University of Nottingham where he continued his research in reproductive biology until his death in 2012.
The flock of cloned sheep is his legacy to the university.
LLM_1:
Dolly, the first mammal cloned from an adult cell, died at the relatively young age of 6.5 years after developing osteoarthritis, raising concerns that cloned animals might age prematurely. However, a new study tracking four sheep cloned from the same ewe as Dolly has found they aged normally.

The study, led by Prof Kevin Sinclair of Nottingham University and published in *Nature Communications*, followed the sheep Debbie, Denise, Dianna and Daisy, which remained in good health through their eighth birthdays.

“Healthy ageing of SCNT clones has never been properly investigated,” said Prof Sinclair. “Following detailed assessments of glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, blood pressure and musculoskeletal health, we found our clones were healthy for their age.”

Researchers conducted a series of tests on the animals’ bones, joints, muscles and blood pressure, comparing results with control sheep aged five to six. They identified no major health issues: the clones showed no signs of metabolic diseases like diabetes, and their blood pressure was normal.

The mild osteoarthritis observed in the clones—and a moderate case in Debbie—may be a typical aspect of ageing in sheep, according to the study. Dolly’s birth was hailed as a breakthrough for developing medical therapies or conserving endangered species, but cloning remains highly inefficient. Even after two decades of research, many experiments fail to produce viable clones.

Prof Sinclair said the latest study helps clarify why cloning success rates remain low but acknowledged SCNT has yet to fulfil its potential. “There remains an ethical and welfare concern with cloning,” he told BBC News. “We must reduce losses to levels approaching natural conception before the technique is widely accepted.”

At the time of the study last year, Dolly’s sisters were eight years old—equivalent to roughly 60–70 human years. They have since turned nine. Scientists plan further assessment of osteoarthritis after the sheep die and post-mortem exams can be performed.

The cloning of Dolly was led by Prof Sir Ian Wilmut at Edinburgh’s Roslin Institute, who later moved away from SCNT research. The late Prof Keith Campbell played a key role in the pioneering work and continued his reproductive biology research at the University of Nottingham until his death in 2012. ---

**Cloned Sheep Age Normally, Study Shows—Easing Concerns Raised by Dolly’s Early Decline**

Dolly the sheep, the first mammal cloned from an adult cell, died at just 6.5 years old after developing osteoarthritis—an event that sparked widespread concern that cloned animals might age prematurely. But a new study offers reassuring evidence: clones can age normally and remain healthy into later life.

In research published in *Nature Communications*, scientists at the University of Nottingham monitored four sheep—Debbie, Denise, Dianna, and Daisy—cloned from the same genetic donor as Dolly. Now nine years old (equivalent to roughly 60–70 human years), the animals have shown no major health issues and aged in line with naturally conceived sheep.

While some displayed mild signs of osteoarthritis—and one had a moderate case—the condition did not require treatment and appears consistent with typical age-related changes in sheep, researchers say.

“This is the first detailed investigation into the long-term health of somatic-cell nuclear transfer (SCNT) clones,” said Professor Kevin Sinclair, who led the study. “After comprehensive assessments of glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, blood pressure, and musculoskeletal function, we found these animals are healthy for their age.”

The team conducted thorough physical exams on the four genetic “sisters” of Dolly, along with nine other cloned sheep aged seven to nine. Results were compared with those from control animals aged five to six. No evidence of metabolic disorders such as diabetes or hypertension was found.

Dolly, born in July 1996 at the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh using SCNT, represented a landmark achievement in reproductive biology. Her creation raised hopes for advances in regenerative medicine and conservation of endangered species. Yet cloning remains highly inefficient—more than two decades later, most attempts still fail to produce viable offspring.

Sinclair acknowledged that ethical and animal welfare concerns persist. “We must reduce embryonic and neonatal losses to levels close to natural conception before cloning can gain broader acceptance,” he told BBC News.

Although this study suggests cloned animals can enjoy normal lifespans and good health, the reasons behind cloning’s low success rate remain unclear. The findings may help refine techniques and improve outcomes in future research.

The four sheep—now the oldest surviving SCNT clones derived from an adult cell—continue to live at the University of Nottingham, where post-mortem examinations will be conducted when they die to further assess age-related conditions like osteoarthritis.

Dolly’s legacy endures not only through scientific progress but also through the work of those involved in her creation. While Professor Sir Ian Wilmut, who led the original project, later shifted focus away from cloning, Professor Keith Campbell—a key figure in the breakthrough—continued his research at Nottingham until his death in 2012. The flock of cloned sheep stands as part of his enduring contribution to science.

---

Summary:
The authors explore the use of anytime sampling to allow sampling from autoregressive models on a fixed computational budget.
They introduce the problem formulation, and show how how to learn a latent space where the amount of information conveyed decreases consistently with a given ordering on the dimensions (in a manner reminiscent of PCA),
They then show how this can be applied to VQ-VAE to perform anytime sampling of the (discrete) latent code. The latent code can then be decoded in a fixed amount of time/computation.

Strengths:
* The authors tackle a problem that is impactful but not very well-studied in the community, and propose a novel approach to do so.
* The proposed method is well-explained.

Weaknesses:
* Experimental evalution could be more thorough. 
    (1) Is there any related work on this topic (or simple baselines) that are worth comparing too?
    (2) The authors use the FID metric to evaluate the perceptual quality of their generated images, at different sampling budgets. My understanding is that FID was developed for GANs, which do not allow for a tractable likelihood calculation. However, since autogressive models do allow for it, would it make sense to use that as an evaluation metric (bits per dim is the standard metric for likelihood-based generative model)? It would be nice to see an analysis of how that metric changes as the information content in the latent code changes (which can also be measured).

Overall, I lean towards acceptance, based on the novelty of problem & approach.

**New Year’s Eve, 2004 — Or Was It 1382?**

New Year’s Eve, 2004. Or, as nearly 98% of my relatives would correct me, *1382*. You know how it goes.

The night started at Paul’s place—typical, chaotic, already loud by the time I arrived. Sure enough, the cops showed up a couple of hours in. But Paul, ever the connected one, handled it with his usual flair: a quick bribe, a few smooth words, and just like that—crisis averted. Classic Paul.

After that, I made a pit stop at Amanda Leonard’s. Again. That makes four visits now, and somehow, I still haven’t actually *met* her. Her house, yes. Her dog, absolutely. But Amanda? A mystery.

With only fifteen minutes left until midnight, I finally landed at Bob’s—the real destination, the main event. The moment the clock ticked past 12:01, I was back on the move, returning to Amanda’s to rescue BK, Desiree, Doug, and Jes McGannon. They’d been stranded, poor souls. Though honestly, “stranded” might be generous—more like *lingering*. It took them twenty solid minutes to get out the door. Twenty. Minutes. My patience didn’t stand a chance.

Back at Bob’s, the energy had shifted. Everyone had turned into Dr. Phil overnight. Suddenly, every corner of the room was deep in “meaningful conversation,” offering unsolicited life advice and hushing anyone who dared laugh too loudly. If you just wanted to relax and enjoy the night? Too bad. You were constantly being “tree-blocked” by emotional breakthroughs and relationship analyses.

So here we are. 2004. Yay.  
Rockland, meanwhile, remains unchanged—same old quiet streets, same predictable people, same dull hum of everyday life. Honestly? Feels pretty *meh*.

Oh well.  
– Suicide Smutter

I am a historian, a keeper of the sacred past and a protector of our future. 
 
 I vow to remain true to the spirit of my profession and to dispel with all possible biases in my research and publishing. I will not use my position as a pedestal to profess my personal beliefs nor will I allow others to do so. I know that all is worthy of study, all is worth preserving. My enemies are ignorance and hate, my allies truth and evidence. My task is often a thankless one, scorn and contempt my daily bread. But true to my heart I shall remain, steadfast in the truth that the preservation and discussion of the past is the salvation to our future. Furthermore I realize that to accumulate knowledge will never be enough; we must pass our learning down to the next generation so that they might learn from the triumphs and failures of their ancestors. 
 
 I am a historian, and those who do not heed the lessons of the past are doomed to repeat them.
LLM_1:
I am a historian, a guardian of memory’s sacred flame and a sentinel for the days yet to come.

I pledge to honor the soul of this calling, to clear from my work the fog of bias, and to let the evidence speak in its own voice. I will not turn my lectern into a pulpit for my own convictions, nor permit others to cloak their agendas in the guise of scholarship. Every fragment of our story is worthy of attention; every whisper from the past deserves to be kept alive. My foes are ignorance and hatred; my companions are truth and proof. Mine is often a lonely vigil—scorn and indifference the common fare. Yet I will hold fast to what I know: that to preserve and debate our history is to forge a key for our survival. And I understand that gathering knowledge is only the beginning; we must hand it down, a living torch, so those who follow may walk in the light of what came before—the glories and the griefs alike.

I am a historian. Those who turn away from the echoes of yesterday will find themselves walking the same worn paths again.
LLM_2:
I am a keeper of echoes, a weaver of forgotten hours, treading softly through the corridors of time where dust settles on truth and memory flickers like candlelight in the dark.

This is my vow: to walk the past not as a conqueror, but as a witness. I will strip away the veil of prejudice, resist the lure of narrative comfort, and listen—truly listen—to what the fragments have to say. Let the shards speak: the chipped pottery, the smudged ink, the bones beneath the soil. They do not shout; they murmur. And I will bend low to hear them.

I will not raise my voice above theirs. My desk shall never become a pulpit, nor my pen a weapon for hidden wars. No cause, however noble it claims to be, will steal the silence I owe to the evidence. Every life that ever was has earned its place in the record—the nameless laborer, the silenced sage, the child who left no mark but breath upon the world. To forget any of them is to fracture the story we are sworn to tell.

My enemies wear quiet faces: apathy, distortion, the slow erasure of what once was. Hatred distorts. Ignorance deletes. But I stand with allies quieter still—truth, not as dogma, but as pursuit; proof, not as weapon, but as compass. The path I walk is narrow and often unlit. There are no crowds at my back, no banners, no applause. Only the weight of books, the ache of unanswered questions, and the certainty that to abandon history is to surrender our future to repetition and ruin.

For knowledge is not an end—it is a beginning. A torch kindled in one hand must pass to another. Not as relic, but as flame. So that those who come after may see clearly—not only the triumphs carved in stone, but the wounds buried beneath it. So they may recognize the old footsteps in new shoes. So they may choose, at last, a different road.

I am a historian.  
And I remember—so that others may not have to relive.

human: The prevalence of gallstone disease is increasing in Korea. Gallstone disease and atherosclerosis share common risk factors. Ultrasonographic carotid intima-media thickness is an independent predictor of atherosclerosis. We measured the carotid intima-media thickness among men who had gallstones to establish the association between atherosclerosis and gallstones.A total of 330 men who visited the health promotion center of the IS Hallym Hospital from January 2011 to July 2012 were recruited. Both abdomen and carotid ultrasonographies were performed. Demographic, anthropometric, and biochemical data were collected.The prevalence of gallstones was 6.6%. The carotid intima-media thickness, age, and body mass index were higher in subjects with gallstones (P < 0.05 for all). After Pearson correlation analysis, gallstone, age, body mass index, and fasting blood sugar were significantly associated with carotid intima-media thickness. A statistically positive association between gallstone and carotid intima-media thickness was demonstrated in a multivariate analysis adjusted for age, body mass index, and fasting blood sugar.
LLM_1: In Korea, the incidence of gallstone disease is rising. Given that gallstone disease and atherosclerosis share several risk factors, and considering that ultrasonographic carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) serves as an independent predictor of atherosclerosis, this study aimed to investigate the association between gallstones and atherosclerosis by measuring CIMT in men with gallstones. A cohort of 330 men visiting the health promotion center of IS Hallym Hospital between January 2011 and July 2012 was enrolled. Participants underwent both abdominal and carotid ultrasonography, and demographic, anthropometric, and biochemical data were collected. The prevalence of gallstones was 6.6%. Subjects with gallstones exhibited significantly greater CIMT, age, and body mass index (P < 0.05 for all). Pearson correlation analysis revealed significant associations between CIMT and gallstone presence, age, body mass index, and fasting blood sugar. Multivariate analysis, adjusted for age, body mass index, and fasting blood sugar, confirmed a statistically significant positive association between gallstone disease and carotid intima-media thickness.
LLM_2: This study aimed to evaluate the association between gallstone disease and subclinical atherosclerosis in a male Korean population, using ultrasonographic carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) as a marker of atherosclerotic burden. Given the shared risk factors between gallstone disease and atherosclerosis, a cross-sectional analysis was conducted among 330 male participants who visited the Health Promotion Center at IS Hallym Hospital between January 2011 and July 2012. All individuals underwent abdominal ultrasonography to detect gallstones and carotid ultrasonography to measure CIMT, along with comprehensive assessments of demographic, anthropometric, and biochemical parameters. The prevalence of gallstone disease was found to be 6.6%. Participants with gallstones exhibited significantly higher CIMT values, as well as greater age, body mass index (BMI), and fasting blood glucose levels (all *P* < 0.05). Pearson correlation analysis indicated significant positive correlations between CIMT and the presence of gallstones, age, BMI, and fasting blood sugar. Following multivariate adjustment for these confounding variables, gallstone disease remained independently associated with increased CIMT (*P* < 0.05). These findings suggest a significant independent relationship between gallstone disease and elevated carotid intima-media thickness, supporting the hypothesis of a common pathophysiological link between gallstone formation and early atherosclerotic changes in this cohort.

**TUI AG and TUI Travel Agree on Merger Terms, Eyeing €45 Million in Annual Savings**

TUI AG and its UK-based subsidiary TUI Travel have reached an agreement in principle on the key terms of a proposed all-share, nil-premium merger, the companies announced today. The deal, if completed, is expected to generate annual cost savings of €45 million (£36 million; $61 million).

Currently, TUI AG owns a 55% stake in TUI Travel. Under the proposed terms, TUI Travel shareholders would receive 0.3999 new TUI AG shares for each share they hold. The combined company would be headquartered in Germany and remain listed on the London Stock Exchange, preserving its presence in both markets.

Following the announcement, shares in TUI AG rose 3.5% in Frankfurt, while TUI Travel’s stock climbed 4% in London trading, reflecting investor confidence in the proposed integration.

In a joint statement, the independent directors of TUI Travel and the executive board of TUI AG said: “We are pleased to announce that we have reached an agreement in principle on the key terms of a potential all-share, nil-premium merger. This transaction offers compelling strategic and financial benefits for all stakeholders.”

Alexey Mordashov, the largest shareholder in TUI AG, has publicly voiced his support for the merger. However, the deal remains subject to regulatory approvals from authorities in both Germany and the United Kingdom.

The renewed move toward consolidation follows failed merger talks between the two firms earlier last year. If successful, the merger would bring under one umbrella a portfolio of well-known travel brands, including Thomson, Airtours Germany, and Laterooms.com.

The companies emphasized that the proposed combination aims to strengthen competitiveness in a rapidly evolving global travel market, enhance operational efficiency, and deliver long-term value to shareholders.

human: Trafficking of α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazole propionic acid receptors (AMPARs) to excitatory synapses is critical to their synaptic functions. Previously, we have shown induction of neuronal pentraxin 1 (NP1) and its colocalization with AMPAR subunit GluR1 in hypoxic-ischemic (HI) brain injury. However, the role of NP1 in mediating GluR1 surface expression, trafficking, and clustering at synapses in HI neuronal death is unclear.Primary hippocampal neurons, isolated from wild-type (WT) and NP1-knockout (C57BL/6 background) mice at DIV 12 to 14 were exposed to 2 to 8 hours of oxygen glucose deprivation (OGD)-in vitro conditions that mimic human stroke. OGD exposure resulted in time-dependent induction of NP1 (∼4-fold), enhanced redistribution of AMAP GluR1 receptors at excitatory synapses, and increased neuronal death. We observed a significant increase in surface and synaptic GluR1 clusters that colocalized with PSD-95 on dendrites with a simultaneous decrease in internalized GluR1. Surface cross-linking with BS(3) showed enhanced membrane insertions of GluR1, and increased phosphorylation at Ser-845 further supported enhanced surface availability of GluR1 after OGD. NP1 protein colocalized with GluR1 and PSD-95, and OGD significantly increased their synaptic coclustering. Most strikingly, the genetic deletion of NP1 resulted in decreases in surface GluR1 cluster density, synaptic localization, phospho-GluR1 (Ser-845) levels, and neuronal death after OGD compared with WT neurons. AMPA (50 μmol/L) induced NP1 and significant cell death in WT but not in NP1-/- neurons.

Previous work has demonstrated the induction of neuronal pentraxin 1 (NP1) and its colocalization with the AMPAR subunit GluR1 following hypoxic-ischemic (HI) brain injury. However, the specific role of NP1 in regulating GluR1 surface expression, trafficking, and synaptic clustering during HI-induced neuronal death remains unclear. Primary hippocampal neurons from wild-type (WT) and NP1-knockout mice (C57BL/6 background) at days in vitro 12–14 were subjected to oxygen–glucose deprivation (OGD) for 2–8 hours, an in vitro model of ischemic stroke. OGD induced a time-dependent upregulation of NP1 (approximately 4-fold), increased redistribution of AMPAR GluR1 subunits to excitatory synapses, and elevated neuronal death. Surface and synaptic GluR1 clusters colocalized with PSD-95 on dendrites were significantly increased, while internalized GluR1 was reduced. Surface cross-linking with BS³ revealed enhanced membrane insertion of GluR1, and increased phosphorylation at Ser-845 further indicated greater surface availability of GluR1 after OGD. NP1 protein colocalized with both GluR1 and PSD-95, and OGD markedly enhanced their synaptic coclustering. Notably, genetic deletion of NP1 reduced surface GluR1 cluster density, synaptic localization, phospho-GluR1 (Ser-845) levels, and neuronal death following OGD compared to WT neurons. AMPA (50 μmol/L) induced NP1 expression and significant cell death in WT but not in NP1⁻/⁻ neurons.
LLM_2:
---

**Abstract (Polished Version):**

The trafficking of α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazole propionic acid receptors (AMPARs) to excitatory synapses is critical for synaptic function and plasticity. Neuronal pentraxin 1 (NP1) has been previously shown to be upregulated and colocalized with the AMPAR subunit GluR1 following hypoxic-ischemic (HI) brain injury; however, its specific role in regulating GluR1 surface expression, intracellular trafficking, and synaptic clustering during HI-induced neuronal death remains poorly understood. In this study, primary hippocampal neurons derived from wild-type (WT) and NP1-knockout mice (on a C57BL/6 background) at 12–14 days in vitro were subjected to oxygen-glucose deprivation (OGD), an *in vitro* model of ischemic stroke. OGD elicited a time-dependent increase in NP1 expression (approximately fourfold), accompanied by enhanced redistribution of GluR1 to excitatory synapses and increased neuronal cell death. Immunofluorescence analysis revealed a significant increase in surface and synaptic GluR1 clusters colocalized with PSD-95 along dendrites, while intracellular GluR1 levels were reduced. Surface cross-linking assays using BS³ demonstrated increased membrane insertion of GluR1, and elevated phosphorylation at Ser-845 further supported enhanced surface retention of GluR1 following OGD. NP1 colocalized with both GluR1 and PSD-95 at synapses, and this coclustering was markedly intensified under OGD conditions. Notably, genetic ablation of NP1 significantly attenuated OGD-induced increases in surface GluR1 cluster density, synaptic localization, GluR1 phosphorylation at Ser-845, and neuronal death compared to WT controls. Furthermore, application of AMPA (50 μmol/L) induced NP1 expression and triggered substantial cell death in WT neurons, but not in NP1⁻/⁻ neurons. These findings indicate that NP1 plays a critical role in regulating GluR1 trafficking and surface expression during ischemic injury, thereby contributing to excitotoxic neuronal death.

---

The thug stumbled back after Batman punched him. Something on the ground tripped him and he tumbled over. A snap echoed through the alley and a jolt went through Batman's heart. 
 
 The thug lied motionless in the street. Even the subtle rise and fall of his chest was absent. Blood trickled from the back of his head. Batman screamed in horror as the woman who's purse was snatched thanked him. He shot his grappling hook to the roof and fled the scene. 
 
 `` Commissioner, I killed someone last night.'' 
 
 Gordon did not seem terribly phased by Batman's words. `` Cops kill when they have to in the line of duty.''

---

The thug staggered backward from Batman’s punch, his heel catching on a jagged edge in the dark. He fell hard—too hard—and the crack that followed wasn’t the sound of bone meeting stone. It was the snap of fate breaking.

Batman froze.

The man lay sprawled across the alley floor, unnaturally still. No breath stirred his chest. A thin thread of blood crept from beneath his skull, pooling slowly into the grime like ink spilled on old paper. Above him, the woman whose purse had been snatched babbled her thanks—gratitude ringing hollow in the silence between heartbeats.

Batman didn’t answer.

He let out a choked gasp—half sob, half scream—and fired his grappling hook toward the rooftops. He didn’t look back as he ascended into the night.

***

“Commissioner… I killed someone last night.”

Gordon didn’t flinch. His hands rested on the desk, steady, familiar. “Cops kill when they have to. It happens. In the line of duty.”

“I’m *not* a cop!”

Gordon raised his palms, gentle. “I know. But it still happens.”

“It shouldn’t happen to me.” Batman’s voice cracked. “I need to confess.”

“You’re not turning yourself in,” Gordon said softly.

“I *am*.”

Then, slowly, Batman reached up and removed his cowl.

Bruce Wayne stood before him, eyes raw with guilt, face pale beneath the lamplight. Gordon’s breath caught. For once, the commissioner had no words.

“I need to pay my debt,” Bruce whispered.

“You’ve done nothing wrong,” Gordon finally said. “You were protecting this city.”

Days bled into nights. Sleep came in fragments—if at all. Bruce wandered Wayne Manor like a ghost through his own life, haunted by the shape of the man on the pavement, the way his head had lolled sideways, lifeless. Sometimes, in the quiet hours, a thought slithered in: *Maybe he deserved it.*

No.

He crushed it each time. That man should have faced trial. A cell. Judgment—not the cold mercy of gravity and concrete. Cops kill. Soldiers kill. But *Batman*? He was supposed to be more than that. Better.

And yet—no arrest. No trial. No justice.

Worse still was Gordon’s refusal to hold him accountable. There was no punishment. No absolution. Just silence, and the slow rot of impunity.

One evening, Bruce stood before the Batcomputer, the dim glow painting shadows under his eyes. He pulled up the roster of Gotham’s worst—the rogues’ gallery he’d spent years chasing. His finger hovered over the screen.

Then he clicked on the Joker.

If killing is allowed—if death becomes just another cost of doing business—then perhaps it’s time to stop pretending.

Perhaps it’s time to stop holding back.

---

- **Characterization:** Bruce’s internal conflict is amplified through physicality and subtext—his guilt isn't just stated, it's embodied.
- **Thematic Reinforcement:** The central tension—Batman vs. his own code—is sharpened, especially in the final lines, which carry ominous weight.

His breath stank of stale alcohol, his face unkempt and grimy. His eyes were disturbingly bloodshot, almost bulging from his filthy head—not a man you’d care to meet alone at night.

Mr. Marrow looked at the shorter man with disgust. Marrow was nearly the exact opposite of Webb—an incredibly thin man, almost twice as tall. Yet the two contrasting men shared one disturbing trait: both were renowned in the business of kidnapping.

“I mean, sure,” he spluttered. “Looks about, what, eleven? Nice size, not too big… the boss’ll make a pretty penny off him.”

“His hair will fetch a fortune on the Market. Quality, very premium indeed,” agreed Mr. Marrow, his voice clipped and formal.

Webb grunted and stared down at the boy again.

It wasn’t so much that the hair was *dark*—it was more that light seemed to bend around it. It wasn’t just black. It was an absence, a void.

Webb gave a small start as he studied the boy’s face. It was unblemished, generic, completely ordinary. But the expression it wore unnerved him. The eyebrows and mouth were twisted into shapes far too old for a young boy. He looked as though he’d fought wars on every continent, seen things no man should ever see. He looked…

Webb peered through the binoculars once more, only to find their victim staring directly back at him. The two men were completely hidden in bushes and shadow, yet somehow this… this *child* was staring into Webb’s very soul.

---

“Down there.”

“Where? I don’t see him.”

“Look—by that bush… *there!*”

“The scrawny kid in the black trench coat?”

“That’s the one.”

“Hand me those binoculars,” John Webb rasped. “I want a closer look.”  
He was a mountain of a man—broad as he was tall, his body a grotesque parody of proportion. Crooked yellow teeth jutted from his mouth like broken tombstones. His breath reeked of sour whiskey and decay; his face, unshaven and greasy, seemed never to have known soap. But it was his eyes that unsettled most: bloodshot, bulging, swimming with veins like cracked porcelain. Not the sort of man you’d want to meet in a dark alley—or anywhere, really.

They crouched on a balcony high above the street, shadows among shadows, watching the world below fade into dusk.

Mr. Marrow regarded his partner with quiet revulsion. Where Webb was a bloated sack of flesh, Marrow was stretched thin—a skeletal figure nearly twice his height, draped in an immaculate pinstripe suit. His bowler hat caught the last glimmers of twilight, gleaming like polished obsidian. A single wisp of mustache curled beneath his hawkish nose. Impeccable. Sterile. Yet both men shared one unsavory distinction: they were legends in the trade of disappearance.

Without a word, Marrow passed over the binoculars.

Webb pressed them to his eyes, breathing heavily through his nose. After a long silence, he spoke.

“Well,” he grunted, “he’s small. Eleven, maybe twelve. Good size—not too bulky. Boss’ll get top dollar.”

“His *hair*,” Marrow said, voice clipped and precise, “will command a fortune on the Market. Rare quality. Pure grade.”

Webb didn’t answer. He stared again at the boy below.

Now little more than a silhouette against the encroaching night, the child wore darkness like a second skin—black coat, black trousers, black shoes. But it was the *hair* that held Webb’s gaze. It wasn’t simply black. It devoured light. Swallowed it whole. Like staring into a hole in the world. Not color—*absence.*

Then he saw the face.

Smooth. Unmarked. Utterly ordinary.

And yet—wrong.

The features were those of a child, but the expression belonged to something ancient. The brows drawn low in weary disdain, the mouth set in a grimace too knowing, too weathered. As if this boy had stood atop burning cities, walked through mass graves, watched empires rot from within. There was no innocence left. Only memory.

Only danger.

Webb lowered the binoculars, heart thudding.

He glanced at Marrow.

For the first time, the tall man’s mask had slipped. His lips were tight, jaw clenched. He’d seen it too.

Webb swallowed hard, forcing air into his lungs. *This is nothing new,* he told himself. *Just another snatch. Just another payday.* He shoved the image aside. But the fear remained—a cold worm coiling in his gut.

He raised the binoculars once more.

And froze.

The boy was looking *up*.

Not toward the balcony—no, directly at *him*. Through the foliage, through the gloom, through the distance—as if Webb were standing naked before him. Those eyes locked onto his own with impossible precision.

Black. Featureless. Pupil-less voids.

And burning.

Not with anger. With *hatred*. Cold, bottomless, eternal.

“Shit!” Webb gasped.

The binoculars clattered to the floor. He scrambled backward, hands slipping on the stone, breath coming in ragged bursts. Sweat slicked his forehead, rolled down his neck.

“What? What is it?” Marrow hissed, voice sharp with alarm.

Webb could only stammer. “That—fucking—kid—he—”

They both turned to the street.

Empty.

The boy was gone.

---

“S… Sir?”

“Sir!”

Commissioner Harrison jerked upright in the passenger seat of the squad car, blinking awake. He rubbed his eyes, stepped out onto cracked asphalt, and squinted down at the nervous officer who’d called him.

“…Yes?”

“The—uh—the forensics team just wrapped up, sir.” The young man stuttered, fingers twitching at his sides. “No tracks. No fingerprints. No shell casings. No poison. No wounds. N-nothing, sir.”

Harrison stared. Silent. Unblinking.

The officer flushed crimson, then looked away.

After a full minute, the Commissioner exhaled—a dry, humorless laugh curling from his lips.

“And they’re the same as…?”

“Yes, S-Sir,” the officer blurted, voice cracking. “Same as all the others.”

“Same as the *goddamn* others,” Harrison murmured. “Of course they are.”

He laughed again—short, strangled—and kicked the tire of the squad car hard enough to leave a dent.

When he looked up, the officer was already retreating toward the row of forensic tents pitched in the center of the crime scene. Behind them, emergency lights pulsed like a dying heartbeat across a sea of police cruisers and ambulances.

“Hey, kid!” Harrison called.

The officer stopped. Dead still. One foot frozen mid-step.

Slowly, he turned his head.

“Yes, *Sir?*” he whispered.

Harrison blinked. The sudden halt—it was unnatural. Too precise. Like a puppet catching the string.

“I—never caught your name,” he said. “You new?”

He watched the man’s posture shift—shoulders dropping, face softening from something cold and unreadable back into timid youth.

“Y-yes, sir. Drafted in last week,” the officer mumbled, hurrying away without another word.

Alone now, Harrison lit one of his signature cigars. The flame flickered in his cupped hands, casting hollows beneath his cheekbones.

He took a long drag, smoke curling into the night, and surveyed the scene.

It was different this time. Not in the lack of evidence—that never changed. No traces. No cause of death. Bodies found perfectly intact, hearts simply… *stopped*. Every time.

But the bags.

One was short. Bloated. Barely filled a standard gurney.

The other—so long it required two stretchers lashed together.

Harrison blew out a plume of smoke, eyes distant.

Another killer loose. Another ghost.

And then—unbidden—his thoughts returned to the boy-faced officer. How young he looked. How very still. How utterly silent.

And how *black* his hair was.

Not just dark.

Like a shadow given form.

Like something that shouldn’t be.

---

### Notes on the Polishing:
- **Tone & Atmosphere**: Enhanced the noir, eerie mood with richer sensory details (e.g., "swimming with veins like cracked porcelain," "smoke curling into the night").
- **Pacing & Rhythm**: Varied sentence structure for dramatic effect—short, punchy lines during tension; longer, flowing sentences for introspection.
- **Character Depth**: Subtle psychological cues added (e.g., Marrow’s slight loss of composure, Webb’s internal struggle) to deepen realism.
- **Imagery**: Strengthened metaphors ("a hole in the world," "puppet catching the string") to elevate literary quality.
- **Dialogue**: Preserved naturalism while tightening delivery for impact.

The paper studies the problem of uniformity testing in ranking data: that is testing whether an unknown distribution is uniformly random over possible rankings OR it is epsilon away from it (in total variation distance). Noting that this problem in general is quite hard, they consider the special case where the alt-hypothesis is that the unknown distribution is a single parameter Mallows model (i.e., exponential decay of permutations around an unknown fixed ranking).

The key contributions of the paper include a testing method for this problem with O(1/\sqrt(m)) samples. They also show that they can adapt their algorithm to enable local differential privacy.

As I mentioned, the central contributions of the paper include a testing method for this problem with O(1/\sqrt(m)) samples (they also show only two samples are needed when m, the number of items, is large enough -- which also follows from the above result (?). Why not just present this one result instead of two). They also show that they can adapt their algorithm to enable differential privacy.

The underlying idea behind this (non-private) result is quite simple to describe: partition the items into m/2 random disjoint pairs and construct a random variable that accounts for the deviations between the pairs of items. The idea is if the null hypothesis is satisfied value of the above random variable is large, else if the unknown distribution follows the mallows model, then the value is significantly small.

I like the simplicity of the algorithm -- which means it can useful in practice. On the flip side, I wonder if the assumption on alternative hypothesis class being a single variable exponential around a fixed ranking makes the problem too simple and uninteresting. The proof structure seems to following standard concentration analyses.
LLM_1:
This paper addresses uniformity testing for ranking data, distinguishing whether an unknown distribution is uniformly random over all possible rankings or at least ε away in total variation distance. Recognizing the general hardness of this problem, the authors focus on a specific alternative hypothesis: that the distribution follows a single-parameter Mallows model, characterized by exponential decay around an unknown central ranking.

The main contributions are a testing method requiring O(1/√m) samples and an adaptation of the algorithm to satisfy local differential privacy. Notably, the sample complexity reduces to just two samples when the number of items m is sufficiently large—a consequence of the primary bound. Presenting both results may be somewhat redundant; emphasizing the more general O(1/√m) bound might streamline the exposition.

The core algorithmic idea is straightforward: partition items into m/2 random disjoint pairs and define a statistic capturing deviations within these pairs. Under the uniform null hypothesis, this statistic tends to be large, whereas under the Mallows alternative, it becomes significantly smaller.

I appreciate the simplicity and practical applicability of the proposed method. However, the restriction to a single-parameter Mallows model as the alternative may oversimplify the problem, potentially limiting its broader interest. The analysis relies largely on standard concentration techniques, which, while effective, may not introduce novel methodological insights.

human: Diffuse gliomas represent the most prevalent class of primary brain tumor. Despite significant recent advances in the understanding of glioblastoma [World Health Organization (WHO) IV], its most malignant subtype, lower grade (WHO II and III) glioma variants remain comparatively understudied, especially in light of their notable clinical heterogeneity. Accordingly, we sought to identify and characterize clinically relevant molecular subclasses of lower grade diffuse astrocytic gliomas.We conducted multidimensional molecular profiling, including global transcriptional analysis, on 101 lower grade diffuse astrocytic gliomas collected at our own institution and validated our findings using publically available gene expression and copy number data from large independent patient cohorts.We found that IDH mutational status delineated molecularly and clinically distinct glioma subsets, with IDH mutant (IDH mt) tumors exhibiting TP53 mutations, platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR)A overexpression, and prolonged survival, and IDH wild-type (IDH wt) tumors exhibiting EGFR amplification, PTEN loss, and unfavorable disease outcome. Furthermore, global expression profiling revealed three robust molecular subclasses within lower grade diffuse astrocytic gliomas, two of which were predominantly IDH mt and one almost entirely IDH wt. IDH mt subclasses were distinguished from each other on the basis of TP53 mutations, DNA copy number abnormalities, and links to distinct stages of neurogenesis in the subventricular zone. This latter finding implicates discrete pools of neuroglial progenitors as cells of origin for the different subclasses of IDH mt tumors.
LLM_1: Diffuse gliomas constitute the most common type of primary brain tumor. While considerable progress has been made in elucidating glioblastoma (World Health Organization grade IV), its most aggressive form, lower-grade (WHO grades II–III) diffuse gliomas have received less attention, particularly given their substantial clinical variability. This study aimed to define and characterize clinically significant molecular subtypes within lower-grade diffuse astrocytic gliomas. Multidimensional molecular profiling, encompassing genome-wide transcriptional analysis, was performed on 101 lower-grade diffuse astrocytic glioma samples from an institutional cohort. Findings were validated using independent, publicly available gene expression and copy-number datasets from large patient cohorts. IDH mutation status was found to separate gliomas into molecularly and clinically distinct groups: IDH-mutant tumors displayed frequent TP53 mutations, platelet-derived growth factor receptor A (PDGFRA) overexpression, and longer survival, whereas IDH wild-type tumors showed EGFR amplification, PTEN loss, and poorer outcomes. Moreover, global expression profiling identified three robust molecular subclasses within lower-grade diffuse astrocytic gliomas—two predominantly IDH-mutant and one almost exclusively IDH wild-type. The IDH-mutant subclasses were distinguished by TP53 mutation status, DNA copy-number alterations, and associations with specific neurogenic stages in the subventricular zone. This observation suggests distinct neuroglial progenitor populations as potential cells of origin for different IDH-mutant glioma subtypes.
LLM_2: This study systematically characterizes molecularly defined subtypes of lower-grade (World Health Organization grades II–III) diffuse astrocytic gliomas through integrative multidimensional profiling. Despite advances in understanding glioblastoma (WHO grade IV), lower-grade variants exhibit considerable clinical heterogeneity that remains poorly understood at the molecular level. To address this, genome-wide transcriptional and genomic analyses were conducted on 101 tumor samples from an institutional cohort, with validation performed using independent, publicly available gene expression and copy-number datasets. Molecular stratification revealed that isocitrate dehydrogenase (*IDH*) mutation status serves as a fundamental discriminator, delineating biologically and clinically distinct entities: *IDH*-mutant tumors are associated with frequent *TP53* mutations, overexpression of platelet-derived growth factor receptor alpha (*PDGFRA*), and improved survival, whereas *IDH* wild-type tumors are characterized by epidermal growth factor receptor (*EGFR*) amplification, phosphatase and tensin homolog (*PTEN*) loss, and more aggressive clinical behavior. Unsupervised clustering based on global gene expression profiles further resolved three robust molecular subclasses—two enriched for *IDH*-mutant cases and one predominantly composed of *IDH* wild-type tumors. Notably, the *IDH*-mutant subclasses differ by somatic alteration patterns, including *TP53* status and DNA copy-number aberrations, and show differential alignment with specific neurogenic stages in the subventricular zone, implicating distinct neural progenitor cell populations as potential cells of origin. These findings provide a refined molecular framework for the classification of lower-grade diffuse astrocytic gliomas, with implications for prognostication and therapeutic development.

I ’ m a vampire … ” he began. 
 
 “ Okay, that ’ s it. ” 
 
 She stood up, gathered her coat and bag and stared walking towards the parlor door. 
 
 “ Excuse me? ” the man in the upright armchair across from her seemed surprised at her sudden departure but more so at her sudden anger. 
 
 “ You seriously think I ’ m going to sit here and let you insult my family. Just cause my grandfather had … issues, doesn ’ t give you the right to make fun of him or me. ” 
 
 She stepped out into the shadowy hallway and felt something brush against her arm. 
 
 “ I ’ m not making fun of anyone. ” 
 
 Quickly turning she found him standing right behind her. She hadn ’ t heard him move yet he must have sprinted to cover the distance that had been between them in the second she ’ d turned away. He loomed over her, his dark eyes glinting in the candlelight as they peered into hers. 
 
 “ Oh no, you just happened to claim you ’ re a vampire without knowing what it means to me ” she placed her hand on his chest and forcefully pushed him back to arms length. “ Well let me tell you something, I ’ ve put up with that sort of thing for long enough. ” 
 
 “ I ’ m trying to tell you something important! ” 
 
 “ They always say it ’ s important. I only came here because I thought you had a serious offer of employment. But once again it ’ s just another joke at my expense. I ’ m a vampire, I ’ m a monster, let me bite you pretty lady. Well this is the last straw. ” 
 
 “ I ’ m not asking to taste your blood madam I simply wish to ask you to … ”

Well a good stern word and a swift knee between the legs help usually deals with that. And they don ’ t dare ask me to kiss it better afterwards. ” 
 
 He seemed temporarily stunned as he listened to her talk. She strode down the hallway without further interruption until she reached the large front door. 
 
 “ This is a serious matter of life and death ” he called out. 
 
 “ Good day to you ” She said sharply and gripped the ornamental door handle. 
 
 “ Wait, no! ” 
 
 She flung the front door open and heard her host yelling behind her. But when she looked back he had gone, probably to sulk at the fact she ’ d not played along with his pathetic attempt at humor. LLM_1:
“I am a vampire,” he started.

“Right. That’s enough.”

She rose, collected her coat and bag, and moved toward the parlor door.

“Pardon?” The man seated in the armchair opposite looked startled—not just by her abrupt exit, but by the heat in her tone.

“Do you honestly expect me to listen to you insult my family? Just because my grandfather had… difficulties, that doesn’t entitle you to mock him. Or me.”

She stepped into the dim hall—and felt a light touch against her sleeve.

“I am not mocking anyone.”

Whirling, she found him already behind her. She hadn’t heard a step, yet he must have crossed the space between them in the instant she’d turned away. He stood close, towering, his dark eyes catching the candlelight as they held hers.

“Oh, of course not. You just happened to announce you’re a vampire, with no idea what that means to me.” She pressed a palm to his chest and shoved him firmly back. “Let me tell you something—I’ve endured this kind of nonsense long enough.”

“I am trying to tell you something important!”

“It’s always important. I only came because I believed you had a real job to offer. But once again, it’s just another joke at my expense. ‘I’m a vampire, I’m a monster, let me bite you, pretty lady.’ Well, this is the last time.”

“Madam, I do not wish to taste your blood. I only wish to ask you to—”

“Don’t,” she cut in, her face tightening with anger and revulsion, “even start with jokes about… *sucking* things. And they all think it’s so clever, as if I’ve never heard it before. Usually, a sharp word and a swift knee settle the matter. And they never ask me to kiss it better afterward.”

He fell silent, momentarily stunned. She turned and marched down the hall, unimpeded, until she reached the heavy front door.

“This is a matter of life and death,” he called after her.

“Good day,” she said curtly, her hand closing on the ornate handle.

“Wait—please!”

She threw the door open, hearing his protest behind her. But when she glanced back, he was gone—probably off to sulk because she hadn’t indulged his pathetic humor. She clicked her tongue as sunlight spilled in, illuminating the large cloud of dust and ash suspended in the air.

“And you might tidy up in here,” Miss Van Helsing called over her shoulder. “Opening the curtains would help you see the mess.”
LLM_2:
“I am a vampire,” he said, voice low but steady, as if confessing a truth long buried beneath silence.

“Charming.”  

She rose in one fluid motion, snatching up her coat and clutching her bag like a shield. Without another glance, she turned toward the parlor door, heels clicking against the worn floorboards.

“Pardon?” The man in the armchair startled upright, his expression caught between disbelief and something sharper—wounded surprise. “You’re leaving? After just that?”

“You expect me to sit here while you mock my bloodline?” She didn’t turn, but her voice cracked like a whip. “Just because my grandfather was *different*, because he walked paths others feared—it doesn’t give you the right to sneer at his memory. Or mine.”

The hallway swallowed her the moment she stepped into it—a narrow throat of shadow lit only by the occasional guttering sconce. Then came the brush of fingers on her sleeve, feather-light, yet it froze her mid-step.

“I am not mocking him.”  

She spun—and found him already there, impossibly close, though she hadn’t heard him rise, let alone cross the room. He loomed over her now, tall and still as stone, eyes dark pools catching the faint glow of candlelight from behind. There was no breathlessness in him, no sign of movement. As if he had always stood there.

“Oh, I’m sure,” she snapped, shoving hard against his chest. He yielded slightly—not from force, she suspected, but concession. “How convenient that your grand revelation happens to echo every drunken fool who’s ever tried to impress me with fangs and filth. ‘I’m a monster,’ they say, grinning like wolves. ‘Let me taste you.’ Well, I’ve had enough of monsters playing at tragedy.”

“This is not a game!” His voice cracked through the dimness, sudden and raw. “I am trying to tell you something real!”

“And it’s *always* real,” she shot back, bitterness curling her words. “I came here for work—something honest, something solid. Not another masquerade. Not another man dressing up his cruelty as romance. ‘I’m cursed, I’m ancient, I hunger for you—’ Spare me. I’ve heard every line, endured every leer. Most learn quickly when I introduce them to my knee. None have ever dared ask me to kiss it better.”

He went utterly still. Even the air seemed to pause.

She turned away, marched down the hall without looking back, her pulse hammering more from fury than fear. The front door loomed ahead—solid, heavy, promising escape.

“This is a matter of life and death,” he called after her, voice echoing strangely, as if spoken from deeper within the house than the space allowed.

“Good day,” she replied, cold and clipped, fingers closing around the ornate brass handle.

“Wait—please!”

With a sharp twist, she threw the door open. Sunlight surged in like a flood, golden and blinding. For a heartbeat, she saw dust swirling in the light—no, not dust. Ash. A great cloud of it, hanging suspended, drifting slowly downward as if settling from a recent disturbance.

And he was gone.

Not retreating. Not stepping back into shadow.

*Gone.*

She exhaled sharply through her nose, lips thinning. Probably vanished into some brooding corner to nurse his wounded pride, offended that she wouldn’t play along.

“Do us both a favor,” Miss Van Helsing said aloud, her voice cutting clean through the quiet, “and tidy this place up. A little light might help you see how far you’ve fallen into ruin.”

She stepped out, letting the sun seal the past behind her.

The GAN approach has been compared to CAGAN for inpainting different clothes to an input image of a person in the foreground. The approach amounts to changing the loss function injecting some new terms, the newer one is a perceptual base one.

The results are not satisfying, even if better than CAGAN. In fact, the new clothes are remarkably changed (the stripes red t-shirts becomes a washed out garment). Unfortunately, these are the details that let a person choose and buy an item. Plus, the face of the persons become distorted. Finally, candidate people having diverse types of body shape (endomorph, mesomorph, ectomorph) should have been included.
LLM_1: The authors compare their GAN-based method to CAGAN for clothing inpainting on foreground person images, primarily by augmenting the loss function with additional terms, including a perceptual loss. However, the results remain unsatisfactory—though improved over CAGAN—as the inpainted garments undergo noticeable alteration (e.g., a striped red t-shirt appears washed out). Such details are critical for realistic apparel visualization and consumer decision-making. Additionally, facial distortions are introduced, and the evaluation lacks diversity in body types (e.g., endomorph, mesomorph, ectomorph), limiting the claimed generality.
LLM_2: The authors propose a GAN-based approach for clothing inpainting on foreground person images, building upon CAGAN by enhancing the loss function with additional components, such as perceptual loss. While the method shows improvement over the baseline, the results still fall short in key aspects of visual fidelity. Notably, synthesized garments exhibit visible artifacts—for instance, a striped red t-shirt appears washed out—indicating insufficient preservation of fine texture and color details, which are crucial for realistic virtual try-on and user trust in applications like e-commerce. Moreover, unintended distortions in facial regions suggest potential instability or misalignment in the generation process. A more significant limitation lies in the evaluation: the experiments lack diversity in body morphologies (e.g., endomorph, mesomorph, ectomorph), thereby weakening the claim of generalizability across body types. A more comprehensive assessment across varied anatomical profiles would strengthen the validity of the conclusions.

human: To test whether academic centers (ACs) are more successful than nonacademic centers (NACs) in immunohistochemistry (IHC) external quality assessment challenges in the Canadian Immunohistochemistry Quality Control (CIQC) program.Results of 9 CIQC challenges for breast cancer marker (BM) and various non-breast cancer marker (NBM) tests were examined. Success rates were compared between AC/NAC laboratories and those located in small or large cities. Performance was also correlated with annual IHC case volumes.There was no statistically significant difference in performance in any of the comparisons. However, overall performance on BM was significantly better (P < .0001, t test) than on NBM tests regardless of AC/NAC nature or city size. The mean failure rate on NBM was approximately twice that of BM tests.
LLM_1: This study evaluated whether academic centers (ACs) outperform nonacademic centers (NACs) in immunohistochemistry (IHC) external quality assessment challenges within the Canadian Immunohistochemistry Quality Control (CIQC) program. Results from nine CIQC challenges for breast cancer markers (BMs) and various non-breast cancer markers (NBMs) were analyzed. Success rates were compared between AC and NAC laboratories, as well as between laboratories located in small and large cities. Performance was further correlated with annual IHC case volumes. In this paper the authors propose an algorithm to reduce the memory
requirements for calculating relative position vectors in a
self-attention (transformer) network, based on the work of [Vaswani et
al., 2017; Shaw et al. 2018]. The authors applied their model to a music
generation task, and evaluated it on two datasets (J.S. Bach Chorales
and Piano-e-Competition). Their model obtained improvements over the
state-of-the-art in the Piano-e-Competition set in terms of
log-likelihoods. Additionally, they performed human evaluation on the
Piano-e-Competition set showing preference of the participants for their
method over the state-of-the-art.

The application of the transformer network seems suitable for the task,
and the authors fairly justify their motivations and choices. They show
improvements over the-state-of-the-art for one data-set and explained
their results. They also show an interesting application of
sequence-to-sequence models for generating complete pieces of music
based on a given melody.

My main concern is the novelty of the paper. The authors use the model
proposed by [Shaw et al. 2018] with an additional modification to manage
very long sequences proposed by [Liu et al., 2018; Parmar et al., 2018],
(chunking the input sequences in non-overlaping blocks and calculating
attention only on the current and the previous blocks). Their main
contribution is to reduce the memory requirement for matrix operations
for calculating the relative position vectors of the self-attention
function, which was sub-optimal in [Shaw et al. 2018]. The memory
reduction is from O(L^2D+L^2) to O(LD+L^2). I would qualify this as an
optimization in the implementation of the existing method rather than a
new approach.

Their model achieves improved log-likelihoods over the state-of-the-art on the Piano-e-Competition dataset. Furthermore, a human evaluation conducted on the same dataset indicates a preference among participants for the proposed method compared to existing approaches.

The application of the transformer architecture is well-suited to the task, and the authors provide a clear rationale for their methodological choices. They demonstrate performance gains over the state-of-the-art on one dataset and offer a thorough analysis of the results. The work also presents a compelling use of sequence-to-sequence modeling for generating complete musical compositions from a given melody.

human: Impairment of the gastrointestinal mucosal barrier contributes to progression of HIV infection. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effect of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) on the HIV-induced intestinal barrier defect and to identify underlying mechanisms.Epithelial barrier function was characterised by impedance spectroscopy and [(3)H]mannitol fluxes in duodenal biopsies from 11 untreated and 8 suppressively treated HIV-infected patients, and 9 HIV-seronegative controls. The villus/crypt ratio was determined microscopically. Epithelial apoptoses were analysed by terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase-mediated deoxyuridine triphosphate nick-end labelling (TUNEL) and caspase-3 staining. Tight junction protein expression was quantified by densitometric analysis of immunoblots. Mucosal cytokine production was determined by cytometric bead array.Only in untreated but not in treated HIV-infected patients, epithelial resistance was reduced (13 (1) vs 23 (2) ohm cm(2), p<0.01) and mannitol permeability was increased compared with HIV-negative controls (19 (3) vs 9 (1) nm/s, p<0.05). As structural correlates, epithelial apoptoses and expression of the pore-forming claudin-2 were increased while expression of the sealing claudin-1 was reduced in untreated compared with treated patients and HIV-negative controls. Furthermore, villous atrophy was evident and mucosal production of interleukin 2 (IL2), IL4 and tumour necrosis factor alpha (TNFalpha) was increased in untreated but not in treated HIV-infected patients. Incubation with IL2, IL4, TNFalpha and IL13 reduced the transepithelial resistance of rat jejunal mucosa.
LLM_1: Impairment of the gastrointestinal mucosal barrier is implicated in the advancement of HIV infection. This study aimed to examine the impact of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) on HIV-associated intestinal barrier dysfunction and to elucidate the mechanisms involved. Duodenal biopsies from 11 untreated and 8 suppressively treated HIV-infected patients, along with 9 HIV-seronegative controls, were assessed for epithelial barrier function using impedance spectroscopy and [(3)H]mannitol flux measurements. Microscopic analysis determined the villus/crypt ratio. Epithelial apoptosis was evaluated via terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase-mediated deoxyuridine triphosphate nick-end labelling (TUNEL) and caspase-3 staining. Tight junction protein expression was quantified by densitometric immunoblot analysis, and mucosal cytokine production was measured by cytometric bead array. Results indicated that untreated HIV-infected patients exhibited reduced epithelial resistance (13 (1) vs 23 (2) ohm cm(2), p<0.01) and increased mannitol permeability (19 (3) vs 9 (1) nm/s, p<0.05) relative to HIV-negative controls, whereas treated patients did not differ significantly. Structural alterations in untreated patients included elevated epithelial apoptosis and increased expression of the pore-forming claudin-2, alongside decreased expression of the sealing claudin-1, compared to both treated patients and controls. Additionally, villous atrophy was observed, and mucosal production of interleukin 2 (IL2), IL4, and tumour necrosis factor alpha (TNFα) was heightened in untreated patients. In vitro incubation with IL2, IL4, TNFα, and IL13 reduced transepithelial resistance in rat jejunal mucosa.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

Gastrointestinal mucosal barrier dysfunction plays a critical role in the pathogenesis and progression of HIV infection. This study investigated the effects of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) on intestinal barrier integrity in HIV-infected individuals and explored underlying molecular and immunological mechanisms. Duodenal biopsy specimens were obtained from 11 HIV-infected patients not receiving treatment, 8 HIV-infected patients with sustained viral suppression under HAART, and 9 HIV-seronegative controls. Epithelial barrier function was assessed using impedance spectroscopy and [(3)H]mannitol paracellular flux assays. Histomorphological changes were evaluated by determining the villus/crypt ratio, while epithelial apoptosis was quantified via terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase-mediated dUTP nick-end labeling (TUNEL) and caspase-3 immunostaining. Expression levels of tight junction proteins—specifically claudin-1 and claudin-2—were analyzed by densitometric immunoblotting, and mucosal cytokine profiles were measured using cytometric bead array. Compared to HIV-negative controls, untreated HIV-infected individuals exhibited significantly reduced transepithelial electrical resistance (13 (1) vs. 23 (2) Ω·cm², p < 0.01) and elevated mannitol permeability (19 (3) vs. 9 (1) nm/s, p < 0.05), indicating impaired barrier function; these abnormalities were normalized in HAART-treated patients. Untreated patients also demonstrated increased epithelial apoptosis, altered tight junction protein expression characterized by upregulation of pore-forming claudin-2 and downregulation of barrier-sealing claudin-1, and histological evidence of villous atrophy. Moreover, mucosal production of pro-inflammatory and immune-regulatory cytokines—including interleukin-2 (IL-2), IL-4, tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), and IL-13—was significantly elevated in untreated infection. In vitro experiments revealed that exposure to IL-2, IL-4, TNF-α, and IL-13 induced a reduction in transepithelial resistance in rat jejunal epithelium, suggesting a direct contribution of these cytokines to barrier disruption. These findings indicate that HAART ameliorates HIV-associated intestinal barrier dysfunction, potentially through modulation of apoptosis, tight junction protein expression, and mucosal immune activation.
