`` Away from the light of justice, in the darkness of evil, I bring justice. Face... Shadowlaw.'' 
 
 The mugger looked around, suddenly much more frightened than those he was attempting to rob a moment before. He scanned the alleyway, but the voice seemed to come from everywhere. Waving his gun back and forth, there was barely a warning as the whoosh of a disk rammed into his hand. As the weapon tumbled from his now numb hand, the mugger turned to run out of the alleyway. He made just a few steps before a second disk bounced off the back of his head; he slumped to the ground, unconscious. 
 
 The disk bounced spun to a stop in front of the shocked couple, and they watched it spin until they could make out a symbol on the side. It *was* him, he was n't just a myth! But what... what now? Motion drew their attention to the mugger, and they saw him. 
 
 Dressed in blacks and greys, they saw clearly the man that to this point had only been captured in the grainiest of photographs. What some called `` vigilante,'' others called `` hero.'' It was him -- Shadowlaw. 
 
 `` You have nothing to fear from me,'' the man growled, still kneeling over the mugger. He was using zip-ties to bind the criminal's wrists behind his back. He moved down to the mugger's ankles, tying them together as well. 
 
 `` I ca n't believe it,'' the woman said, `` you saved us!'' 
 
 The couple was surprised. The vigilante, hero, whatever, had stopped. He remained motionless. 
 
 After a few silent seconds, she asked `` Um, so, now what?'' 
 
 This seemed to jolt the vigilante back to life. `` Um, well, you're safe now, obviously,'' he growled, though the growl was much more forced than before. He turned to face the couple; a helmet kept his eyes from view, but his mouth was visible, and it was a hard line, as though the vigilante were holding something back. `` So, you are, um, out on a date?'' 
 
 The man of the couple nodded. `` It's our three-month anniversary.'' 
 
 `` **Three! **... um, three months, really?'' asked the vigilante. `` Sounds serious.'' 
 
 `` Well, I like to think so,'' said the man, though the woman appeared to be a bit embarrassed by it. 
 
 `` Glad,'' and Shadowlaw stopped short. He cleared his throat. `` Glad to, ah, hear it. Love is... love is very hard,'' and his voice broke a moment. `` Hard to find,'' he finally managed to growl out. Shadowlaw quickly looked down to his gauntlet, a wrist-computer that helped make his fight for justice possible. `` I'm calling the police; they will be here shortly. Give them a statement.'' 
 
 This seemed to alarm the woman. `` No no, really, we should just go on our way...'' 
 
 `` *NO! *'' Shadowlaw interrupted. `` People who cheat... I mean, people who commit crimes can not be allowed to escape justice. If you do n't press charges, if you do n't *do the right thing, * Sharon, then justice is undone.'' 
 
 She nodded, and then looked shocked. `` Wait, how do you know my name?'' 
 
 Shadowlaw's face, what little they saw of it, was stony. `` I heard him say your name when you were first attacked.'' 
 
 `` I, uh, did n't think...'' 
 
 `` *The shadows hide few secrets from me, *'' he growled. His arm shot upward, there was a burst from his grappling gun, and Shadowlaw shot into the air. He disappeared just as quickly as he arrived. 
 
 Sharon felt her date's arms around her shoulders, as he said `` I can hear sirens. Everything's going to be okay.'' She was n't at all certain of that. 
 
 Reports of street crime foiled by a vigilante skyrocketed that night, even as Shadowlaw discovered that tears obscure his helmet's tactical display.

---

**Away from the light of justice, in the darkness of evil, I bring justice.  
Face… Shadowlaw.**

The mugger froze. His fear—sudden, sharp, suffocating—cut deeper than any he’d ever inspired in his victims. A moment ago, he had been the predator. Now, he was prey.

He spun in the alley, boots scraping wet concrete, but the voice had no source. It came from the walls, the sky, the silence between heartbeats. He swung his gun wildly into the dark—too late.

A whirring disk split the air like a whisper of steel. It struck his hand with surgical precision. Pain flared; the weapon clattered from numb fingers. He turned to run—but another disc glanced off the back of his skull. Not hard enough to fracture bone. Just hard enough to black out.

He collapsed, unconscious, onto the damp pavement.

The first disk skidded across the ground, spinning in slow circles before the stunned couple. It gleamed under the flickering streetlight, coming to rest at their feet. As it stilled, a symbol emerged on its surface—etched in silver, pulsing faintly.

*It was him.*

Not rumor. Not urban legend. *Real.*

But what… what were they supposed to do now?

Movement drew their eyes back to the fallen man. Then—*him*.

Clad in blacks and greys, woven from shadow and silence, he stood as if conjured by the night itself. Taller than the photographs suggested. Still as stone. Some called him a vigilante. Others, a hero. But there was only one name whispered in alleys and precincts alike:

**Shadowlaw.**

“You have nothing to fear from me,” he growled, kneeling over the unconscious mugger. With swift, practiced motions, he zip-tied wrists, then ankles—efficient, impersonal. Justice delivered without ceremony.

“I can’t believe it,” the woman breathed. “You… you saved us.”

They stared. And for the first time, the figure went still.

Silence stretched. Then, tentatively: “Um… so. Now what?”

The question seemed to pull him back from somewhere distant—some place darker than the alley around them. He turned toward them. His helmet concealed his eyes, but his mouth was visible: a tight, unyielding line, like a wound stitched shut.

“Well,” he said, voice strained, “you’re safe now. Obviously.” A pause. Then, softer: “Out on a date?”

The man nodded. “It’s our three-month anniversary.”

“**Three!**” Shadowlaw’s voice cracked—then corrected itself, too quickly. “...Three months. Really? That’s… serious.”

“I like to think so,” the man replied. His partner flushed, just slightly.

Shadowlaw looked away. “Glad—” He stopped. Cleared his throat. “Glad to hear it.” Another pause. Longer. “Love is… love is hard to find.” His voice trembled—just once—on the last word. Then he dropped his gaze to the gauntlet on his wrist. Its screen glowed faintly, casting pale blue shadows across his jaw. “I’m calling the police. They’ll be here soon. Give them your statement.”

The woman shook her head. “No, we should just go—”

“***NO!***” The word tore from him, raw and sudden. “People who cheat—I mean, people who *commit crimes*—can’t escape justice. If you don’t press charges… if you don’t *do the right thing*, Sharon…” He paused. “Then justice isn’t justice. It’s surrender.”

She blinked. “Wait—how do you know my name?”

His expression didn’t change—but something in the set of his jaw tightened. “I heard him say it when he attacked you.”

“I… didn’t think…”

“***The shadows hide few secrets from me.***”

In one fluid motion, his arm snapped upward. A grappling gun fired—a thin cable biting into brick. With a final gust of wind, he rose, vanishing into the night as swiftly as he had come, swallowed by the city’s breath.

Sharon felt her date’s arms wrap around her shoulders. “I hear sirens,” he whispered. “Everything’s going to be okay.”

She wasn’t sure at all.

That night, reports of foiled street crimes surged across the city.

And high above, perched on a gargoyle slick with rain, Shadowlaw wiped a gloved hand across his visor.

Tears, he discovered, blur even the most advanced tactical display.

---

### Notes on the Polishing:
- **Tone & Atmosphere:** Enhanced the noir-tinged, cinematic mood with richer sensory details (e.g., “woven from shadow and silence,” “swallowed by the city’s breath”).
- **Pacing & Rhythm:** Broke longer paragraphs for dramatic effect, using shorter sentences to heighten tension.
- **Character Depth:** Subtly humanized Shadowlaw—his voice cracks, he corrects himself, hesitates—hinting at inner conflict beneath the stoic exterior.
- **Dialogue Refinement:** Made exchanges more natural and emotionally resonant, especially the awkward yet poignant moment about love.
- **Symbolism & Closure:** The final line ties theme and image together—justice obscured by emotion, technology failing where humanity intrudes.

human: Deriving an appropriate differential diagnosis is a key clinical competency, but there is little data available on how medical students learn this skill. Software resources designed to complement clinical reasoning might be asset in helping them in this task.The goals of this study were to identify the resources third year medical students use to solve a challenging diagnostic case, and specifically to evaluate the usefulness of Isabel, a second-generation electronic diagnosis support system.Third year medical students (n = 117) were presented a challenging case and asked to identify and prioritize their top 3 diagnoses, report the time devoted to the exercise, and list the resources they used and their relative usefulness. Students were randomized to receive (or not) free access, instruction, and encouragement to use to a web-based decision support system (Isabel).Students who identified the correct diagnosis as their first choice spent significantly more time on the case than did the other students (3.75 +/- 0.28 hours vs 2.88 +/- 0.15 hours, p < 0.05). Participants were randomly assigned to receive or not receive complimentary access, training, and encouragement to use the web-based decision support system (Isabel). Students who correctly identified the diagnosis as their primary choice invested significantly more time in the case compared to their peers (3.75 ± 0.28 hours versus 2.88 ± 0.15 hours, p < 0.05). This study sought to identify the resources employed by third-year medical students when confronted with a complex diagnostic scenario, with particular emphasis on evaluating the effectiveness of Isabel, a second-generation electronic diagnostic support system. A total of 117 third-year medical students were presented with a challenging case and asked to enumerate and prioritize their top three differential diagnoses, record the time devoted to the task, and document the resources utilized along with their perceived efficacy. Participants were randomly assigned to either receive or forgo complimentary access, training, and encouragement to utilize the web-based decision support system (Isabel). ---

### Strengths

- The manuscript is clearly written and well-organized, with a logical structure that facilitates comprehension. The presentation of ideas is coherent, and the overall readability is strong.

- The primary contribution—a neural network-based pipeline for multi-codebook quantization (MCQ)—is both novel and practically motivated. The proposed framework, DeepQ, offers a conceptually simple yet effective solution to the MCQ problem, which may inspire further research at the intersection of deep learning and approximate nearest neighbor search.

- The analysis of computational latency is thorough and empirically well-supported. The authors provide detailed profiling of runtime performance, which strengthens the practical relevance of their method, particularly in resource-constrained or real-time retrieval scenarios.

### Weaknesses

I appreciate the authors’ efforts in developing an innovative approach to multi-codebook quantization. While the work shows promise, several concerns—primarily related to experimental validation and comparative analysis—warrant clarification before a final assessment can be made.

- Although DeepQ demonstrates favorable efficiency, its accuracy gains appear limited in key experimental settings. For instance, as shown in Table 2, DeepQ achieves a Recall@1 of 28.0 on the SIFT1M dataset under the 64-bit configuration, which is notably lower than LSQ’s 33.2—a gap of approximately 5 percentage points. This discrepancy raises questions about the validity of characterizing DeepQ’s performance as “comparable” to LSQ without further qualification. Similarly, on the DEEP1M dataset, improvements over baseline methods are marginal, often ranging between 0.1 and 0.5 percentage points in Recall@1. These modest gains suggest that the empirical advantage of DeepQ may be dataset- and setting-dependent, and thus require more nuanced discussion.

- The introduction of VC-PPO—an adapted variant of the PPO algorithm intended to accelerate training convergence—is a notable design choice. However, the current evaluation lacks sufficient ablation evidence to isolate the impact of VC-PPO on model performance and convergence speed. A dedicated ablation study comparing training dynamics with and without VC-PPO, or against standard PPO, would significantly strengthen the authors’ claims regarding its effectiveness.

- Several minor issues should be addressed in revision. Notably, the term “state-of-the-arts” in the caption of Table 2 is grammatically incorrect; the appropriate phrasing is “state-of-the-art.” Additional proofreading is recommended to identify and correct similar typographical or linguistic inconsistencies throughout the manuscript.

human:
Leeches Eat for Free 
 
... 
 
 Most of us are taught that nothing in this world is free. Everything in life comes at a cost, and life itself can be extremely unaffordable. Dr. Amy K. Glasmeier and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed a projection of the cost of living for every major city in every state of our nation. According to their Living Wage Calculator, in the city of San Luis Obispo the necessary annual income of a childless, single adult that is financially independent is 24,761 dollars. This means that if I wanted to be able to support myself right now, I would have to work a little over fifty hours a week. Of course I would have to drop out of school as well because the cost of tuition in addition to Glasmeier ’ s projection of living expenses would require me to work more hours than there are in a week. This reality is disheartening and troubles me deeply, however I have to acknowledge that there are people in much worse circumstances than me. For example: children suffering from anaemia, women that are experiencing complications during their pregnancy, or victims of severe accidents in trauma. These people have a common need for clean, healthy blood, which luckily for me, is constantly pumping through my readily available veins. Before I present my argument I want to provide you with three definitions from the American Oxford Dictionary. 
 
 Parasitism: Habitual reliance on or exploitation of others 
 ex: tapeworms, fleas, ticks. 
 
 Mutualism: The doctrine that mutual dependence is necessary to social well-being 
 ex: bees and flowers, zebras and oxpeckers, dogs and humans. 
 
 Hero: A person who is admired or idealized for courage, outstanding achievements, or noble qualities 
 ex: firefighter, police officer, blood donor. 
 
 My argument is, as I hope to demonstrate in this paper, not unreasonable nor ill-conceived but rather a logical proposal. Its application would see a more mutualistic society and benefit all parties involved. I am arguing for the financial compensation of blood donors. 
 According to the United Blood Services ’ website, the nonprofit organization has existed for 73 years and was first established as the Salt River Valley Blood Bank in Phoenix, Arizona. Their website also suggests that blood donors are heroes for their generous contributions to saving lives. But hero and free don ’ t necessarily need to go hand in hand. There are plenty of occupations that our society considers heroic that definitely do not work for free. Firefighters, highway patrol, even navy seals; they all save lives and are recognized for their brave and noble actions not only with praise, admiration, and hollywood movie portrayals, but they are also recognized for their time and effort with sizeable salaries and pensions. United Blood Services recognize the time and effort of the heroes whose blood they rely on with a reward system. The description of the reward system appears as follows on their website: “ All who give blood during a calendar year are automatically recognized and rewarded in the Hero in Me Program. The program uses Gold, Silver and Bronze recognition levels to offer benefits to donors who give regularly during a calendar year. The program also offers reward points for specific activities; these reward points can be redeemed for thank-you gifts. ” Curious to know why those that surrender their blood for the greater good of mankind don ’ t deserve more than a thank you, I decided to call United Blood Services and ask a representative. After being passed around to a few different people, I was finally connected to man who calmly told me, “ We depend on the generosity of volunteer donors. Studies show that the safest blood comes from volunteer donors, so the State of California does not allow us to pay donors. ” The line sounded rehearsed so I hung up and Googled it. The first result was a frequently-asked-questions page from the San Diego Blood Bank website. The same line that the representative I spoke with used was provided almost verbatim on the website as an answer to a question regarding payment for blood. I was unable to find, however, any evidence of this claim or any research to back it up on either the San Diego Blood Bank website or the United Blood Services website. This idea that the safest donations come from volunteer donors, seemingly unbacked by any research, intrigued me none the less. I decided to look into programs similar to blood banks. 
 Sperm banks do not subscribe to the same philosophy of the United Blood Services. According to the California Cryobank website, sperm donors are paid up to 125 dollars per donation and are allowed to donate up to three times a week. That means as a sperm donor I could make 1,500 dollars a month. Interestingly enough, their website calls its donors heroes just as the United Blood Services does. With 1,500 extra dollars a month I could work part time, go to college full time and still be able to live comfortably on my own by supplementing my income with the money I receive from the sperm bank. So why aren ’ t sperm banks concerned with the safety of the donations they receive? Why not follow the model of the United Blood Services and rely solely on unpaid donated sperm? I came to the conclusion that to find the answer I would have to compare the requirements of donor eligibility for blood donors and sperm donors. 
 It is surprisingly difficult to become a sperm donor. Upon acceptance of a prospective donor ’ s application, the prospective donor will undergo a four-phase screening process. Phase 1 is concerned with determining the eligibility of the donor. The donor must provide a sample to be lab tested and is required to be able to produce above average levels of sperm as a normal male. The donor will then meet with the Donor Coordinator and provide a brief family history and leave a second sample for testing. Phase 2 involves more extensive screening. Donors will provide weekly samples as well as submit to STD/genetic disease testing. Donors will meet with a genetic counselor to fill out a detailed family history form. Donors will then write a personal narrative and provide a baby photo. Donors will be subjected to various interviews with “ Healthworkers ” and submit to another health examination. Phase 3 requires the donor to enter into a contract with the sperm bank that binds the donor to a 6-12 month period in which they are expected to provide at least one sample a week to the bank and have quarterly blood and urine tests and biannual physical exams. The last phase of the process is a final blood test six months after the donor ’ s last sample collection. Other eligibility requirements for sperm donors include: being between 20 and 39 years old, being at least five feet and seven inches tall, having or pursuing a college degree, and being able to legally work in the United States. All of this information is outlined on the Sperm Bank of California ’ s website. Compared to these stipulations, blood donor requirements are extremely minimal. When I donated blood last year, I was asked to fill out a few forms regarding my health, medications I use, my weight and height, and my recent sexual activity. This process took not but forty-five minutes and one hour later, the United Blood Services had my life essence all bagged up and ready to save lives. It seems to me as if the UBS ’ s argument that unpaid donations are safer isn ’ t very valid. Clearly the rigorous screenings conducted by sperm banks are far more extensive and they can still manage to pay their donors more than a part-time job can. 
 I don ’ t even have to make an appointment with a sperm bank to know that I wouldn ’ t qualify as a donor. This is disappointing because I certainly could use an extra 1,500 dollars a month. However, I know for a fact that I qualify as a blood donor because the United Blood Services has contacted me over the phone nearly every other day since my first donation a year ago to ask if they can take more blood out of me. When I politely refuse, the representatives attempt to sway me by informing me that less than 1 in 10 people donate blood in the United States. But this problem would easily be quelled if blood donors had monetary incentive. And the idea that this notion is a selfish one is ludicrous. Find me one CHP officer willing to abandon his/her 92,640 dollar base salary ( which does not include additional pay incentives or overtime compensation they receive ) simply because the gratification of saving lives should be payment enough. And when “ Donor Recruitment Representatives ” working for United Blood Services are making 41,244 dollars a year on average and “ Donor Outreach Supervisors ” are making 41,510 dollars a year, why aren ’ t the people that actually make their whole system possible being compensated? If I was being paid 125 dollars per blood donation just as sperm donors are, I ’ d be down at the clinic as often as they would allow me and I believe a lot more than 1 in 10 people would follow suit. 
 Mutualism is a far superior system to parasitism. When both parties are benefitting it makes for a more progressive community. It makes sense that people that need money and people that need blood should be able to help each other. If a market for sperm can exist, surely a blood market can as well. The United Blood Services calls its donors heroes. If fleas, ticks, and other blood-suckers could talk, they'd call us heroes too, but when leeches eat for free, who's the real sucker?

For someone like me, that means clocking over fifty hours each week. School would vanish from the picture; between tuition and living costs, I’d need more hours than a week holds. It’s a grim arithmetic, yet I know others face darker equations: children pale with anemia, mothers in peril during childbirth, bodies broken in trauma. They all share a need for what flows freely through my veins—clean, living blood.

Before I go further, let me offer three definitions, borrowed from the dictionary:

*Parasitism*: Habitual reliance on the resources of others.  
Think tapeworms, fleas, ticks.

*Mutualism*: A doctrine that mutual dependence fuels social well-being.  
Think bees and flowers, zebras and oxpeckers, dogs and humans.

*Hero*: One admired for courage, outstanding deeds, or noble qualities.  
Think firefighters, police, blood donors.

What I propose is neither wild nor reckless—it’s a bridge toward mutualism, where everyone gains. I believe we should pay people for their blood.

Consider United Blood Services. For 73 years, this nonprofit has called donors heroes. But must heroism mean working free? We celebrate firefighters, highway patrol, soldiers—they save lives and receive not just medals and movies, but salaries and pensions. United Blood Services does offer a token of thanks: a “Hero in Me” program with reward points and gift tiers. Yet when I called to ask why donors don’t earn real compensation, a calm voice replied, “We depend on volunteer generosity. Studies show volunteer blood is safest, so California law forbids payment.”

The line felt rehearsed. I searched, and there it was—echoed on a blood bank FAQ. But I found no studies, no proof to anchor the claim. It made me wonder: if unpaid blood is so vital, why do sperm banks operate differently?

Sperm donors can earn up to $125 per donation, three times a week—$1,500 a month. They, too, are called heroes. That extra income could let someone work part-time, study full-time, and live independently. Why no fear over safety there? The answer lies in the screening.

Becoming a sperm donor is a gauntlet. Applicants endure a four-phase sieve: health histories, genetic counseling, weekly samples, STD panels, personal essays, baby photos, interviews, and contracts binding them for months. Donors must be college-educated, over five-seven, between 20 and 39. Blood donation, by contrast, asks a few forms, a quick check—within an hour, your essence is bagged and tagged. If sperm banks can vet so fiercely and still pay, why can’t blood banks?

I’d never qualify as a sperm donor. But I’m a prime candidate for blood donation—so much so that United Blood Services calls me relentlessly, reminding me that fewer than one in ten Americans give. Imagine if that changed with a financial nudge. Is it selfish to want compensation? Then ask a highway patrol officer to surrender a $92,640 salary because saving lives should be payment enough. Ask why donor recruiters earn over $41,000 a year, while those who provide the very substance of the system get only points and praise.

If I were paid $125 per donation, like sperm donors, I’d be at the clinic as often as allowed. And I suspect far more than one in ten would join me.

Mutualism beats parasitism. When both sides benefit, the whole community moves forward. People who need money and people who need blood could lift each other up. If a market for sperm can thrive, why not for blood? United Blood Services calls its donors heroes. Fleas and ticks would probably call us heroes too. But when leeches eat for free, who’s the real sucker?

human: The maximal calcium absorption in response to vitamin D has been proposed as a biomarker for vitamin D sufficiency.The objective was to determine whether there is a threshold beyond which increasing doses of vitamin D, or concentrations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D], no longer increase calcium absorption.This was a placebo-controlled, dose-response, randomized, double-blind study of the effect of vitamin D on calcium absorption in healthy postmenopausal women. Seventy-six healthy postmenopausal women were randomly assigned to placebo or 800 IU (20 μg), 2000 IU (50 μg), or 4000 IU (100 μg) vitamin D₃ for 8 wk. The technique of dual isotopes of stable calcium was used with a calcium carrier to measure calcium absorption at baseline and after 8 wk.Seventy-one women with a mean ± SD age of 58.8 ± 4.9 y completed the study. The mean calcium intake was 1142 ± 509 mg/d and serum 25(OH)D was 63 ± 14 nmol/L at baseline. A statistically significant linear trend of an increase in calcium absorption adjusted for age and body mass index with increasing vitamin D₃ dose or serum 25(OH)D concentration was observed. A 6.7% absolute increase in calcium absorption was found in the highest vitamin D₃ group (100 μg). No evidence of nonlinearity was observed in the dose-response curve.
LLM_1: Maximal calcium absorption in response to vitamin D has been suggested as a potential biomarker for vitamin D sufficiency. This study aimed to identify whether a threshold exists beyond which higher doses of vitamin D or elevated serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] concentrations no longer enhance calcium absorption. A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled dose-response trial was conducted in healthy postmenopausal women. Participants (n=76) were randomly allocated to receive placebo or vitamin D₃ at doses of 800 IU (20 μg), 2000 IU (50 μg), or 4000 IU (100 μg) daily for eight weeks. Calcium absorption was assessed at baseline and after the intervention using a dual-isotope stable calcium method with a calcium carrier. Of the initial cohort, 71 women (mean age 58.8 ± 4.9 years) completed the study. Baseline mean calcium intake was 1142 ± 509 mg/day, and mean serum 25(OH)D concentration was 63 ± 14 nmol/L. After adjusting for age and body mass index, a statistically significant linear trend of increased calcium absorption was observed with rising vitamin D₃ doses and corresponding serum 25(OH)D levels. The highest dose group (100 μg) demonstrated an absolute increase in calcium absorption of 6.7%. No evidence of nonlinearity was detected in the dose-response relationship.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

The relationship between maximal calcium absorption and vitamin D sufficiency has been proposed as a potential biomarker for assessing vitamin D levels. This study aimed to determine whether a threshold exists at which additional vitamin D supplementation or increased serum concentrations of 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] ceases to further enhance calcium absorption. A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled dose-response trial was conducted with a cohort of healthy postmenopausal women. A total of 76 participants were randomly assigned to receive either a placebo or vitamin D₃ at daily doses of 800 IU (20 μg), 2000 IU (50 μg), or 4000 IU (100 μg) for a duration of eight weeks. Calcium absorption was evaluated at baseline and at the conclusion of the intervention through a dual-isotope stable calcium method utilizing a calcium carrier. Out of the original group, 71 women (mean age 58.8 ± 4.9 years) successfully completed the study. At baseline, the mean calcium intake was recorded at 1142 ± 509 mg/day, while the mean serum 25(OH)D concentration was 63 ± 14 nmol/L. After controlling for age and body mass index, a statistically significant linear trend was identified, indicating increased calcium absorption correlating with higher doses of vitamin D₃ and associated serum 25(OH)D levels. The group receiving the highest dose (100 μg) exhibited an absolute increase in calcium absorption of 6.7%. No evidence of a nonlinear relationship was found within the dose-response curve.

Yeah… I’m crushed. I don’t even know where to begin.

When I read that email, my heart just stopped. For a moment, the world went quiet. I couldn’t understand *why*. I came home, looked at him, and all I felt was this heavy, suffocating weight—like something inside me had shattered. Completely broken. Disturbed. And then, suddenly, it hit me: something was gone. And that… that terrified me.

The other day, we were out shopping for Lina’s gift when we came across this beautiful crystal—supposedly helps with focus, reduces daydreaming. And today? It all just… dissolved. Like smoke. Like it was never meant to be. And I was left here, reduced to tears.

Worse still, the pain opened old wounds. All those memories I’d buried—the ones I thought I’d moved past—came rushing back. Haunting me. And no matter how hard I try, I can’t seem to let them go.

**Abstract**

This study evaluates the prognostic value of up-shoot in adduction for the functional outcomes of binocular vision in patients with fully refractive accommodative esotropia (RAET). We conducted a retrospective analysis of 58 patients diagnosed with RAET, all of whom were followed for a minimum of four years. Up-shoot in adduction—either with or without a V pattern—was observed without glasses in 22 out of 51 patients who maintained normal binocular alignment throughout the follow-up period. Additionally, it was noted in 3 out of 7 patients who lost normal binocular vision and exhibited manifest esotropia at any time, despite wearing glasses. Among these 25 cases, up-shoot in adduction persisted with glasses in only three patients. Of these, two remained fully compensated with glasses throughout the study, while the third developed up-shoot in adduction following the decompensation of a previously compensated strabismus.

human:
The Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg, who has made mental health a policy priority, talked of a "seismic shift" to end the "injustice" of some young people being left without access to care or treatment.
Now the reality and failings of the system have been laid bare by a taskforce of experts and NHS chiefs in England set up by the government.
Their report begs the question of why Mr Clegg and his coalition colleagues have over the last five years allowed children's mental health provision to get to the state its now in.
The report describes how there are an increasing numbers of referrals, longer waiting times and more complex and severe problems being presented by patients.
It says there is a lack of clear leadership and accountability across different agencies, access to crisis services is variable and "real changes" across the system are required.  Children and young people's mental health services are, says the report, facing "ingrained and systemic" problems.
The report looks at the funding issue and notes that money often sits in different budgets in different organisations without adequate information on how it is spent and who is responsible.  The authors note tactfully that "historically" mental health services have suffered when the public sector is under financial pressure.
Translated, that means this area of the health budget has fallen in real terms and the report says that children and adolescent services funding has been reduced as a proportion of overall spending on mental health services.
The report makes clear that there is a strong economic case for protecting the mental wellbeing of children and teenagers.  A mental health problem can greatly increase the risk of physical ill-health - for example, coronary heart disease in adults.  Early intervention, its argued, can result in significant savings in costs to public services in later years.
The taskforce does give credit to the Government for some recent initiatives in the mental health field.   Improved access to psychological therapies, more beds for young patients in areas with the least provision and extra funding for care of young people with eating disorders are moves which get a positive write-up in the report.
But the group of experts and leading lights in the NHS and at the Department of Health who wrote the report are clear that radical reforms are needed.
The status quo, in their view, is in essence not fit for purpose. The fact that as many as 70% of children and adolescents who experience clinical problems have not had the right counselling or treatment at an early enough age speaks for itself.
Mental health charities have welcomed the report and the response by Health Minister Norman Lamb who has unveiled new measures, including better access to care and more support for parents.
Like Mr Clegg, he is strongly committed to improving mental health services. But that question is still lingering - why has it taken till the final weeks of this Government's term of office for a full action plan to be announced?
LLM_1:
Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg, who has prioritized mental health policy, recently described a “seismic shift” needed to address the “injustice” of inadequate care for young people. Yet a government-appointed taskforce of health experts and NHS leaders in England has now exposed deep and systemic failures in current provision.

The report raises urgent questions about why, over the past five years, Mr. Clegg and coalition partners have allowed children’s mental health services to reach such a critical state. It details rising referral rates, longer waiting times, and increasingly severe cases among young patients. According to the findings, services suffer from unclear leadership, inconsistent crisis care, and “ingrained” structural problems that demand “real changes.”

Funding arrangements are also scrutinized. Money is often split across different budgets and organizations, with poor transparency over spending or accountability. The authors note that mental health services have “historically” been vulnerable during periods of public sector austerity—meaning budgets have effectively been cut, with children’s services receiving a shrinking share of overall mental health spending.

The report underscores the economic argument for investing in young people’s mental wellbeing, linking untreated conditions to higher risks of physical illness, such as coronary heart disease in adulthood. Early intervention, it argues, would yield significant long-term savings for public services.

While acknowledging recent government initiatives—such as improved access to psychological therapies, additional beds in underserved areas, and extra funding for eating disorder care—the taskforce insists that far more radical reform is essential. The current system, they conclude, is “not fit for purpose,” a point underscored by the finding that up to 70% of young people with clinical conditions do not receive timely treatment.

Mental health charities have welcomed both the report and the response from Health Minister Norman Lamb, who has announced new measures including better care access and increased parental support. Like Mr. Clegg, Mr. Lamb expresses strong commitment to improving services. Nevertheless, a pressing question remains: why has a comprehensive action plan only emerged in the final weeks of this government’s term?

human: Cognitive disorders occurring after electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) are regarded as an expression of brain damage, despite computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showing no signs of structural brain damage. Serum neuron-specific enolase (NSE) is a sensitive marker of neuronal damage (i.e., after stroke or cardiac arrest). The objective of this study was to investigate whether ECT leads to a rise in the serum NSE level as an expression of neuronal damage.We investigated seven patients (four women, three men; mean age 6212 years) with major depressive disorder, who were treated with ECT for the first time. ECT was administered every 2 days, three times a week under standard conditions (anaesthesia: thiopental, succinylcholine, 100% oxygen, unilateral ECT, seizure duration more than 20 s). Blood samples were drawn at the following times. For the first ECT: 15 and 1 min before ECT, and 1, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 45, 60, 75, 90, 105, 120 min, and 8, 12, 24 h after ECT. For all subsequent ECT: 1 min before and 4 h after every ECT. Serum NSE was measured by means of enzyme immunoassay (Cobas Core NSE, EIA, Hoffmann-La Roche).On average, each patient underwent ECT 10 times (range 5-20). In the first ECT there was no difference in serum NSE levels before and at all times following ECT. A comparison of serum NSE levels before and after each subsequent bout of ECT revealed no differences. Moreover, comparing the baseline serum NSE levels (before the first ECT) with the values after final ECT showed no differences either.

Serum neuron-specific enolase (NSE) serves as a sensitive biomarker for neuronal damage, such as after stroke or cardiac arrest. This study aimed to determine whether ECT induces an increase in serum NSE levels as an indicator of neuronal injury. We examined seven patients (four women, three men; mean age 62 ± 12 years) with major depressive disorder undergoing first-time ECT. Treatments were administered three times per week, every two days, under standard conditions (anesthesia with thiopental and succinylcholine, 100% oxygen, unilateral electrode placement, seizure duration >20 seconds). Blood sampling for the first ECT occurred at 15 and 1 minute before treatment, and at 1, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 45, 60, 75, 90, 105, 120 minutes, and 8, 12, 24 hours after ECT. For subsequent ECT sessions, samples were taken 1 minute before and 4 hours after each treatment. Serum NSE was measured using an enzyme immunoassay (Cobas Core NSE EIA, Hoffmann-La Roche). Patients received an average of 10 ECT sessions (range 5–20). No significant differences in serum NSE levels were observed before versus after the first ECT at any time point. Similarly, comparisons before and after each subsequent ECT session showed no differences. Baseline NSE levels (prior to the first ECT) also did not differ from those measured after the final ECT session.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

Cognitive impairments following electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) are frequently attributed to neuronal injury, despite the lack of observable structural damage on computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Serum neuron-specific enolase (NSE) is recognized as a sensitive biomarker for neuronal damage, commonly associated with conditions such as stroke or cardiac arrest. This study aimed to investigate whether ECT results in an elevation of serum NSE levels, which may indicate neuronal injury. We assessed seven patients (four women, three men; mean age 62 ± 12 years) diagnosed with major depressive disorder who were undergoing their first ECT treatment. ECT was administered three times per week, every two days, under standardized conditions, including anesthesia with thiopental and succinylcholine, administration of 100% oxygen, unilateral electrode placement, and seizure durations exceeding 20 seconds. Blood samples were collected prior to the initial ECT session at 15 and 1 minute before treatment, as well as at 1, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 45, 60, 75, 90, 105, 120 minutes, and 8, 12, and 24 hours post-ECT. For subsequent ECT sessions, samples were taken 1 minute before and 4 hours after each treatment. Serum NSE levels were quantified using an enzyme immunoassay (Cobas Core NSE EIA, Hoffmann-La Roche). The patients received an average of 10 ECT sessions (range 5–20). No significant differences in serum NSE levels were detected when comparing pre- and post-first ECT measurements at any time point. Similarly, analyses of NSE levels before and after each subsequent ECT session revealed no significant variations. Furthermore, baseline NSE levels measured prior to the first ECT session did not differ from those assessed following the final ECT session.

Dante Michael Soiu, 67, from Ohio, was acquitted of felony stalking and attempted stalking by a jury at Los Angeles Superior Court.
The actress had given evidence in the case, tearfully telling the jury she had feared for her family's safety after receiving multiple letters.
In 2000, Soiu had been sent to a psychiatric facility after a previous stalking case involving the actress.
After being found not guilty in the latest case his lawyer Lynda Westlund  said Soiu "just needed the right medication. He is completely lucid."
"He's unique. He's special. But ... he's very cogent," she said.
Paltrow gave evidence for three hours last week in which she claimed she was sent around 70 messages between 2009 and 2015 by Soiu.
She said the letters ranged from "religious to pornographic to threatening", and some of which some talked of her death.
She also read aloud from some of the letters, in which some expressed Mr Soiu's wish to marry her.
She said he had also sent her a cookbook, jewellery and items of clothing.
But Mr Soiu told the court he only wanted to show love and friendship and how he was not bitter about her testifying against him in the previous stalking case.
Paltrow said she had been scared by the messages "because the communications completely defy logic".
"I've been dealing for 17 years with the communications from this man," she said.
"I felt very upset by it... this has been a very long and very traumatic experience already."
In defence, Ms Westlund said her client was harmless.
She said the actress had misinterpreted his letters, many of which were biblical in nature and were therefore intended to give her a religious, not threatening message.

Paltrow testified for three hours last week, stating she received approximately 70 messages between 2009 and 2015. She described the correspondence as ranging from religious and pornographic to threatening, with some letters referencing her death. During her testimony, she read aloud portions in which Soiu expressed a desire to marry her. She also noted he had sent gifts including a cookbook, jewelry, and clothing.

“I’ve been dealing for 17 years with communications from this man,” Paltrow said. “The communications completely defy logic. This has been a very long and very traumatic experience.”

human: Dietary nitrate supplementation positively affects cardiovascular function at rest and energy metabolism during exercise in humans and has recently also been reported to markedly enhance the in vitro contractile properties of mouse fast-twitch muscle. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of short-term nitrate supplementation on the in vivo contractile properties of the skeletal muscle and voluntary muscle function of humans.In a double-blind, randomized, crossover design, 19 healthy untrained men (21 ± 3 yr) ingested a nitrate-rich concentrated beetroot juice (NIT; nitrate dosage, approximately 9.7 mmol·d) and a placebo (PLA) for seven consecutive days. After the last supplementation dose, force was recorded while participants completed a series of voluntary and involuntary (electrically evoked) unilateral isometric contractions of the knee extensors.NIT enhanced the peak force response to low-frequency electrical stimulation, as follows: maximal twitch (NIT, 149 ± 41 N, vs PLA, 138 ± 37 N; P = 0.008; effect size, r (ES) = 0.56) and submaximal 1- to 20-Hz contractions (5%-10%, ES = 0.53-0.63). Whereas explosive (rising phase) force production during the first 50 ms of evoked maximal twitch and octet contractions (eight electrical impulses at 300 Hz) was also 3%-15% greater after NIT compared with that after PLA (P = 0.023-0.048, ES = 0.52-0.59), explosive voluntary force remained similar (P = 0.510, ES = 0.16). Maximum voluntary force was also unchanged after NIT (P = 0.539, ES = 0.15).

Explosive force production during the initial 50 ms of evoked maximal twitch and octet contractions (eight impulses at 300 Hz) was also 3%–15% greater following NIT compared to PLA (P = 0.023–0.048; effect size range = 0.52–0.59). **Abstract**  
Neurotensin (NTS) and its primary receptor NTSR1 have been implicated in cancer progression; however, their functional role and underlying mechanisms in glioblastoma remain incompletely understood. In this study, we demonstrate that aberrant NTS/NTSR1 signaling promotes glioblastoma cell proliferation through modulation of microRNA expression and cell cycle regulators. Microarray and quantitative real-time PCR analyses identified miR-29b-1 and miR-129-3p as downstream targets regulated by NTS/NTSR1. Luciferase reporter assays and immunoblotting confirmed that these miRNAs directly target cyclin-dependent kinase 6 (CDK6). Chromatin immunoprecipitation assays revealed that the transcription factor c-Myc binds to the promoters of both *miR-29b-1* and *CDK4*, mediating their differential regulation. Pharmacological inhibition or siRNA-mediated knockdown of NTSR1 induced G1-phase cell cycle arrest, accompanied by downregulation of CDK4, CDK6, and c-Myc. Furthermore, NTS/NTSR1 signaling in U87 cells activated c-Myc, leading to increased CDK4 expression and repression of miR-29b-1. In an orthotopic xenograft model, NTSR1 knockdown significantly suppressed tumor growth and prolonged survival in mice—effects that were markedly reversed upon administration of miR-29b-1 antagomirs. These findings reveal a novel NTSR1/c-Myc/miR-29b-1/CDK4/6 regulatory axis in glioblastoma, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic target.

This work proposes a benchmark for clinical sequential decision-making. The simulated environment comprises an underlying dynamics model and a policy model, both of which can be independently specified. The benchmark offers flexibility in the policy classes used to sample synthetic data across two clinical domains (ICU and Ward). The environment is modeled using various deep learning methods trained on real-world data, enabling synthetic data generation under customizable policies. Environment modeling employs diverse approaches, including LSTMs, recurrent counterfactual networks, and latent variable models.

This benchmark—fairly general in scope—could prove highly valuable to the community for proof-of-concept demonstrations of clinical decision support models.  
2. The methodology for designing the environment is clear and reasonable, particularly regarding non-Markovian policies and autoregressive (Markovian) environments. I suggest the authors clarify this distinction in Table 1, unless I overlooked it (i.e., only policies can be non-Markovian, not environment dynamics).  
3. The benchmark’s primary utility appears to be its capacity to evaluate reinforcement learning algorithms and incorporate realistic clinician behavior (e.g., practice variation) into policies.

**Weaknesses:**  
My main concern pertains to how environments are modeled. While I appreciate the need for realistic data, the authors have chosen to model environments using methods such as recurrent neural networks, “counterfactual” recurrent neural networks, and latent variable models like attention-based state-space models and variational autoencoders. This design choice inherently biases the benchmark and its evaluation toward certain methods over others. Specific concerns include:

i) Conceptually, it would be more meaningful to characterize environment variability in terms of statistical properties rather than specific model types. For users, it is more informative to assess whether a policy or method performs well under conditions such as non-stationarity (and its type), heteroskedasticity (and its form), multimodality, or heterogeneity, rather than making general claims about neural network-based environments.  
ii) Model-based reinforcement learning methods cannot be realistically or properly evaluated with such environments. If the environment is modeled with specific parametric forms, methods that match those forms will be less prone to misspecification compared to others. If the benchmark is not intended for model-based evaluation, the authors should state this explicitly in the introduction. I strongly recommend employing complex parametric models that inject noise into real data to create semi-synthetic data generators, rather than deep network-based environments. It is unclear whether such deep networks serve as good proxies for realistic clinical environments. Statistical descriptions of environment choices would help elucidate limitations without introducing methodological bias, thereby enhancing the benchmark’s usability.  
iii) Relying on semi-synthetic data with parametrized *distributions*—rather than deep learning models of the environment—would also mitigate bias in generated samples. If certain populations or disease types are overrepresented in the data, the environment becomes biased in a way that undermines rigorous evaluation.

### **Review**

This work introduces a benchmark environment for clinical sequential decision-making, designed to reflect real-world complexities in training models for clinical decision support. The problem is well motivated, and the authors present a principled approach to constructing a challenging and customizable simulation framework. However, my primary concern lies in the modeling assumptions underlying the environment dynamics, which I believe introduce methodological biases that may limit the generality and fairness of downstream evaluations. These issues, if addressed, could significantly strengthen the contribution.

**Rating:** 5 (Marginally below acceptance threshold)  
**Confidence:** 4 (Confident but not absolutely certain)

---

#### **Summary and Contributions**

The paper proposes a benchmark framework for evaluating sequential decision-making algorithms in two clinical settings: intensive care unit (ICU) and general ward environments. The core innovation lies in the modular design of the simulation environment, which decouples the specification of environment dynamics from behavior policies. Both components can be independently instantiated using various deep learning architectures trained on real-world electronic health record (EHR) data, enabling synthetic data generation under user-defined policies. The framework supports customization along several clinically relevant dimensions, including clinician behavior patterns, Markovianity, practice variation, and policy class diversity. Evaluation is conducted via imitation learning baselines and discriminative performance comparisons between real and synthetic trajectories.

Key modeling approaches include LSTMs, recurrent counterfactual networks, attention-based state-space models, and variational autoencoders—all used to capture complex temporal dependencies in patient physiology and treatment responses.

---

#### **Strengths**

1. **High Practical Relevance**: Evaluating data-driven clinical policies using real patient outcomes poses significant ethical and logistical challenges. A flexible, realistic benchmark of this nature holds substantial value for the community, particularly for proof-of-concept validation of reinforcement learning (RL) and imitation learning methods in safety-critical domains.

2. **Clear Methodological Design**: The separation between environment dynamics and policy models is conceptually sound and enhances interpretability. In particular, the explicit handling of non-Markovian policies within an autoregressive (Markovian) environment structure represents a thoughtful architectural choice. That said, I recommend the authors clarify this distinction explicitly in Table 1—or elsewhere—if it is not already stated, as it is crucial for correct interpretation of the setup.

3. **Modeling Realistic Clinician Behavior**: One of the most promising aspects of the benchmark is its ability to incorporate heterogeneity in clinical practice (i.e., practice variation) into the policy model. This enables more realistic simulations than static or deterministic baselines, thereby improving ecological validity.

---

#### **Weaknesses**

My principal reservations pertain to the way environment dynamics are modeled and how these choices affect the validity and neutrality of the benchmark.

While I appreciate the goal of realism through data-driven modeling, the reliance on specific deep learning architectures—such as recurrent neural networks (including "counterfactual" variants), attention-based latent variable models, and variational autoencoders—to represent environment dynamics raises important concerns:

**i)** *Lack of statistical transparency*: From a scientific evaluation standpoint, it would be more informative to characterize environmental variability in terms of interpretable statistical properties rather than implicit assumptions encoded by particular neural network classes. For instance, users should be able to assess algorithmic robustness with respect to **non-stationarity** (type and degree), **heteroskedasticity**, **multimodality in transition distributions**, or **population-level heterogeneity**, independent of any parametric model family. Currently, such characteristics are entangled with model architecture, making it difficult to isolate sources of difficulty or generalize findings across benchmarks.

**ii)** *Bias against model-based RL methods*: The use of highly expressive, deep-network-based environment models inherently favors methods whose inductive biases align with the generator—especially model-free or amortized inference approaches. Conversely, model-based RL algorithms may suffer from misspecification even when structurally appropriate, simply because they cannot perfectly approximate the complex, opaque generator functions. If the benchmark is not intended for evaluating model-based methods, this limitation should be clearly acknowledged in the introduction. Alternatively, I strongly encourage the authors to consider semi-synthetic data generation strategies based on perturbing real trajectories with controlled, interpretable noise processes governed by parametric distributions. Such an approach would enhance reproducibility, reduce architectural bias, and allow for clearer attribution of performance differences.

**iii)** *Risk of distributional bias amplification*: By training environment models end-to-end on observational data, the framework risks perpetuating and potentially amplifying existing biases related to patient demographics, disease prevalence, or institutional practices. Using parametrized *distributions*—rather than black-box deep learning surrogates—for key transitions would enable better auditing of generated data and facilitate mitigation of such biases. Moreover, providing statistical summaries of the induced environment (e.g., marginal/conditional distribution shifts, autocorrelation decay, intervention frequency) would greatly improve transparency and usability.

In sum, while the current design achieves high fidelity in trajectory generation, it does so at the cost of introducing architectural priors that may compromise the neutrality of the benchmark. Greater emphasis on *statistical specifications* over *model-specific implementations* would enhance both interpretability and fairness in evaluation.

---

#### **Correctness**

1. The limitations outlined above constitute a meaningful constraint on the current benchmark’s scope. Addressing them would substantially improve its scientific utility and broader applicability.

2. Regarding Equation (1) for $Q_{\pi}^{\Omega}$: the notation $q(y \mid \cdot)$ is introduced as part of a verifiable ground-truth structure for customizable data generation. While its role in sampling is clear, the paper would benefit from further elaboration on how this component encodes *interpretable*, *customizable*, and *verifiable* structural relationships (e.g., causal or conditional independence assumptions). Clarifying the connection between $q(y \mid \cdot)$ and domain knowledge—such as known physiological constraints or treatment guidelines—would strengthen confidence in the construct validity of the simulated environment.

---

#### **Clarity**

The manuscript is generally well written, logically structured, and effectively communicates the motivation and design of the benchmark. Minor typographical errors are present but do not impede understanding. A careful proofreading pass is recommended prior to publication.

---

#### **Relation to Prior Work**

The authors adequately situate their work within the landscape of existing clinical benchmarks and simulation frameworks (e.g., MIMIC-based simulators, RLCard, etc.). The comparison highlights the novelty of their modular, policy-agnostic design and strengthens the positioning of the contribution.

---

#### **Documentation**

The codebase is available, and basic documentation—including README files and usage examples—is provided. Reproducibility appears feasible given the information supplied. However, no long-term maintenance plan or versioning strategy is mentioned. Including such details would increase trust in the sustainability of the resource.

---

#### **Ethics**

The paper would benefit from additional clarification regarding data provenance and access protocols. Specifically:
- How was real-world EHR data preprocessed and de-identified?
- Are there restrictions on data sharing or reuse for other researchers?
- What institutional review board (IRB) approvals or ethical consents apply across domains?

Providing concise statements on these points will ensure compliance with ethical standards in clinical AI research.

---

#### **Additional Feedback**

The authors have developed a timely and potentially impactful resource for the clinical ML community. With revisions addressing the concerns raised—particularly around **environment modeling transparency**, **evaluation neutrality**, and **statistical interpretability**—this work could serve as a gold-standard benchmark.

If the authors can provide a detailed response to the weaknesses highlighted above—possibly including ablation studies or alternative environment specifications—I would be willing to reconsider my rating favorably.

human: Beta-site alpha-amyloid protein cleaving enzyme1 (BACE1) plays a key role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. Additional to its moderate expression in the brain, high levels of BACE1 mRNA were found in the pancreas. Murine Bace1 has been immunohistochemicaly detected at the apical pole of acinar cells within the exocrine pancreas of mice and Bace1 activity was observed in pancreatic juice. In vitro experiments revealed enteropeptidase as a putative substrate for Bace1 suggesting a role in acute pancreatitis.The aim of this study was to address a protective mechanism of Bace1 in acute experimental pancreatitis in mice.Acute experimental pancreatitis was induced by intraperitoneal injection of caerulein in homozygote Bace1-/- mice and wild type mice. Serum and tissue analyses were carried out after 4 h, 8 h and 24 h. Measurement of plasma amylase and lipase was performed to confirm pancreatitis induction. In order to assess the severity of pancreatitis H&E stained pancreatic sections were examined regarding edema, inflammation and apoptosis. Immunohistochemical detection of myeloperoxidase (MPO) positive cells was carried out to further quantify the extent of inflammation. Expression of Bace2 within the pancreas was analyzed by immunohistochemistry and RT-qPCR.We demonstrate that total loss of Bace1 in mice leads to no alterations in the course of acute experimental caerulein-pancreatitis. Bace1-/- mice develop a moderate pancreatitis that is comparable in histomorphological and serological features with those seen in wild type mice.

Pancreatitis induction was confirmed by elevated plasma amylase and lipase. Histopathological evaluation of H&E-stained pancreatic sections assessed edema, inflammation, and apoptosis severity. LLM_2:
**Abstract**

Beta-site amyloid precursor protein cleaving enzyme 1 (BACE1) is a key protease implicated in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease. Although predominantly studied in the central nervous system, BACE1 is also expressed at significant levels in peripheral tissues, including the pancreas, where it localizes to the apical domain of exocrine acinar cells and is detectable in pancreatic secretions. In vitro evidence suggests that BACE1 may process enteropeptidase, a trypsinogen activator, implicating potential involvement in pancreatic function and acute pancreatitis. This study aimed to evaluate the role of BACE1 in the development and progression of experimental acute pancreatitis using *Bace1*-deficient (*Bace1*⁻/⁻) mice. Acute pancreatitis was induced by supramaximal stimulation with caerulein, and disease severity was assessed through serological markers (amylase and lipase), histopathological analysis of pancreatic tissue (evaluating edema, inflammatory infiltration, and apoptosis), and quantification of myeloperoxidase (MPO)-positive neutrophils. Additionally, compensatory expression of BACE2 was examined via immunohistochemistry and RT-qPCR. Biochemical and histological analyses revealed no significant differences in the severity of pancreatitis between *Bace1*⁻/⁻ and wild-type mice at 4, 8, or 24 hours post-induction. Pancreatic injury, inflammatory response, and enzyme elevation were comparable across genotypes. Furthermore, no alterations in BACE2 expression were observed. These findings indicate that BACE1 deficiency does not exacerbate or attenuate caerulein-induced acute pancreatitis in mice, suggesting that BACE1 is not essential for the pathophysiological course of this condition under the experimental conditions tested.

Captain Quentin Langley limped through the fields of dead for that was what it was; the bodies of both sides littering the ground in tangled heaps and mound, enemy and ally draped over one another to carpet the blood soaked ground. Here and there a crippled tank or fallen battlemech lay like iron irons in the sea of death, the trunkless legs of a once powerful *Berserker* standing like the stone limbs in that ancient Terran poem. 
 
 *My name is Ozymandias, king of kings: * 
 *Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair! `` * 
 
 Indeed, nothing beside remained, save for the smoking remnants of ruined machines and the squawking carrion birds feasting on the dead. How quickly is life extinguished, how many hopes and dreams and fears snuffed out in a single afternoon. Too many. 
 
 Langley's feet guided him through the dead, his eyes washing over those of his comrades and once foes never to open again. Some appeared to have died peaceful with almost beatific expressions, their skin alabaster pale. Others died in pain and terror, their dull eyes wide in shock and dread of the unknown. Soldiers with too many seasons fell next with those with too few, the weak perishing with the strong. Soaked as they were in their commingled blood it was difficult to tell who belong to which side. 
 
 It reminded him of a story he once read, of a poor man who tried to bargain with Death, pleading for more time, that it was unfair. Death, of course, refused, kindly explaining to the man that it was not his place to decide who lived and who died. But he told the man that he was the fairest being of all, choosing no sides, and treating all whose time had come equally. 
 
 *Who was the fool, who the wise man, * 
 *who the beggar or the emperor? * 
 *Whether rich or poor, all are equal in death. * 
 
 It was then he saw it, the goal of his search. Standing like a sentinel o'er the dead, itself lifeless and cold. Its black armor was scorched and pitted, dissolved in places by fire and ion wash. Its mighty metal fists were shattered and crushed, evidence of having been used. The missile launcher mounted on its left shoulder was stained with soot and ash, the PPC bent and broken in its right arm. The glass of the cockpit was shattered, the frame twisted and warped. 
 
 In the pilot chair was a man, the lens of his helmet raised to reveal his face, the oxygen mask hanging by a strap. Three days worth of beard covered his face, his icy blue eyes staring out in frank astonishment. A ring of enemy dead encircled him, a full dozen battlemechs toppled over into the muddy ground like the stones of some long forgotten pagan grove with his machine in the center. The numerous wounds that covered his body had not been life threatening, bits of glass and broken shrapnel piercing his chest and limbs and face. He had died from neural feedback, from the intense barrage of signals received through his neurohelmet, every single nerve cell in his brain peaking in one massive spike of stimulation. The damage suffered by his machine, coupled with shock had fried his brain, the switch inside his head flicking off. 
 
 Langley sighed and climbed over the dead to near the broken machine and its pilot. The expected grief only registering as a dull ache. From his pocket he took a pen and paper, scrawling in his script a message. Clicking his pen off he climbed the metal giant up to the cockpit, the stench of iron rich blood and charred flesh strong. He opened the dead pilot's pocket and was about to place the slip of paper inside before something stopped him, some strange feeling washing upon him. He unfolded the paper, reading the hastily written lines to no one save himself and the angels. 
 
 *'' Here is the body of Colonel Tycho Novak, commanding officer of the Grave Guards mercenary regiment. * 
 
 *He died with his boots on. `` *
LLM_1:
Captain Quentin Langley picked his way across the killing field—for that was what it had become. The dead lay tangled in heaps, friend and foe draped together over earth dark with old blood. Here and there, a crippled tank or fallen BattleMech lay like iron tombs amid the carnage; the legless husk of a *Berserker* stood like those stone limbs in an ancient Terran verse.

*My name is Ozymandias, king of kings:*  
*Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!*

Nothing else remained. Only the smoldering wreckage of machines, and the ragged cries of carrion birds feasting. How swiftly life could be extinguished—how many hopes, dreams, terrors, erased in one afternoon. Too many.

Langley’s feet carried him on, his gaze drifting over comrades and enemies whose eyes would never open again. Some wore expressions of eerie peace, skin like alabaster. Others lay frozen in pain or shock, mouths agape at whatever waited beyond. Veterans of countless seasons lay beside boys who’d seen too few; the strong and the weak alike steeped in mingled blood, until it was impossible to tell which side was which.

It called to mind an old tale—a beggar who tried to bargain with Death, pleading that it wasn’t fair. Death refused, of course, but gently explained: it was not his to choose who lived or died. Yet he was the fairest of all, he said. He took no sides. When the hour came, every soul was met the same.

*Who was the fool, who the wise man,*  
*who the beggar or the emperor?*  
*Whether rich or poor, all are equal in death.*

Then Langley saw it—the thing he’d come to find. It stood like a sentinel over the fallen, itself now lifeless, cold. Its black armor was scorched and pitted, eaten away in places by fire and ion wash. The massive fists were shattered, evidence of brutal use. A missile rack, ash-stained, hung limp on one shoulder; the PPC on its right arm bent and broken. The cockpit canopy had burst inward, the frame twisted like a grim sculpture.

Inside sat the pilot, his helmet visor raised, oxygen mask dangling. Three days’ beard covered his face. Icy blue eyes stared out, wide with what looked like frank astonishment. Around his ’Mech lay a ring of enemy dead—a full dozen war machines toppled into the mud like stones from some forgotten pagan circle, his own at the center. The wounds that covered him weren’t what killed him—just fragments of glass and shrapnel studding his chest, limbs, face. He’d died from neural feedback, his brain scorched by the storm of signals through his neurohelmet, every neuron firing once in a final, fatal surge. The machine’s agony had become his own. A switch, flipped off.

Langley sighed and climbed over the dead toward the broken giant and its rider. The grief he expected arrived only as a dull, deep ache. From his pocket he took pen and paper, scrawling a few lines in his tight script. Pen clipped shut, he hauled himself up the metal carcass toward the cockpit—the air thick with the stench of blood and charred flesh. He opened the dead pilot’s pocket, about to tuck the note inside, when something gave him pause. A strange stillness washed over him. He unfolded the paper and read the hasty words aloud, to no one but himself and whatever angels lingered here.

*Here lies the body of Colonel Tycho Novak, commanding officer of the Grave Guards mercenary regiment.*

*He died with his boots on.*

Inside, the pilot remained, helmet visor lifted, oxygen mask hanging uselessly. A scruffy beard, untouched by time, adorned his face. His icy blue eyes stared outward, wide with an expression that seemed to blend astonishment and defeat. Encircling his ’Mech lay a grim tableau of enemy casualties—dozens of war machines toppled into the mud like stones cast aside from an ancient sacrificial site, his own machine at the center. The injuries that marred his body were not the cause of his demise; they were mere remnants of battle—shards of glass and metal embedded in his chest, limbs, and face. He had succumbed to neural feedback, his mind scorched by a cacophony of signals pulsing through his neurohelmet, every neuron firing in a final, cataclysmic surge. The agony of the machine had become his own—an abrupt termination, a switch flicked into darkness.

With a heavy sigh, Langley clambered over the bodies toward the broken colossus and its fallen pilot. The sorrow he anticipated manifested only as a dull, lingering ache. From his pocket, he withdrew pen and paper, inscribing a few brief lines in his meticulous script. With the pen secured, he ascended the metallic carcass toward the cockpit, the air thick with the stench of blood and charred remains. As he prepared to place the note in the dead pilot’s pocket, a sudden stillness enveloped him, halting his hand. He unfolded the paper and read the hastily written lines aloud, his voice echoing in the silence, directed at no one but himself and the lingering spirits that might dwell in this place.

*Here lies the body of Colonel Tycho Novak, commanding officer of the Grave Guards mercenary regiment.*

*He died with his boots on.*

human:
Chris Smart said there was a feeling UKIP was "almost unravelling" following rows about Wales leader Nathan Gill "double jobbing", and the leadership election to succeed Nigel Farage.
Mr Smart was speaking before Mr Gill revealed he was leaving UKIP's assembly group to sit as an independent.
Candidates will push their cases at a hustings event in Newport on Wednesday.
But one leading contender - South East England MEP Diane James - will not be taking part in the event.
UKIP members in Wales were due to vote on whether Mr Gill should be allowed to continue to serve as both an MEP and an AM.
Mr Smart, who believes Mr Gill should resign from one of the roles, said: "The infighting's not doing anyone any good at all.
"I saw some of our members who are really upset about what's going on because they joined UKIP to get out of the EU.
"Of course that's happened, and now things seem to be almost unravelling.
"Some are putting it down to Nathan Gill not doing what he pledged to do before the election.
"Many people may unfortunately leave the party - which would be a great pity - and go back to their former roots, maybe, in many cases the Conservative party, but in some cases Labour as well."
Mr Smart said he hoped the situation "can be put right" once UKIP's new leader is elected.
Mr Gill previously defended his ability to do both jobs and said he would consider court action if he was expelled from the party.
Meanwhile, four of the five contenders to succeed Nigel Farage will put their cases to party members in Newport on Wednesday.
Cambridgeshire councillor Lisa Duffy, West Midlands MEP Bill Etheridge, national executive committee member Elizabeth Jones, and former Conservative councillor Philip Broughton are due to attend the event.
Diane James is not taking part in the hustings, but will be in Newport for a "meet Diane" event a week on Friday.
"My stance is to give UKIP members the opportunity to focus on me, the candidate, grill me on issues that matter to them and thus examine my leadership qualities," she wrote on her website.â€‹
Ballot papers will be sent to members on 1 September, with the result announced a fortnight later.
LLM_1:
Chris Smart expressed concerns that UKIP appeared to be "almost unravelling" amid internal disputes over Welsh leader Nathan Gill’s dual roles as both an MEP and an AM, alongside the ongoing leadership contest to replace Nigel Farage. His comments came shortly before Mr. Gill announced he would leave UKIP’s assembly group to sit as an independent.

Candidates vying for the leadership are set to make their cases at a hustings event in Newport on Wednesday, although one frontrunner—South East England MEP Diane James—will not participate.

UKIP members in Wales were expected to vote on whether Mr. Gill should continue holding both elected positions. Mr. Smart, who believes Mr. Gill should step down from one role, stated: "The infighting’s not doing anyone any good. I’ve spoken with members deeply upset by the situation—many joined UKIP to leave the EU, and now the party seems to be coming apart." He attributed some of the tension to Mr. Gill not fulfilling pre-election pledges and warned that disillusioned members might depart, potentially returning to the Conservatives or Labour.

Mr. Smart added that he hopes the election of a new leader will help resolve the party’s troubles.

Mr. Gill has previously defended his capacity to serve in both roles and indicated he might pursue legal action if expelled from UKIP.

Meanwhile, four of the five leadership candidates—Cambridgeshire councillor Lisa Duffy, West Midlands MEP Bill Etheridge, NEC member Elizabeth Jones, and former Conservative councillor Philip Broughton—will address members at the Newport hustings. Diane James, though absent from that event, will hold a separate "meet Diane" gathering in Newport the following Friday. On her website, she explained her approach: "I want to give members the chance to focus on me as a candidate, question me on key issues, and assess my leadership qualities."

Ballot papers will be distributed to members on 1 September, with the result announced two weeks later.
