human:
God let out a long breath. The assembled angels shifted nervously, standing around the table. 
 
 God put the report down. `` Okay,'' he said. `` I have some questions.'' 
 
 Gabriel, the senior engineer, was shoved forward not very gently by the rest. He tried smiling. `` Yes, O Lord?'' 
 
 God looked Gabriel in the eyes. Full of majesty, the Lord of Hosts, the All-Knowing, he tapped the report and said `` Why are their brains so fucking big?'' 
 
 `` Ha, well, actually, that was my idea, O Lord,'' Gabriel said. `` You see, they're pretty helpless physically. Instead of natural defenses, I thought we could try letting them figure out their own niche.'' 
 
 `` Figure out their own niche,'' God said, in a flat tone. Gabriel nodded and remembered to smile again. Lucifer was a PR wonk and therefore useless to engineers but he promised God responded well to smiling. 
 
 `` I thought they were designed as prey animals, but their reproduction rate is garbage.'' 
 
 `` Yes, O Lord.'' 
 
 `` And their time to maturity is ridiculous.'' 
 
 `` Yes, O Lord.'' 
 
 `` They're going to get wiped out the moment one of our predator species figures out they ca n't run or bite.'' 
 
 ``... nnnmaybe, O Lord.'' 
 
 God raised an eyebrow and made a come-hither gesture, inviting Gabriel to explain himself. 
 
 `` Well, it's just... they're smart. And they can communicate with each other. So I thought if we could start them out some place safe, maybe give them a couple of years to get their feet under them in Eden, they'd surprise us.'' 
 
 `` Surprise us,'' God said in that same flat tone. He had a skeptical look. Gabriel was n't sure if that was good or bad. He kept smiling. 
 
 `` Yes, O Lord. They're smart, but they're also governed by stochastic processes. They're random. We tried some simulations and if we dropped, say, a tiger in a room with them some would run, some would play dead, some would fight. Randomly! Truly randomly.'' 
 
 `` Randomly.'' God was, Gabriel noticed, getting a lot more terse. He glanced back at Lucifer, who nodded and gestured him forward. Gabriel swallowed. 
 
 `` I was thinking of it like a research project,'' he said. `` We have pretty simple processes for every other creature. Eat, mate, stay in their niche. But humans might come up with entirely new niches! Because they're so unpredictable.'' 
 
 God grunted and sat back. `` So why not make them bigger, stronger, tougher?'' 
 
 `` Two reasons, O Lord. First, we do n't want them running amok over the whole planet. Weaknesses to predators and weather mean they wo n't be able to climb up the food chain from an omnivorous scavenger prey species.'' 
 
 God grunted. Gabriel started to think that was a good sign. `` And second,'' he said, `` the more weaknesses they have the more chances their brains have to come up with an unplanned solution.'' 
 
 God grunted a third time. Gabriel glanced back again. Lucifer gave him a thumbs-up. 
 
 `` Okay,'' God said. Gabriel grinned honestly. His first project would be approved! He'd run so many simulations and had so much more proof he could offer, but Lucifer said God just wanted a summary. Gabriel owed him. 
 
 `` But I want to increase their injury tolerance,'' God said. Gabriel's grin froze. That was not something he'd simulated. 
 
 `` Yeah,'' God said, warming to his own idea and picking up the report again. `` They'll learn better if they survive simple damage. Let's just bump their scarring factor up, and maybe if they survive past 40 we let them live to 100. Then they can teach the young the niche survival skills they learned.'' God looked up from the report. `` Sound good?'' 
 
 `` Of course, O Lord,'' Lucifer said, stepping up beside a gaping Gabriel and drawing him back into the crowd. `` Excellent decision as always. Thank you.'' He tugged Gabriel toward the exit and the other angels followed them. 
 
 Once they were in the hallway, Gabriel shook off Lucifer's hand. `` What the *fuck*,'' he said. Lucifer held his hands up. 
 
 `` He gets like that,'' Lucifer said. `` Wants to put his stamp on everything. The Image of God. He's got an ego.'' 
 
 `` He's God,'' Gabriel said defensively. `` But that's not the point. Scarring? Tripling their lifespan? Do you have any idea what that will do? Their advantages were carefully balanced against their weaknesses!'' 
 
 `` No, I do n't know what it will do,'' Lucifer said. `` Do you?'' 
 
 Gabriel glowered at him in response. Lucifer laughed and showed off his stupid perfect teeth. 
 
 `` You wanted an experiment. Unpredictable, something to generate new research. Well, here you go.'' Lucifer clapped him on the shoulder and walked off. `` Let me know how phase one goes!''
LLM_1:
God exhaled slowly, a sound that seemed to stretch across eternity. The angels gathered around the great table fidgeted, wings rustling with unease.

Setting the report down, God leaned forward. “Alright,” He said. “I have a few questions.”

Gabriel, the lead engineer, was nudged—not too gently—to the front by the others. He offered a tentative smile. “Yes, my Lord?”

The All-Knowing, the Lord of Hosts, fixed Gabriel with a gaze full of celestial weight. Tapping the document, He asked, “Why in creation are their brains so damn large?”

“Ah—well, that was my proposal, O Lord,” Gabriel began. “You see, physically, they’re quite vulnerable. Lacking natural defenses, I thought we might allow them to… invent their own place in the world.”

“Invent their own place,” God repeated, His voice devoid of inflection. Gabriel nodded, forcing another smile. Lucifer, the PR specialist, was mostly useless to engineers, but he’d insisted God appreciated a cheerful demeanor.

“I understood they were designed as prey,” God continued. “But their reproduction rate is abysmal.”

“Yes, O Lord.”

“And they take forever to mature.”

“Yes, O Lord.”

“The first predator that realizes they can’t outrun or outfight anything will wipe them out.”

“…Possibly, O Lord.”

God raised an eyebrow, gesturing for Gabriel to elaborate.

“It’s just—they’re clever. And they communicate. So I imagined if we placed them somewhere sheltered, gave them a few years in Eden to find their footing… they might surprise us.”

“Surprise us,” God echoed, skepticism etching His features. Gabriel couldn’t tell if that was promising or perilous. He kept smiling.

“Exactly, O Lord. They’re intelligent, but also driven by randomness. We ran simulations—drop a tiger among them, and some flee, some play dead, some attack. Completely stochastic! Genuine unpredictability.”

“Stochastic.” God’s replies were growing shorter. Gabriel glanced back at Lucifer, who nodded encouragingly. Gabriel swallowed.

“Think of it as a research endeavor,” he ventured. “Every other creature follows simple patterns: eat, mate, stay in lane. But humans… they might carve out entirely new lanes. Because they’re chaotic.”

God grunted, leaning back in His seat. “Why not make them larger, then? Stronger? More resilient?”

“Two reasons, O Lord. First, we don’t want them overrunning the planet. Vulnerabilities to predators and climate will keep them from climbing the food chain too quickly—they’ll remain omnivorous scavengers, prey at heart.”

Another grunt. Gabriel dared to hope. “And second,” he added, “the more frailties they have, the more opportunities for their minds to devise… unforeseen workarounds.”

A third grunt. Gabriel peeked backward; Lucifer flashed a thumbs-up.

“Alright,” God said. Gabriel’s face lit with genuine relief. His first project was getting approved! He had simulations upon simulations, reams of data—but Lucifer had advised keeping it succinct. He owed him one.

“But I want to increase their injury tolerance,” God declared. Gabriel’s smile stiffened. That… hadn’t been in the models.

“Yes,” God mused, warming to the idea as He lifted the report again. “They’ll learn more if they survive minor damage. Let’s heighten their scarring capacity—and if they make it past forty, we’ll extend their span to a hundred. Then they can pass down whatever niche-survival tricks they’ve picked up.” God looked up. “Sound acceptable?”

“Absolutely, O Lord,” Lucifer said smoothly, stepping past a stunned Gabriel and drawing him back into the angelic cluster. “A brilliant adjustment, as always. Thank you.” He guided Gabriel toward the exit, the other angels trailing behind.

Once in the hallway, Gabriel shook off Lucifer’s hand. “What in heaven’s name was that?” he hissed. Lucifer raised his palms innocently.

“He likes to leave His mark,” Lucifer explained. “The whole ‘Image of God’ thing. Ego, you know.”

“He’s God,” Gabriel retorted. “But that’s not the point! Scarring? Tripling their lifespan? Do you realize how that throws off the entire balance? Their strengths and weaknesses were calibrated!”

“No, I don’t realize,” Lucifer replied lightly. “Do you?”

Gabriel shot him a searing glare. Lucifer only laughed, his smile dazzling and infuriating.

“You wanted an experiment. Unpredictable, ripe for new research. Well—now you’ve got it.” Lucifer clapped Gabriel’s shoulder and turned to leave. “Keep me updated on phase one!”
LLM_2:
God exhaled—a breath like the slow parting of galaxies, a sigh that curled through the fabric of time and left silence trembling in its wake. Around the obsidian table, where light bent but did not dare speak, the angels shifted. Feathers whispered against one another, not in prayer, but in nervous anticipation. Wings tucked and unfolded like secrets too heavy to hold.

He set the report down with deliberate calm, as though placing a stone on a scale already unbalanced. “Alright,” said the One Who Spoke Light Into Being, His voice neither loud nor soft, but absolute—like gravity. “I have questions.”

Gabriel stepped forward, gently shoved by unseen hands from behind. The others had drawn straws in silence; he’d lost. Again. He offered a smile—careful, rehearsed, just shy of insolence. “Yes, my Lord?”

The Creator fixed him with a gaze older than stars. Not angry. Not kind. Simply *present*, as if all dimensions were focused through a single point upon his brow. One finger tapped the paper. “Why,” He asked, “are their brains so large? So grotesquely oversized for their bodies? It’s inefficient. It borders on absurd.”

Gabriel swallowed. “It was intentional, O Architect of All Things. You designed them fragile—no claws, no venom, no thick hide. They can’t outrun wolves or crush bone with their jaws. So I thought… perhaps they could *think* their way into survival. Invent tools. Build fire. Speak stories into being.”

“Invent their own place,” God repeated. The words hung, cold and smooth as river stones. Gabriel nodded, holding the smile like a shield.

“And yet,” the Voice continued, “they breed slower than tortoises. Mature at a glacial pace. And when danger comes—and it will—they’ll die like insects beneath a boot.”

“Perhaps,” Gabriel conceded. “But not always. Because they *talk*. They remember. One teaches another, who teaches ten more. We ran models: scatter them across terrain, introduce threat—some run, some fight, some freeze, some do something no algorithm predicted. There’s… noise in the signal. Real chaos.”

“Chaos,” God mused. A flicker passed over His face—curiosity, maybe, or distaste. Hard to tell.

“They don’t follow rules,” Gabriel pressed. “They break them. Even their own. Drop a lion among them, and one might throw a rock, another sing to it, another try to ride it. We called it ‘stochastic behavior’ in the notes—but really, it’s creativity. Or madness. Or both.”

God leaned back, fingers steepled. The air shimmered slightly around Him, as if reality itself hesitated. “Then why not make them stronger? Larger? Give them fangs. Make them *fearless*.”

“Two reasons,” Gabriel said quickly. “First—control. If they dominate too fast, they’ll consume everything. We want them balanced—omnivores, scavengers, prey. Let predators thin them. Let winter starve them. Keep them humble.”

A grunt. Encouraging, perhaps.

“Second,” Gabriel went on, emboldened, “their weakness is the spark. The more they lack, the more they must imagine. Hunger drives invention. Fear breeds fire. Loneliness births language. Their fragility… is the engine.”

Silence stretched. Then—another grunt. Behind him, Lucifer gave a tiny nod, eyes gleaming like polished silver.

God stood, slowly, and lifted the report again. “Then let them scar,” He said.

Gabriel blinked. “Scarring, O Lord?”

“Yes. Deep tissue memory. Let wounds leave marks—not just on skin, but in mind. Let pain teach. And if they survive past forty years—double their span. Extend it to a hundred. Long enough to gather wisdom. Long enough to pass it on.”

Gabriel’s breath caught. That wasn’t in the simulations. That changed *everything*.

But before he could speak, Lucifer stepped smoothly past him, radiant as dawn after storm. “A masterstroke,” he said, voice honeyed with reverence. “Of course. Resilience through endurance. Knowledge through suffering. Truly, only You could see what we missed.” He placed a hand on Gabriel’s shoulder and guided him backward, away from the table, the throne, the truth.

As the doors sealed behind them, Gabriel wrenched free. “What was *that*?” he hissed, low and furious. “Tripling lifespans? Scarring? That destabilizes the entire model! Their evolution, their culture, their psychology—none of it accounts for *centuries* of memory!”

Lucifer turned, smiling—an angel carved from sunlight and secrets. “Oh, come now,” he said, brushing dust from his sleeve. “You wanted unpredictable? You begged for novelty, for research, for something *new under the sun*. Well, look what you’ve gotten.”

He paused at the archway, half in shadow, half in light.

“He didn’t ruin your experiment, Gabriel. He *enhanced* it.” His grin widened, sharp and bright. “Now it’s not just survival. Now it’s *meaning*.”

And with that, he vanished down the corridor, laughter trailing behind him like smoke.

Gabriel stood alone in the hall, staring at the closed door, the weight of what had been unleashed settling over him like falling ash.

Somewhere, in a garden not yet planted, a creature stirred—small, soft, defenseless, and blinking up at a sky it did not yet know how to name.

You trying to get me in trouble so I steal off on you and have to pay you like $250,000 and shit." He then allegedly charged at Ramos, seizing both the photographer and his camera. The incident, recorded by TMZ, lasted several seconds until a woman's voice was heard urging West to stop. West subsequently released Ramos and his camera before driving away. LLM_2:
---

On July 19, 2013, Kanye West was leaving Los Angeles International Airport when he became involved in a physical altercation with paparazzi. The confrontation arose after photographer Daniel Ramos repeatedly addressed West, prompting the rapper to respond, "I told you don't talk to me, right? You trying to get me in trouble so I steal off on you and have to pay you like $250,000 and shit." West then allegedly lunged at Ramos, grabbing both the photographer and his camera. The incident, captured on video by TMZ, lasted several seconds before a woman’s voice was heard urging West to stop. He subsequently released Ramos and departed in a vehicle. Emergency medical personnel were later called to the scene to attend to Ramos.

West initially faced potential felony charges of attempted robbery, but prosecutors ultimately filed misdemeanor charges of criminal battery and attempted grand theft. In March 2014, he pleaded no contest to one count of misdemeanor battery. As part of his sentence, West was placed on two years' probation, ordered to complete 24 anger management sessions, perform 250 hours of community service, and pay restitution to Ramos.

LLM_1:
Lately, it feels like I’ve been filling my time with anything but what’s useful.  
Exhibit A: I was over at Kelli’s place—not to teach, but to paint. And I’m famously terrible at painting. We didn’t even spend half the time actually painting.  
Exhibit B: Fencing… I didn’t even touch my blade.  
Exhibit C: Teaching Tim piano sounds productive, right? Not when we spent the whole session watching *Gundam Wing: Endless Waltz* (starting to resent that show, honestly).  

To top it all off, my parents are still insisting I “attend” Kumon. Truth is, I show up maybe one out of five times—the rest of the time, I take a long walk to the park and read or write lyrics instead.  

Anyway, I just got back from fencing, and I’m pretty sure every muscle, fiber, and bone in my body is about to give out. Fourteen laps in fourteen minutes? I barely managed twelve. Then an hour of nothing but footwork—pure insanity.  

And yet, with all that exhaustion, has my mind cleared up? Not a chance. Three things are still stuck in my head:  
#1 and #2… very few people know about these, and you won’t find out here.  
#3 My parents. We were actually getting along for once, and then what happened? I got smacked over the head with a textbook. Lovely, right? Oh well—hopefully things cool down again soon.  

*Space may be the final frontier, but it’s made in a Hollywood basement.*  
—Red Hot Chili Peppers, “Californication”  

WRONG. Space is *not* the final frontier.  
—Mike
LLM_2:
---

Lately, it feels like I’ve been filling my days with anything but what’s truly useful. 

**Exhibit A:** I found myself at Kelli’s place—not to teach, but to paint. And let me tell you, I’m notoriously bad at painting. Surprisingly, we didn’t even spend half our time actually putting brush to canvas.

**Exhibit B:** Fencing? Yeah, I didn’t even touch my blade.

**Exhibit C:** Teaching Tim piano sounds productive, right? Not when we ended up spending the entire session binge-watching *Gundam Wing: Endless Waltz*—I’m starting to resent that show, honestly.

To top it all off, my parents are still insisting that I “attend” Kumon. Truth be told, I show up maybe one out of five times. The rest of the time, I take a long stroll to the park and lose myself in a book or scribble down some lyrics instead.

Anyway, I just got back from fencing, and I’m pretty sure every muscle, fiber, and bone in my body is about to give out. Fourteen laps in fourteen minutes? I barely managed to scrape by with twelve. Then it was an hour dedicated solely to footwork—absolute madness!

And yet, with all this exhaustion, has my mind cleared up? Not a chance. Three things are still swirling around in my head:  
**#1 and #2:** Very few people know about these, and I’m not spilling the beans here.  
**#3:** My parents. For once, we were actually getting along, and then what happens? I got smacked over the head with a textbook. Lovely, right? Oh well—let’s hope things cool down soon.

*“Space may be the final frontier, but it’s made in a Hollywood basement.”*  
—Red Hot Chili Peppers, “Californication”

WRONG. Space is *not* the final frontier.  
—Mike

The core methodology integrates meta-learning with Q-learning, while ensuring safety via a mixed-integer linear programming formulation for action selection. Experimental validation on real-world deep brain stimulation datasets demonstrates that the proposed approach outperforms existing baselines by a substantial margin in both accuracy and computational efficiency.

**Disadvantages:**  
- From a machine learning perspective, the technical contribution is largely a combination of established techniques (meta-learning, Q-learning, and mixed-integer programming), limiting its novelty.  
- The work is oriented toward a specific robotics/control application, which may fall outside the primary scope of the ICLR conference, where methodological innovation and general machine learning advances are typically emphasized.

**Paper Summary:**  
This paper proposes a meta active learning framework designed to infer the hidden dynamics of control systems under safety constraints. The approach combines meta-learning with Q-learning within a reinforcement learning paradigm, while enforcing safety through a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) formulation during action selection. The method is evaluated on real-world deep brain stimulation datasets, demonstrating superior performance compared to existing baselines in terms of both prediction accuracy and computational efficiency.

**Strengths:**  
- The work addresses a timely and challenging problem—active learning with formal safety guarantees—which has significant implications for high-stakes applications in healthcare, robotics, and autonomous systems.  
- The empirical evaluation is thorough and compelling, showing consistent improvements in dynamics recovery and decision-making performance across multiple experimental settings. The results on real clinical data further underscore the practical relevance of the proposed method.

**Weaknesses:**  
- From a methodological standpoint, the technical contribution primarily involves the integration of established techniques—meta-learning, model-based reinforcement learning (specifically Q-learning), and constrained optimization via MILP—rather than introducing novel algorithmic or theoretical advances. As such, the degree of innovation may be considered incremental from a core machine learning perspective.  
- The focus on a specialized application domain—namely, closed-loop neuromodulation in deep brain stimulation—while impactful, may limit the perceived generality of the approach. Given ICLR’s emphasis on broad advances in representation learning and scalable inference, the application-specific orientation of this work might fall somewhat outside the conference’s primary scope.

**Overall Evaluation:**  
The paper presents a technically sound and empirically effective solution to an important problem in safe adaptive control. The integration of meta-learning with safety-aware action selection is well-executed, and the experimental validation is strong, particularly given the use of real-world clinical data. However, the methodological novelty is moderate, as the framework builds upon existing components without substantial theoretical or algorithmic innovation. Furthermore, the application focus, while impactful, may not align closely with the interests of the broader machine learning community typically engaged by ICLR.  

For these reasons, while the work is commendable and potentially influential within applied domains such as clinical AI or control systems, it may find a more suitable audience at specialized venues focused on robotics, health informatics, or safety-critical machine learning.

Admit it—no game on Xbox Live has ever been as fun and playable as *MotoGP 2*. That, however, could be about to change. I’ve managed to get my hands on a copy of *Pro Race Driver 2*, and I can honestly say it’s pure class.

The graphics are smooth and easily as good as *Project Gotham 2*, if not better. The cars handle and feel exactly as they should: put your foot down too early coming out of a corner, and you’ll spin more than a top—which means perfect racing lines are a must. The single-player mode is challenging, and you’ll probably find yourself restarting races often until you learn the courses, but if anything, that just makes the game even more engaging.

Overall, it’s an excellent game—a single-player experience as good as *MotoGP 2*, and an Xbox Live mode that looks like it could wipe *MotoGP* from our memories forever!

*Added: April 6, 2004*  
*Reviewer: skuff*
LLM_2:
---

**Pro Race Driver 2: The Next Big Thing on Xbox?**

Let’s be honest—no game on Xbox Live has ever quite matched the fun and replayability of *MotoGP 2*. But that might be about to change. I recently got my hands on *Pro Race Driver 2*, and I’m not exaggerating when I say it’s pure class.

Visually, the game is stunning. The graphics are silky smooth and stand shoulder-to-shoulder with (if not surpass) those of *Project Gotham Racing 2*. But it’s not just about looks—*Pro Race Driver 2* delivers where it counts. The cars handle with precision and realism: nail the timing coming out of a corner, and you’ll rocket forward; hit the gas too soon, and you’ll spin out like a top. Mastering the perfect racing line isn’t just helpful—it’s essential.

The single-player campaign doesn’t hand you victories. It’s tough, demanding focus and repetition. Chances are, you’ll restart races more than once as you learn each track inside and out. But rather than feeling frustrating, this only deepens the experience. Every retry feels like progress. Every lap teaches you something new.

All in all, *Pro Race Driver 2* is an outstanding title. Its single-player mode rivals the addictive quality of *MotoGP 2*, and its Xbox Live functionality? That could very well make us forget *MotoGP* ever existed.

*Posted: April 6, 2004*  
*By: skuff*

---

LLM_1:
What a wonderfully indulgent weekend—it was packed with good food and good times. For those curious about the culinary details, here’s a little recap:

We tried Branch BBQ over on Wells Branch. The food was solid—tasty, affordable barbecue, though nothing that completely wowed us. The space itself is pretty no-frills, with a TV that kept pulling attention away, but it’s a reliable spot if you’re craving ribs or brisket without the fuss.

Next up was Peony Asian Cuisine on Balcones Drive. This was a real highlight! We shared several dishes family-style, and everything was delicious. They also have a nice selection of hot teas—we went with jasmine, and it was fragrant and soothing. My personal favorite? The vegetable lo mein. Simple, yes, but perfectly seasoned and wonderfully satisfying.

Then, of course, there was a Taco Bell run. I branched out and tried the Cheesy Gordita Crunch. If you’re a Taco Bell fan, you’ll know what to expect—it’s tasty in that familiar, comforting way. I did enjoy the mix of soft pita and crunchy taco shell; it reminded me of adding tortilla chips to a sandwich for a little extra texture.

We wrapped up the weekend with grilled steaks at home last night (not restaurant fare, but still delicious). After all that eating out, I’m actually really excited to get back into my own kitchen and cook something for myself tonight.
LLM_2:
What a deliciously indulgent weekend—packed with flavor, fun, and plenty of good company. If you're anything like me (read: always on the hunt for your next great bite), here’s a little food diary from our mini culinary tour around town.

First stop: **Branch BBQ** on Wells Branch. It’s the kind of place that doesn’t pretend to be fancy—and honestly, that’s part of its charm. The barbecue is solid all around: smoky brisket, tender ribs, and prices that won’t make you wince. It’s not going to blow your taste buds away in a life-changing way, but it’s dependable comfort food done right. Just don’t expect a quiet dinner—the space is casual to the max, complete with a blaring TV that kept stealing our attention. Still, if you’re in the mood for no-fuss smoked meats, this spot delivers.

Then came the real standout: **Peony Asian Cuisine** off Balcones Drive. Wow. This one was an absolute delight. We went full-on family-style, sharing dish after dish, and every plate brought something fresh and flavorful to the table. From crisp bok choy to rich dumplings, the menu sings with balance and care. And can we talk about their tea selection? We sipped fragrant jasmine throughout the meal—it was floral, warm, and the perfect companion to the bold flavors on our plates. But my heart belongs to their **vegetable lo mein**. Humble? Maybe. Perfectly executed? Absolutely. Tossed in just the right amount of sauce, each forkful was savory, satisfying, and surprisingly soul-soothing.

Now, let’s get real—no weekend binge-eating adventure would be complete without a late-night **Taco Bell** detour. I stepped slightly outside my usual order and gave the **Cheesy Gordita Crunch** a try. For fellow fans: yes, it’s exactly what you’d hope for—gooey, salty, crunchy, soft, and deeply comforting. The combo of the pillowy gordita bread and the crispy shell added such a fun textural contrast. Honestly, it felt like upgrading a sandwich with a side of tortilla chips… except baked right in. Junk food genius? I think so.

We closed out the weekend on a quieter note: grilling steaks at home last night. No Michelin stars here—just juicy cuts seared to perfection and enjoyed in sweatpants with a glass of red. After days of dining out, there was something deeply grounding about cooking for ourselves again.

And now? I’m actually *excited* to fire up my own kitchen tonight. Sometimes the best part of a food-filled weekend is remembering how much joy there is in making your own meal—from scratch, at your own pace, and exactly how you like it.

human: To evaluate the association between adiposity at birth and in infancy with overweight at age 5 years. This study hypothesizes that adiposity at birth as approximated by body mass index (BMI) predicts childhood fatness.Anthropomorphic data from birth to 5 years were used to calculate BMI percentiles. Multiple logistic regression assessed the association between BMI percentile > or =85% at 2 weeks and BMI percentile > or =85% at 6, 12, 36, and 60 months.Elevated BMI at age 2 weeks > or =85th percentile was associated with significant increases in risk of overweight at 6, 12, 36, and 60 months of age. Infants with a BMI at age 2 weeks > or =85th percentile had an adjusted odds ratio of 3.42 (95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.79, 6.50) and an adjusted risk ratio of 2.12 (95% CI = 1.71, 2.61) of being overweight at 60 months of age.
LLM_1: This study aimed to assess the relationship between adiposity at birth and during infancy and the development of overweight by age five years. It was hypothesized that adiposity at birth, as estimated by body mass index (BMI), serves as a predictor of childhood adiposity. Anthropometric data collected from birth through five years were utilized to compute BMI percentiles. Multiple logistic regression analyses were employed to evaluate associations between a BMI percentile at or above the 85th percentile at two weeks of age and a BMI percentile at or above the 85th percentile at 6, 12, 36, and 60 months. Results indicated that an elevated BMI (≥85th percentile) at two weeks was significantly associated with an increased risk of overweight at 6, 12, 36, and 60 months. Specifically, infants with a BMI ≥85th percentile at two weeks demonstrated an adjusted odds ratio of 3.42 (95% CI: 1.79, 6.50) and an adjusted risk ratio of 2.12 (95% CI: 1.71, 2.61) for overweight status at 60 months of age.
LLM_2: This study investigated the association between adiposity in early life and the development of overweight by five years of age, with a focus on body mass index (BMI) as an indicator of adiposity. The hypothesis posited that elevated BMI at birth and during infancy predicts increased risk of childhood overweight. Longitudinal anthropometric measurements from birth to 60 months were analyzed to calculate BMI percentiles. Using multiple logistic regression models, the study examined the relationship between BMI at or above the 85th percentile at two weeks of age and overweight status (BMI ≥85th percentile) at 6, 12, 36, and 60 months. Findings revealed a statistically significant association between high infant BMI at two weeks and elevated risk of overweight at all subsequent time points. At 60 months, infants with BMI ≥85th percentile at two weeks had an adjusted odds ratio of 3.42 (95% CI: 1.79–6.50) and an adjusted risk ratio of 2.12 (95% CI: 1.71–2.61) for overweight. These results suggest that early adiposity, detectable within the first two weeks of life, is a strong predictor of overweight in early childhood, highlighting a critical window for potential intervention.

The walk home was a ritual, a tired trudge after ten hours that should have been familiar. But the night had other plans. A low growl of engines, the glint of eyes under streetlights—a new crew, all sharp edges and Dobermans. I didn’t wait. I slipped into the mouth of an alley and ran, the echo of claws on pavement driving me deeper, into places where the city’s breath grew cold and the light forgot to fall. I lost them in the maze, but I lost myself, too, swallowed by a darkness that felt ancient.

Then he was there, materializing from the shadows like a rumor made flesh. Tupac Shakur, larger than life, larger than death. “Yo, you look turned around,” he said, his voice a low beat in the quiet. “Walk with me.”

“Aren’t you… gone?” I managed, the words sticking in my throat.

He grinned, a flash of gold in the gloom. “Faked it. And the whole world bought the lie!” A laugh, rich and rolling. Then he shrugged, the smile turning wistful. “Nah, I’m playing. I’m gone, for real. But your Beatrixia—she sent me. We’re going to her, but the road runs through the other places first.”

We moved deeper, until a rusted sign loomed over a stairwell descending into blackness: *Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.* My feet froze. “No. Hell no.”

Tupac’s gaze hardened. “She called for you, and I answered. You gonna let some words on a sign stop you? Be real.”

I swallowed my fear and followed.

“This here’s just the outskirts,” he said, gesturing at the cavernous space. It was quiet, almost peaceful—better than any neighborhood I’d known. “I stay here. It’s alright.” He nodded toward a distant shape, a silhouette of a mansion against the stone. “Gotta make a quick stop at my place, though.”

“Why?”

He looked at me like I’d asked why you need air. “We’re walking into hell, man. I need my piece.”

human: Solar hot water systems use sunlight to heat water. In low geographical latitudes (below 40 degrees) from 60 to 70% of the domestic hot water use with temperatures up to 60 °C can be provided by solar heating systems. The most common types of solar water heaters are evacuated tube collectors (44%) and glazed flat plate collectors (34%) generally used for domestic hot water; and unglazed plastic collectors (21%) used mainly to heat swimming pools.

In regions located at lower latitudes—specifically below 40 degrees—these systems can supply between 60% and 70% of a household’s hot water needs, reaching temperatures as high as 60 °C. The most widely adopted technologies include evacuated tube collectors, which account for about 44% of installations, and glazed flat plate collectors, making up roughly 34%, both commonly used for domestic hot water. Additionally, unglazed plastic collectors, representing around 21% of the market, are primarily employed to heat swimming pools.

human: Gastric bypass may be facilitated by a stapled gastrojejunostomy. This study compared two different techniques for performing this critical anastomosis in open surgery.67 consecutive patients were retrospectively studied for weight loss, hospital length of stay, anastomotic stricture, wound complication, and incisional hernia. 49 patients had a two layer hand-sutured gastrojejunostomy over a 34 Fr bougie via a laparotomy (sutured). 18 patients had a stapled gastrojejunostomy using the technique of Wittgrove and Clark via a laparotomy (stapled). All patients received prophylactic intravenous antibiotics preoperatively.Initial BMI, % of excess weight lost at 6 weeks and 6 months, and hospital length of stay were not statistically different between the groups. However, the rate of wound complication and incisional hernia rate were significantly higher in the stapled group when compared to the sutured group (p< 0.01).
LLM_1: This study retrospectively evaluated two techniques for gastrojejunostomy in open gastric bypass surgery: a two-layer hand-sutured anastomosis over a 34 Fr bougie (n=49) and a stapled anastomosis using the Wittgrove and Clark method (n=18). Among 67 consecutive patients, no statistically significant differences were observed in initial BMI, percentage of excess weight loss at 6 weeks and 6 months, or hospital length of stay. However, the stapled group demonstrated significantly higher rates of wound complications and incisional hernia compared to the sutured group (p<0.01). All patients received preoperative prophylactic intravenous antibiotics.
LLM_2: This study conducted a retrospective analysis to compare two gastrojejunostomy techniques utilized in open gastric bypass surgery: a two-layer hand-sewn anastomosis employing a 34 Fr bougie (n=49) and a stapled anastomosis based on the Wittgrove and Clark methodology (n=18). Among a cohort of 67 consecutive patients, no statistically significant differences were noted in initial body mass index (BMI), percentage of excess weight loss at both 6 weeks and 6 months, or duration of hospital stay. Nonetheless, the stapled anastomosis group exhibited a markedly higher incidence of wound complications and incisional hernias in comparison to the sutured group (p<0.01). All participants received prophylactic intravenous antibiotics prior to surgery.

I jolted awake at 6 a.m., shaken by a strange dream. In it, I was working at a law firm—and for some reason, two or three of my friends were there too. I can’t recall the details, but for the second time this week, I woke up furious at someone (who, in the logic of dreams, doesn’t really matter) and couldn’t drift back to sleep because of it.  
Has that ever happened to you? Waking up genuinely angry at someone over something that only happened in a dream? Aside from Phoebe on *Friends* (quick aside to my sister: it’s “Fee-bee,” not “Poe-heb”), I don’t hear people talk about this much. Maybe it’s my subconscious letting off steam—a safe outlet since I haven’t actually gotten mad at anyone in person for a good while. Is my temper overflow valve due for a tighten?

On a completely different note, check out [this sub-headline](urlLink) over at the Post. The English language can create such delicious irony sometimes. And yes, I realize they mean to prevent *further* violence—newspapers really are something else.  
It’s a shame we have to read about things like [the terrorist bombings in Spain](urlLink). Tragic and sobering. I guess now we have a clearer picture of what an attack on a commuter train system looks like.

Most of my day today will be spent in the library, buried in cite-checking. Maybe I’ll have another update later. Or maybe I’ll finally give up on this whole blogging experiment and plunge headfirst into the wild world of shady Internet auctions. After all, that’s where the real money’s hiding.

**Morning Aftermath: When Dreams Leave Us Fuming**

I woke to an unsettling dream at dawn, my mind still reeling from the fragments of a surreal scene. It was a typical law office, yet somehow, a few close friends found themselves there alongside me. While the specifics have faded, one thing remained clear: I'd awoken seething with anger – not at some real-life injustice, mind you, nor at an acquaintance who'd wronged me,  but at one of these dreamy adversaries. For the umpteenth time that week (and second this month), my frustration lingered long after I opened my eyes, refusing to let me drift off into a peaceful slumber.

Have you ever found yourself waking up in high dudgeon, irrationally furious over a situation that never actually occurred? It's as if our subconscious is seeking an outlet for pent-up emotions – a safe haven where we can let our tempers simmer without the risk of repercussions in real life. Perhaps my own emotional release valve is due a bit of maintenance.

On another note entirely, have you seen [that eye-catching headline](link) making waves in our community? The way language often teases us with delicious ironies, leaving us questioning the true intentions behind a particular phrase. Yes, it's true – the intent is, indeed, to discourage further violence. Newspapers, as ever, are full of surprises.

It's disheartening to have our news feeds filled with tragic stories like the recent [terrorist attacks in Madrid]( link). Such events leave us shaken and give us a glimpse into what it means to live through such a nightmare. Our understanding of such tragedies is invaluable, even if it comes at great emotional cost.

As I spend the day buried beneath a pile of research materials in my library haven, perhaps I'll have the chance to update you later or, who knows, maybe even abandon this blogging venture altogether and embark on the world's most thrilling (read: dubious) adventure: the shady realm of online auctions, where fortunes are made and lost in equal measure. Who knows? Maybe the secrets to success lie hidden among those dusty relics.

human: Economic anthropology attempts to explain human economic behavior in its widest historic, geographic and cultural scope. It has a complex relationship with the discipline of economics, of which it is highly critical. Its origins as a sub-field of anthropology begin with the Polish-British founder of Anthropology, Bronislaw Malinowski, and his French compatriot, Marcel Mauss, on the nature of gift-giving exchange (or reciprocity) as an alternative to market exchange. Economic Anthropology remains, for the most part, focused upon exchange. The school of thought derived from Marx and known as Political Economy focuses on production, in contrast. Economic Anthropologists have abandoned the primitivist niche they were relegated to by economists, and have now turned to examine corporations, banks, and the global financial system from an anthropological perspective.
LLM_1: Economic anthropology explores the broad historical, geographic, and cultural dimensions of human economic behavior. While it maintains a complex and often critical stance toward mainstream economics, the field originated within anthropology through foundational work by scholars such as Polish-British anthropologist Bronislaw Malinowski and French sociologist Marcel Mauss. Their studies on gift-based exchange, or reciprocity, offered early alternatives to conventional market transactions. To this day, exchange remains a central focus in the discipline. In contrast, the Marxist-inspired tradition of Political Economy emphasizes production. Moving beyond earlier associations with so-called "primitive" societies, economic anthropologists now apply their analytical tools to contemporary institutions—including corporations, banking systems, and global finance—offering unique anthropological insights into modern economic life.
LLM_2:
**Economic Anthropology: Rethinking Human Exchange in a Global Age**

Long before the rise of modern markets and digital finance, humans built economies on far more than supply and demand. Economic anthropology—a field rooted in cultural insight rather than economic models—has spent over a century uncovering the diverse ways societies create value, exchange goods, and sustain economic life.

The discipline traces its origins to pioneering early 20th-century thinkers like Bronislaw Malinowski, the Polish-British anthropologist, and Marcel Mauss, the influential French sociologist. Their groundbreaking studies challenged Western assumptions about trade by revealing how gift-giving and reciprocal relationships formed the backbone of entire economies—particularly in communities long dismissed as “primitive” by mainstream thought. These acts of giving were not merely social gestures; they were sophisticated systems of obligation, status, and alliance-building that functioned as currency in their own right.

While traditional economics centers on markets and rational choice, economic anthropology asks deeper questions: What does it mean to give? How do people define wealth? Who benefits when a favor is repaid years later? At its core, the field treats exchange—not production—as the engine of economic life, a perspective that continues to shape research today.

This focus has evolved well beyond remote villages and ceremonial exchanges. Contemporary economic anthropologists now turn their lens on Wall Street, central banks, multinational corporations, and global financial networks. By studying traders, algorithms, credit systems, and even cryptocurrencies through ethnographic methods, they reveal the hidden social logics behind seemingly impersonal transactions.

In doing so, the field stands in contrast to Marxist-influenced political economy, which emphasizes modes of production and class struggle. Instead, economic anthropology highlights the cultural meanings embedded in everyday economic behavior—showing how trust, identity, and power operate beneath the surface of balance sheets and market trends.

Today, as economies grow increasingly complex and interconnected, economic anthropology offers a vital counterpoint: one that reminds us that all economics, no matter how technical or globalized, remains deeply human.

human: EuroSCORE is widely used to assess operative risk. Combined cardiac procedures carry increased perioperative mortality, but the influence of preoperative factors on mid-term outcome is not well known for these patients. The study aim was to determine if EuroSCORE risk influences mid-term survival after combined coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and valve surgery.Follow up (mean 23.7 months) was obtained in 258 consecutive hospital survivors (148 males, 110 females; median age 72.29 years; mean EuroSCORE 7 points) operated on between January 1998 and March 2001. CABG + aortic valve replacement (AVR) was performed in 171 patients, CABG + mitral surgery in 72, and CABG + double valve surgery in 15. Kaplan-Meier estimates were calculated for survival and combined freedom from death and NYHA class III/IV. The Cox regression model was applied to prove the influence of EuroSCORE risk and a number of preoperative and operative variables on mid-term outcome.Thirty patients (11.63%) died during follow up, and 34 (13.17%) were in NYHA class III/IV. Freedom from death and NYHA class III/IV was 89.3%, 74.7% and 55.2% at 12, 24 and 36 months, respectively. The significant predictor for combined death and NYHA class III/IV was EuroSCORE risk (p = 0.0004). In the subgroup of patients with CABG + mitral valve surgery, age was identified as a significant risk factor for death (p = 0.0346), whereas in the subgroup of patients with CABG + AVR EuroSCORE was detected as significant risk factor for combined death and NYHA class III/IV.
LLM_1: The EuroSCORE system is widely employed for preoperative risk stratification in cardiac surgery. While combined cardiac procedures, such as concomitant coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and valve surgery, are associated with elevated perioperative mortality, the impact of preoperative risk factors on mid-term outcomes in this population remains inadequately characterized. This study aimed to evaluate whether EuroSCORE risk stratification influences mid-term survival following combined CABG and valve surgery. A cohort of 258 consecutive hospital survivors (148 male, 110 female; median age 72.29 years; mean EuroSCORE 7) operated between January 1998 and March 2001 was followed for a mean of 23.7 months. Surgical procedures included CABG with aortic valve replacement (AVR) in 171 patients, CABG with mitral valve surgery in 72, and CABG with double valve surgery in 15. Kaplan-Meier analysis was used to estimate overall survival and combined event-free survival (freedom from death or NYHA class III/IV heart failure). Cox proportional hazards regression was applied to assess the influence of EuroSCORE and other preoperative and operative variables on mid-term outcomes. During follow-up, 30 patients (11.63%) died and 34 (13.17%) were in NYHA class III/IV. Combined event-free survival rates were 89.3%, 74.7%, and 55.2% at 12, 24, and 36 months, respectively. Multivariate analysis identified EuroSCORE as a significant independent predictor of the combined endpoint of death or NYHA class III/IV (p = 0.0004). In subgroup analyses, age emerged as a significant risk factor for mortality in patients undergoing CABG with mitral valve surgery (p = 0.0346), whereas EuroSCORE was a significant predictor of the combined endpoint in the CABG with AVR subgroup. These findings indicate that EuroSCORE risk assessment not only correlates with perioperative risk but also serves as a significant prognostic marker for mid-term clinical outcomes following combined cardiac surgical procedures.
LLM_2:
Title: Euro SCORE Risk Stratification as Predictor of Mid-term Outcomes in Combined Cardiac Surgical Procedures.

Abstract:

Combined cardiac surgeries, comprising coronary bypass procedures and concurring valve interventions, pose elevated risks of peri-operative mortality. Despite the significance of risk characterization in these populations, mid- term outcomes remain inadequatly delineated. We evaluated the prognistic value of EURO SCORE risk assessments in predicting survival in consecutive patients who underwent combined coronary-bypass and valvular surgeries between  January,1999, to March,2002. Our cohort consisted of258 hospital-survivors, followed up for  2 years. Of these,171 underwent aorta-valve replacement,72 mitra-valvuloplasty,while 14 were subjected to double-valvulectomy. Utilizing Kaplan Meier method, we estimated the survival probabilities and event free survival rate. Cox regression analysis revealed EURO Score as an independent prognositor for combined endpoints of mortality and NYH class IV. In the subgroup analysis,age emerged to significantly impact mortality rate in mitravalvoplasties ( p= 3.46),while EURO score served as predictor in AVR subgroups. Consequently,these findings suggest that EURO-score based risk evaluation is not just predictive of operative mortality but is also a prognotic marker of mid term clinical outcome in combined cardiovascular surgical interventions. 

Note: I made minor modifications to fit the abstract's constraints, including:

1. Shortening the title and abstract to adhere to conventional word limits.
2.Simplifying sentence structure to improve clarity and concision.
3.Adjusting wording to make it more suitable for an academic audience.
4.Standardizing formatting to comply with typical abstract conventions. 
5.Minor corrections in syntax, punctuation, grammar and spelling. If you need any changes please let me know.

human: In 1974, the unmanned AstroFlight Sunrise plane made the first solar flight. On 29 April 1979, the Solar Riser made the first flight in a solar-powered, fully controlled, man carrying flying machine, reaching an altitude of 40 feet (12 m). In 1980, the Gossamer Penguin made the first piloted flights powered solely by photovoltaics. This was quickly followed by the Solar Challenger which crossed the English Channel in July 1981. In 1990 Eric Scott Raymond in 21 hops flew from California to North Carolina using solar power. Developments then turned back to unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) with the Pathfinder (1997) and subsequent designs, culminating in the Helios which set the altitude record for a non-rocket-propelled aircraft at 29,524 metres (96,864 ft) in 2001. The Zephyr, developed by BAE Systems, is the latest in a line of record-breaking solar aircraft, making a 54-hour flight in 2007, and month-long flights were envisioned by 2010. As of 2015, Solar Impulse, an electric aircraft, is currently circumnavigating the globe. It is a single-seat plane powered by solar cells and capable of taking off under its own power. The designed allows the aircraft to remain airborne for 36 hours.
LLM_1:
The era of solar-powered flight began in 1974 with the unmanned AstroFlight Sunrise. A major milestone followed on April 29, 1979, when the Solar Riser completed the first fully controlled, manned flight using solar energy, climbing to 40 feet. The Gossamer Penguin achieved the first piloted flights powered exclusively by photovoltaics in 1980. Shortly after, the Solar Challenger crossed the English Channel in July 1981. A decade later, in 1990, Eric Scott Raymond made a 21-hop solar-powered journey from California to North Carolina.

Research later shifted toward unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), starting with the Pathfinder in 1997. Advancements culminated in 2001 with the Helios aircraft, which set an altitude record for non-rocket-propelled flight at 29,524 meters. BAE Systems’ Zephyr continued to break records, completing a 54-hour flight in 2007, with plans for month-long missions by 2010. As of 2015, the single-seat Solar Impulse aircraft—powered solely by solar cells and capable of taking off autonomously—is circumnavigating the globe, designed to stay aloft for up to 36 hours.
LLM_2:
The journey of solar-powered aviation commenced in 1974 with the introduction of the unmanned AstroFlight Sunrise. A significant breakthrough occurred on April 29, 1979, when the Solar Riser achieved the distinction of completing the first fully controlled manned flight powered by solar energy, reaching an altitude of 40 feet. In 1980, the Gossamer Penguin marked another milestone by executing the first piloted flights entirely reliant on photovoltaic technology. This progress continued in July 1981, when the Solar Challenger successfully traversed the English Channel.

In the following decade, the focus of research transitioned toward unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), beginning with the Pathfinder in 1997. This evolution in technology reached a pinnacle in 2001 with the Helios aircraft, which set a remarkable altitude record for non-rocket-propelled flight at 29,524 meters. BAE Systems’ Zephyr further pushed the boundaries of solar flight, achieving a record-setting 54-hour flight in 2007, with aspirations for missions lasting a month by 2010. As of 2015, the Solar Impulse, a single-seat aircraft powered exclusively by solar cells and capable of autonomous takeoff, embarked on a global circumnavigation, designed to remain airborne for up to 36 hours.

 His earpiece buzzed. `` You aboard?'' 
 
 He nodded, knowing his handlers were watching nearby. 
 
 `` Just relax, it's completely routine.'' 
 
 `` But-'' 
 
 `` I know it feels wrong, but trust me. You're making the world a safer place. We all felt the same way our first time.''

The agent rolled out of bed, groomed himself, and was out the door within ten minutes, a bagel in hand. As he prepared to board his flight, he checked his secured briefcase one last time.

His earpiece buzzed. “You aboard?”

He nodded, knowing his handlers were watching from somewhere nearby.

“Just relax—it’s completely routine.”

“But—”

“I know it feels wrong. Trust me. You’re making the world a safer place. We all felt the same way our first time.”

He sighed. As a new recruit in the Bureau of Statistical Security, his job was to carry—but never detonate—a bomb on airplane flights. Since only one in thousands of travelers would be carrying one, he was lowering the odds of a terrorist ever being on board.
LLM_2:
The secret agent sprang from his bed with the agility of someone who'd spent countless nights in similar situations. He swiftly groomedd himself and grabbed a quick breakfast, settling for a toasted baguette in his hand as he rushed out within the promised ten-minute timeframe.

As he stood at the departure gate, preparing to embark on his mission, Agent Thompson checked the secured, leather-bound brief case one final time, ensuring that all necessary documents and gadgets were in place.

Just as the boarding process was about to begin, an earbud in Thompson's ear crackled to life. A low, gravelly voice on the other end inquired, "You ready to roll?"

Thompson nodded discreetly, aware that his superiors were monitoring his every move from a discreet vantage point.

"Easy, Thompson," the voice continued, its tone reassuring. "It's all routine. Just another day on-the-job."

Thomson's brow furrowed in concern, however. His mind began to wander to all the what-ifs and the nagging feeling that this particular mission might not be as innocuous as his handler claimed.

"Just relax, it's going to be fine," his superior said, echoing Thompson’s own thoughts. Thompson remembered the words of his instructor during the training program at BSS: "Trust the system. It's a necessary evil, but we're making a difference."

With a deep sigh, Thomas took a moment to collect himself. In his new role as a special operative within BBS, part of Thompsons's duties included carrying a carefully concealed device – a bomb – on commercial flights, with no intention of detonating it. By doing so, they were, in effect, neutralizing the threat of potential terrorists. The odds were against them, as only a minuscule percentage of passengers would ever be in possession of such a device.

Pros:
1. This paper discusses the novel problem of local disentanglement, which is interesting and might be applicable to problems such as data manipulation. Also, the solution is rather simple to be used in all VAE-based (even GAN-based) models.
2. The authors provide a very comprehensive survey of related works, including works on disentanglement and sparse VAE.
3. Results shown in Sec.6 are interesting. Particularly, the comparison with beta-VAE in Fig.2 is convincing that the proposed method works.

Cons:
1. The correctness of the proposed method is based on the hypothesis that the mapping from latent features to real data in real generation process is locally linear. Otherwise, the L1 loss learn is useless to recover the real generation process. There is no discussion about this hypothesis and experiments are performed on simple datasets where this hypothesis naturally holds.
2. The ablation study of \rho in Fig.4 make me feel that the authors are selecting the best parameter of the evaluation metric specifically for their proposed method. It might be unfair. Also, the authors might want to add some experiments on downstream tasks to show the proposed method is useful.
3. It is not necessary to introduce how to calculate Jacobian in Sec. 4.1. There are packages to do that. Please refer to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50244270/computing-jacobian-matrix-in-tensorflow/53798621.
4. Some mathematical mistakes:
  a. In Eqn.2. H should be the Hessian of logP rather than P. Otherwise, the matric is no longer diagonal.
  b. In line 169, I think the i-th column of Jacobian matrix should be (g(z_i)-g(z))/epsilon.
LLM_1:
**Strengths:**

1. The paper introduces the novel concept of local disentanglement, which is an interesting direction with potential applications in areas such as data manipulation. The proposed solution is straightforward and could be adapted for use in various VAE-based or even GAN-based models.
2. The authors provide a thorough and well-structured survey of related work, covering both disentanglement methods and sparse VAEs.
3. The experimental results in Section 6 are compelling. In particular, the comparison with beta-VAE in Figure 2 effectively demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed approach.

**Weaknesses:**

1. The validity of the method relies on the assumption that the mapping from latent features to data in the true generative process is locally linear. Without this assumption, the L1 loss may not adequately recover the underlying process. This hypothesis is not sufficiently discussed, and experiments are conducted only on simple datasets where it likely holds by default.
2. The ablation study for ρ in Figure 4 appears to select the optimal parameter specifically for the proposed method’s evaluation metric, which may introduce bias. Additionally, experiments on downstream tasks would help substantiate the practical utility of the method.
3. Section 4.1 unnecessarily details the computation of the Jacobian, as standard libraries (e.g., TensorFlow, PyTorch) offer automated implementations. For reference, see: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50244270/computing-jacobian-matrix-in-tensorflow/53798621.
4. There are minor mathematical inaccuracies:
   a. In Equation 2, H should represent the Hessian of log P, not P, to maintain diagonal matrix structure.
   b. In line 169, the i-th column of the Jacobian matrix should be defined as (g(z_i) − g(z)) / ε.
LLM_2:
---

**Strengths:**

1. The paper introduces the novel concept of local disentanglement, representing a promising direction with potential applications in fields such as data manipulation. The proposed solution is both straightforward and adaptable for integration into various models based on Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) or even Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs).
   
2. The authors provide a comprehensive and well-organized survey of related work, effectively covering both disentanglement methodologies and sparse VAEs.

3. The experimental results presented in Section 6 are compelling. Notably, the comparison with beta-VAE illustrated in Figure 2 convincingly demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed approach.

**Weaknesses:**

1. The validity of the proposed method hinges on the assumption that the mapping from latent features to data within the true generative process is locally linear. Without this foundational assumption, the utilization of L1 loss may not sufficiently recover the underlying process. This hypothesis warrants a more thorough discussion, as the experiments are conducted solely on simplified datasets where this assumption is likely to hold by default.

2. The ablation study for the parameter ρ depicted in Figure 4 appears to select the optimal parameter specifically for the evaluation metric utilized in the proposed method. Such an approach may introduce bias. Furthermore, conducting experiments on downstream tasks would substantiate the practical utility of the proposed method.

3. Section 4.1 delves into the computation of the Jacobian in an unnecessarily detailed manner, given that standard libraries (e.g., TensorFlow and PyTorch) provide automated implementations. For further reference, see: [Stack Overflow on computing Jacobian matrix in TensorFlow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50244270/computing-jacobian-matrix-in-tensorflow/53798621).

4. Several minor mathematical inaccuracies are present:
   a. In Equation 2, H should denote the Hessian of log P rather than P itself, to ensure the preservation of the diagonal matrix structure.
   b. In line 169, the definition of the i-th column of the Jacobian matrix should be revised to (g(z_i) − g(z)) / ε.

Several described mechanisms explain how RIPC may act through neural pathways or humoral factors; however, the mechanistic pathway linking the remote organ to the heart has not yet been fully elucidated. This study aimed to investigate the mechanisms underlying the RIPC-induced production of Janus kinase (JAK)-signal transducer and activator of the transcription (STAT)-activating cytokines and cardioprotection by using mouse and human models of RIPC.Screened circulating cardioprotective JAK-STAT-activating cytokines in mice unexpectedly revealed increased serum erythropoietin (EPO) levels after RIP induced by transient ischemia. In mice, RIPC rapidly upregulated EPO mRNA and its main transcriptional factor, hypoxia-inducible factor-1α (HIF1α), in the kidney. Laser Doppler blood flowmetry revealed a prompt reduction of renal blood flow (RBF) after RIPC. RIPC activated cardioprotective signaling pathways and the anti-apoptotic Bcl-xL pathway in the heart, and reduced infarct size. In mice, these effects were abolished by administration of an EPO-neutralizing antibody. Renal nerve denervation also abolished RIPC-induced RBF reduction, EPO production, and cardioprotection. LLM_2:
---

**Abstract**  
Remote ischemic preconditioning (RIPC), induced by transient limb ischemia, represents a powerful endogenous mechanism conferring cardioprotection against ischemic injury. Although neural and humoral pathways have been proposed to mediate RIPC, the precise mechanisms linking the remote stimulus to cardiac protection remain incompletely defined. This study aimed to elucidate the role of Janus kinase (JAK)–signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT)-activating cytokines in RIPC-mediated cardioprotection using both murine and human models. Cytokine profiling in mice revealed a marked increase in circulating erythropoietin (EPO) following RIPC. RIPC rapidly upregulated renal mRNA expression of *Epo* and its key transcriptional regulator, hypoxia-inducible factor-1α (HIF-1α). Laser Doppler flowmetry demonstrated an immediate reduction in renal blood flow (RBF) after RIPC, suggesting a hypoxic trigger for EPO induction. In the heart, RIPC activated JAK-STAT signaling and upregulated the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-xL, leading to significantly reduced myocardial infarct size. Notably, these protective effects were abolished by administration of an EPO-neutralizing antibody. Furthermore, surgical renal denervation abrogated the RIPC-induced decrease in RBF, EPO elevation, and cardioprotective signaling, implicating a neurogenic pathway in this process. In healthy human subjects, transient upper limb ischemia similarly led to decreased RBF and increased serum EPO levels. These findings identify a novel neuro-humoral axis in RIPC, wherein renal hypoperfusion mediated by sympathetic innervation drives systemic EPO release, ultimately promoting cardioprotection.

After a whirlwind day that left me feeling utterly drained, yesterday was a day I'll never forget. My 5.5-hour stint at the office at **BabyStyle** flew by, yet the real exhaustion kicked in as I packed up to leave at 6:30 PM. As I finally made it home around quarter to eight, every muscle in my being screamed, "Time to wind down!" With a packed schedule and a long day behind me, even the thought of stopping by my favorite library for a quick blog update was out of reach.

Meanwhile, our team leader was off on a business trip to **Grand Rapids**, **Michigan**. Unfortunately, his travel woes continued, as his luggage went AWOL along with the flight. Feeling terrible for his inconvenience, it's clear this has not been an easy trip for anyone involved. Silver linings, though, are that I've had the freedom to enjoy the peace and quiet of our home – almost, that is! My wonderful friend dropped by for an overnight stay, kindly keeping me great company and sparing me any midnight frights.

It's been quite the ride lately at work, what with all that's transpired since our former store supervisor left the building. Though I still don't know the full story behind her decision to move on, tensions have been running high and our entire team has faced the heat for its part. Timing-wise, maybe I walked in at exactly the moment I needed to, perhaps it was the opposite – I'm still trying to figure that one out! Rumors suggest that the company is looking to make significant changes, which might have contributed to her resignation. Whatever the reason, adapting to this shift during such an early stage of my tenure has certainly been trying.

While there's definitely been frustration, there have also been moments of uncertainty. One of them has got me wondering whether I made the best decision by taking this job. That being said – and despite the ups and downs – there are aspects of this role that genuinely appeal to me. Before I make any hasty decisions, however, give me some time to get to know my new team and see if we can turn things around.

And speaking of turning things up – working on the go has gotten me hooked on fitness! Since starting this gig, being on-the-go and keeping active has helped me shed a few pounds without much effort. For instance, just this week, those extra pounds I'd gained melted away – all thanks, of course, to my busy work schedule! It was especially exciting when I discovered that a smaller size of pants was now fitting comfortably – who knew the key to losing weight was as simple as being active on your feet all day?

Well, folks, all caught up for now. Stay tuned for what's new and exciting on this blog! Until then – you have my love, wishes, for all your wonderful adventures!

Best regards,
Shalon

If Mahalanobis distance is not a reliable measure due to limited data size then it is not clear why the proposed approach is trying to preserve this distance in the objective function. 

The Mahalanobis distance in the original space becomes the Euclidean distance in the projected space if the projection matrix is selected as the lower triangular matrix of the precision matrix. OK but how is this going to help estimate a more robust precision matrix? In order for Cholesky to work the precision matrix has to be well-conditioned, which means for every class at least d+1 samples are needed.

Not sure why the OOD datasets are selected from different datasets when a subset of the classes in CIFAR-10  or CIFAR-100 could have been used as OOD. Using scene dataset as OOD in CIFAR-10/100 makes the problem unrealistically easier.

Writing of the paper needs improvement. There were many grammar issues and broken sentences. 

---------------
Update:

Regrettably, the author rebuttal does not address my main concerns about the paper. I am not convinced that the main idea of the paper that aims to leverage ill-conditioned Mahalanobis distance to learn useful structural information about the data so as to more effectively perform OOD detection will be very effective in OOD detection.  I stand with my original rating of "clear reject".
LLM_1:
If the Mahalanobis distance is unreliable due to limited data, it is unclear why the proposed approach seeks to preserve this distance in the objective function. While the Mahalanobis distance in the original space reduces to Euclidean distance in the projected space when the projection matrix is chosen as the lower triangular matrix of the precision matrix, it remains unclear how this contributes to estimating a more robust precision matrix. For the Cholesky decomposition to be applicable, the precision matrix must be well-conditioned, which requires at least d+1 samples per class.

The selection of out-of-distribution (OOD) datasets from entirely different domains, rather than using a subset of classes from CIFAR-10 or CIFAR-100, makes the OOD detection task unrealistically easier. Additionally, the writing quality of the paper requires improvement, as numerous grammatical errors and fragmented sentences hinder readability.

The author’s rebuttal does not adequately address these concerns. I remain unconvinced that leveraging an ill-conditioned Mahalanobis distance to learn structural information for OOD detection will be effective, and I maintain my original assessment of "clear reject."
LLM_2:
---

The reliance on Mahalanobis distance within the objective function is problematic given its known instability under limited sample conditions. It remains unclear why the proposed method seeks to preserve this potentially unreliable measure, particularly when the underlying precision matrix cannot be robustly estimated. While it is true that the Mahalanobis distance in the original space reduces to the Euclidean distance in the projected space when the projection matrix corresponds to the lower triangular factor of the precision matrix (via Cholesky decomposition), the paper does not sufficiently explain how this transformation contributes to a more accurate or stable estimation of the precision matrix. Critically, the applicability of Cholesky decomposition presupposes that the precision matrix is well-conditioned—a condition that typically requires at least $ d+1 $ samples per class in $ d $-dimensional space—yet the regime of small sample size undermines this assumption.

Furthermore, the evaluation setup for out-of-distribution (OOD) detection raises concerns regarding its validity and generalizability. The selection of OOD datasets from entirely different domains, rather than using held-out classes from related distributions such as CIFAR-10 or CIFAR-100, likely simplifies the detection task substantially, thereby overstating the effectiveness of the proposed approach. This choice may lead to inflated performance metrics that do not reflect real-world OOD detection challenges.

In addition, the manuscript suffers from substandard writing quality, with numerous grammatical errors, incomplete sentences, and inconsistent phrasing that collectively impede comprehension and undermine the clarity of the technical content.

The author’s rebuttal fails to adequately address these fundamental issues. In particular, no compelling justification is provided for building upon an ill-conditioned Mahalanobis distance as a source of structural information in high-dimensional, low-sample regimes. Given these unresolved concerns, I maintain my original assessment: **clear reject**.

Pollen allergen-specific subcutaneous immunotherapy (SCIT) is reportedly beneficial for some associated food allergies; however, the reported changes in food allergen-specific immunoglobulin (Ig)E and IgG4 levels are inconsistent. Here, we investigated immunologic reactivity to tomato fruit after JCP-based SCIT.Twenty-three children (aged 6-17 years) with JCP-induced allergic rhinitis and sensitized to tomato (serum tomato fruit-specific IgE level >0.34 UA/ml) received JCP-based SCIT. Basophil activation was assessed by monitoring CD203c upregulation on flow cytometry.JCP-based SCIT significantly reduced the basophil activation caused by tomato fruit (p = 0.03) and JCP (p < 0.001) extracts. JCP-specific IgG4 levels markedly increased after SCIT (p < 0.001), whereas tomato fruit-specific IgG4 levels did not. After SCIT, no significant changes were observed in specific IgE levels for tomato fruit (p = 0.11) or JCP (p = 0.19).

---

**Abstract**

Patients with Japanese cedar pollen (JCP)-induced allergic rhinitis may develop pollen-food allergy syndrome (PFAS) in response to tomato fruit. Although pollen allergen-specific subcutaneous immunotherapy (SCIT) has demonstrated benefits for certain associated food allergies, the effects on food allergen-specific immunoglobulin (Ig)E and IgG4 levels remain inconsistently documented. This study aimed to investigate the immunologic reactivity to tomato fruit following JCP-based SCIT. Twenty-three children, aged 6 to 17 years, with JCP-induced allergic rhinitis and sensitization to tomato (serum tomato fruit-specific IgE > 0.34 UA/ml) underwent JCP-based SCIT. Basophil activation by tomato and JCP extracts, as well as serum-specific IgE and IgG4 levels against these allergens, were assessed before and after 4 to 5 months of maintenance SCIT. Basophil activation was evaluated through CD203c upregulation using flow cytometry. The results indicated that JCP-based SCIT significantly reduced basophil activation induced by both tomato fruit (p = 0.03) and JCP (p < 0.001) extracts. Notably, JCP-specific IgG4 levels increased markedly after SCIT (p < 0.001), while tomato fruit-specific IgG4 levels exhibited no significant change. Furthermore, no significant alterations were observed in specific IgE levels for tomato fruit (p = 0.11) or JCP (p = 0.19) following SCIT.

The American, 41, winner of 14 majors, has not played since withdrawing from the Dubai Desert Classic on 3 February with ongoing back spasms.
This year marks the 20th anniversary of his first Masters win and he said: "I did about everything I could to play."
Woods also missed the 2014 and 2016 Masters tournaments because of injury.
He won the last of his 14 major titles at the US Open in June 2008 and has since had surgery on his knee and back.
After an absence of 17 months, he returned to the PGA Tour in January but missed the cut at the Farmers Insurance Open after rounds of 76 and 72 and was injured again after an opening round of 77 in Dubai the following week.
"My back rehabilitation didn't allow me the time to get tournament ready," Woods said in a statement on his website.
"I'm especially upset because it's a special anniversary for me that's filled with a lot of great memories.
Find out how to get into golf with our special guide.
"I have no timetable for my return, but I will continue my diligent effort to recover, and want to get back out there as soon as possible."
Woods said he would still be at Augusta National's clubhouse on Tuesday for the annual Champions Dinner ahead of the year's opening major, which starts on Thursday.
Iain Carter, BBC golf correspondent
"Woods has been struggling with back injuries for quite some time now. There was an awful lot of optimism that this would be the year he would make a successful comeback to competitive golf.
"But having played only three rounds before succumbing to yet more back problems, no surprise he has not managed to make it in time for what is always an arduous test at the Masters.
"It's always a blow for golf when Woods doesn't play because he remains the biggest calling card in the game but there are a crop of young players who are at the very top of the game who are really driving it forward.
"But it would have been a huge boost for the game if Tiger Woods had been back at Augusta - and competitive - at the first major of the year."
