Today was quite a day for me. For starters, we had elections—not that I was running, but casting my vote still felt meaningful, and I’m proud I took part thoughtfully. But what really stands out from today was our inspection with the sixth graders, followed by what I’d call a remarkably thorough critique of our Corps. It wasn’t humiliating; instead, it was eye-opening how our advisor noticed even the smallest missteps, leaving us genuinely reflective.

Tomorrow is Miss Anne’s birthday, and I gave her a medium-sized orange birthday card. It didn’t cost much, but it did take time—and I suppose that’s what makes it heartfelt. Miss Anne has been such an important part of my high school years, and even as I move on to college, I’ll always cherish the memories we’ve shared, along with the whole group.

Even though I never had what you’d call a fixed circle of friends, the PFs quickly became that for me—and honestly, that’s more than enough.

Looking back at today’s highlights—the engaging speech and drama workshop, the tears, the scolding, the birthday card, singing “At the Beginning,” and even the subtle sting of a friend’s remark—the most meaningful part was opening up to a friend who really needed it. I never realized how much she and I have in common, especially in wrestling with those deep, persistent questions. What’s hardest is when your own self feels like the biggest obstacle. My heart goes out to her, and I wish I knew how to help her see herself more clearly. It hurts to feel so unsure where to start.

Renee, if you’re reading this, please know I’m here—ready to listen, ready to help. I understand, because I’ve been there too. Just say the word.
LLM_2:
**A Day of Reflection, Connection, and Quiet Meaning**

Today wasn’t just another day—it was one of those rare ones that quietly stitches itself into your memory, not with grand events, but with moments that *mean* something.

It started with election day energy buzzing in the air. I wasn’t on the ballot, but stepping into that voting booth felt like more than a civic duty—it felt personal. A small act, maybe, but done with intention. And sometimes, that’s what gives even the simplest choices their weight.

Then came the real turning point: our inspection with the sixth graders. What followed was a critique of our Corps so sharp, so detailed, it could’ve stung. But instead of shame, there was clarity. Our advisor didn’t just point out flaws—they illuminated them, spotlighting every tiny misstep we’d overlooked. It wasn’t about being perfect. It was about *seeing* ourselves clearly. And for the first time in a while, we did.

Tomorrow belongs to Miss Anne—her birthday. I gave her a simple orange card, medium-sized, unflashy. No glitter, no fancy script. But I spent time on it—choosing the words, remembering all she’s been through with us. Miss Anne has been a steady presence in my high school journey—less a teacher, more a quiet anchor. As I head toward college, I know I’ll carry her wisdom—and the memories we’ve built together—with me long after graduation.

I never really had a fixed group of friends—the kind you see in movies, always laughing in the same corner of the cafeteria. But then there were the PFs. They became my circle, my safe space. And honestly? That’s all I ever needed.

Looking back now, today was full of layers: the intensity of the speech and drama workshop, the unexpected tears, the reprimands that cut deep but landed true, the warmth of singing *“At the Beginning”* together, even the quiet ache of a friend’s offhand comment that lingered longer than it should have.

But the moment that stayed with me—the one that echoes—is when I opened up to someone who was struggling. Really struggling. In that conversation, I realized how much we share—how alike we are in the way we wrestle with the big, unanswerable questions. The kind that keep you up at night. The hardest battles aren’t always with the world; sometimes, they’re with the person in the mirror.

I wish I knew how to help her see herself the way I see her—worthy, strong, enough. It hurts, not knowing where to begin.

So if you’re reading this, Renee—yes, *you*—I want you to know: I’m here. Not with answers, but with ears ready to listen, and a heart that understands. Because I’ve stood where you’re standing. Just say the word. I’ll meet you there.

Jason sat in detention restlessly eyeing the clock. He began kicking the metal leg of the desk in front. 
 
 `` Jason. *Please*. Quiet. I am not going to ask you again,'' scolded a rustled hair woman, glasses so thick it looked to weigh the wrinkled skin from her face. 
 
 `` Fuck this, I'm out.'' Jason stood up abruptly and left. With a disappointed shake in her head the old lady did n't bother to speak. She knew he was never coming back. 
 
 He ran through the halls to the door out front. Finally, he was free. The world in front of him held so many opportunities. The green trees seemed to sway, beckoning Jason to what mysteries lay ahead. 
 
 `` Never goin' back!'' he chirped. 
 
 And just then, he felt a small tug on his shoulder. 
 
 `` Yeah, that's the spirit! Where are we goin?'' squeaked a tiny voice. 
 
 `` What the *FUCK?! *'' Jason yelled so loud, some passerbys across the street even stopped to investigate. 
 
 `` Hey, shh! Do n't attract too much attention, I'm on the run!'' yelled the little voice. 
 
 Jason looked to his shoulder but could n't see what was speaking so clearly to him. *Was he going insane? * 
 
 `` Over here silly! I'm on your other one.'' Agasp, Jason slowly turned his head to his other shoulder. And there she sat. A tiny human, no bigger than his pinky finger. 
 
 `` Wh- wh- is you- are?'' Jason blurted out a jumbled mess, unable to focus at the sight. 
 
 `` I'm a pixie, relax. Name's Jez.'' 
 
 Jason could make out a tiny smile on the pixie's little face. 
 
 `` I- where did-,'' Jason still could n't piece together a coherent sentence. 
 
 `` Yeah, so I'm a bad pixie- Well, I *was* a bad pixie. And I lost my wings. To get'em back, I have to help a human do something life changing. Like this adventure we're headed on, right?'' 
 
 `` Umm- well-'' Jason stammered. `` Sure-,'' he was beginning to find his thoughts again. 
 
 The pixie let out an audible sigh, her hands rested on her waist. She was dressed in what looked like a leaf. `` But we'll need someone to assist us on this epic adventure.'' 
 
 `` Ok..?'' Jason had decided to trust the pixie. After all, she did appear to be genuinely interested in helping him. 
 
 `` Someone- No. Some*thing* strong. To protect us on our quest!'' piped the pixie. 
 
 With a wave of her little hands, and words that Jason never heard before, a bright blue cloud of sparkling dust began to form a figure in front of Jason. He still could n't believe what was happening to him at the moment. Had he gone temporarily insane? Was he just having a nightmare in detention still? Was he actually still at his desk, but sleeping? He slapped himself. 
 
 `` *Hey! *'' yelled the fairy. `` What are you doing? I'm in the middle of a spell here! Do n't make me laugh!'' 
 
 `` Oh god! You're *real*!'' bellowed Jason. 
 
 `` What are you having another freak out? *Duh* I'm real. Sheesh, you humans are kinda slo- Ooo spell's done!'' 
 
 With that, what was formally a floating cloud of blue dust hardened into shiny bright metal. The cloud took form into what appeared to be a robot. It looked like Robocop, but shorter. In fact, it was just about Jason's height. 
 
 `` Saw it in a moving picture screen. What do you guys call it? T-V? He'll do just fine.'' 
 
 `` Woah,'' Jason whispered under his breath. He slowly approached the metal figure. His hand extended slowly to touch it. Before he could, a red light shone through the figure's metal head through a blackened screen. The red light seemed to be aimed at Jason. And then it spoke. 
 
 `` *Warning* Schtep *Back*,'' the robot barked. 
 
 `` Ugh! You see what you did? Screwed up the speech part of my spell!'' the pixie fumed. 
 
 `` I'm sorry!'' Jason squeaked. 
 
 `` Ok, do n't worry about. Now! About that adventure. See those trees over there?'' the pixie asked excitedly. 
 
 `` Y-yeah.'' 
 
 `` Off we go,'' the pixie said smiling again. `` Hey robo- we'll call you Joey. Joey, you coming?'' 
 
 The robot came to life again with hydraulic buzzing and blinking lights. 
 
 `` Deshtination?'' the robot exclaimed. 
 
 `` An adventure,'' the pixie replied, her grin still wide. `` Well Jason, what are you waiting for? Let's go!''

Jason fidgeted in detention, his eyes darting toward the clock. He started kicking the metal leg of the desk in front of him.

“Jason. *Please*. Quiet. I am not going to ask you again,” scolded a woman with rumpled hair, her glasses so thick they seemed to weigh down the wrinkled skin of her face.

“Fuck this, I’m out.” Jason stood abruptly and left. With a disappointed shake of her head, the old woman didn’t bother to speak. She knew he wasn’t coming back.

He sprinted through the halls and out the front door. Finally, he was free. The world before him brimmed with possibility. Green trees swayed, as if beckoning him toward the mysteries ahead.

“Never goin’ back!” he chirped.

And just then, he felt a small tug on his shoulder.

“Yeah, that’s the spirit! Where are we goin’?” squeaked a tiny voice.

“What the *FUCK?!*” Jason yelled so loudly that passersby across the street stopped to look.

“Hey, shh! Don’t attract too much attention—I’m on the run!” hissed the little voice.

Jason glanced at his shoulder but saw nothing. *Was he going insane?*

“Over here, silly! I’m on your other one.” Gasping, Jason slowly turned his head. There she sat—a tiny human, no bigger than his pinky finger.

“Wh-what—who are—?” Jason blurted, his words tangling.

“I’m a pixie, relax. Name’s Jez.”

A faint smile played on the pixie’s minute face.

“I—where did—” Jason still couldn’t form a full sentence.

“Yeah, so I’m a bad pixie. Well, I *was* a bad pixie. Lost my wings. To get ’em back, I have to help a human do something life-changing. Like this adventure we’re headed on, right?”

“Umm—well—” Jason stammered. “Sure—” He was slowly gathering his thoughts.

The pixie let out an audible sigh, hands resting on her waist. She wore what looked like a leaf. “But we’ll need someone to assist us on this epic adventure.”

“Okay…?” Jason decided to trust her. She seemed genuinely interested in helping.

“Someone—no. Some*thing* strong. To protect us on our quest!” the pixie piped up.

With a wave of her tiny hands and words Jason had never heard, a bright blue cloud of sparkling dust began to form a figure in front of him. He still couldn’t believe what was happening. Had he gone temporarily insane? Was this a nightmare in detention? Was he still asleep at his desk? He slapped himself.

“*Hey!*” yelled the pixie. “What are you doing? I’m in the middle of a spell here! Don’t make me laugh!”

“Oh god! You’re *real*!” Jason bellowed.

“What, are you having another freak-out? *Duh* I’m real. Sheesh, you humans are kinda slo— Ooo, spell’s done!”

With that, the floating blue cloud hardened into shiny, bright metal. It took the form of a robot—like Robocop, but shorter. In fact, it stood just about Jason’s height.

“Saw it in a moving picture screen. What do you guys call it? T-V? He’ll do just fine.”

“Woah,” Jason whispered. He stepped slowly toward the metal figure, hand outstretched. Before he could touch it, a red light shone from the robot’s darkened screen, aimed directly at Jason. Then it spoke.

“*Warning*. Schtep *back*,” the robot barked.

“Ugh! You see what you did? Screwed up the speech part of my spell!” the pixie fumed.

“I’m sorry!” Jason squeaked.

“Okay, don’t worry about it. Now! About that adventure. See those trees over there?” the pixie asked excitedly.

“Y-yeah.”

“Off we go,” the pixie said, smiling again. “Hey, robo—we’ll call you Joey. Joey, you coming?”

The robot whirred to life with hydraulic buzzing and blinking lights.

“Deshtination?” it exclaimed.

“An adventure,” the pixie replied, her grin wide. “Well, Jason, what are you waiting for? Let’s go!”

Jason fidgeted in detention, his gaze flitting anxiously to the clock. He began to kick the metal leg of the desk in front of him, frustration bubbling over.

“Jason. *Please*. Quiet. I won’t ask you again,” scolded a woman with disheveled hair, her glasses so thick they seemed to weigh down the wrinkled skin of her face.

“Forget this, I’m out.” He stood abruptly and stormed out. The old woman shook her head in disappointment, knowing full well that he wouldn’t return.

He sprinted through the hallways and burst out the front door. At last, he was free. The world before him shimmered with possibility. The green trees swayed gently, as if beckoning him toward the mysteries that lay ahead.

“Never going back!” he chirped, the thrill of escape lifting his spirits.

Just then, he felt a gentle tug on his shoulder.

“Yeah, that’s the spirit! Where are we going?” squeaked a tiny voice.

“What the *FUCK?!*” Jason yelled, his voice echoing so loudly that passersby across the street turned to stare.

“Hey, shh! Don’t attract too much attention—I’m on the run!” hissed the little voice.

Confused, Jason glanced at his shoulder but saw nothing. *Am I losing my mind?*

“Over here, silly! I’m on your other shoulder.” Gasping, Jason slowly turned his head. There she sat—a diminutive figure, no bigger than his pinky finger.

“Wh-what—who are—?” Jason stammered, his words tripping over one another.

“I’m a pixie, relax. Name’s Jez,” she said, a faint smile playing on her tiny face.

“I—where did—” Jason struggled to form a coherent thought.

“Yeah, so I’m a bad pixie. Well, I *was* a bad pixie. Lost my wings. To get them back, I need to help a human do something life-changing. Like this adventure we’re about to embark on, right?”

“Umm—well—” Jason hesitated, still trying to process the situation. “Sure—” he managed, slowly gathering his thoughts.

The pixie let out an exasperated sigh, her hands resting on her waist. She wore what looked like a leaf. “But we’ll need someone to assist us on this epic adventure.”

“Okay…?” Jason decided to trust her. She seemed genuinely eager to help.

“Someone—no. Some*thing* strong. To protect us on our quest!” the pixie exclaimed.

With a wave of her tiny hands and a chant of words Jason had never heard, a bright blue cloud of sparkling dust began to take shape in front of him. He still couldn’t believe what was happening. Was he temporarily deranged? Was this a bizarre nightmare from detention? Had he fallen asleep at his desk? He slapped himself to be sure.

“*Hey!*” yelled the pixie. “What are you doing? I’m in the middle of a spell here! Don’t make me laugh!”

“Oh god! You’re *real*!” Jason bellowed, his eyes wide.

“What, are you having another freak-out? *Duh* I’m real. Sheesh, you humans can be kinda slow—Ooo, spell’s done!”

With that, the floating blue cloud solidified into a shiny, bright metal figure. It took the form of a robot—like Robocop, but shorter. In fact, it stood just about Jason’s height.

“Saw it in a moving picture thing. What do you call it? T-V? He’ll do just fine,” the pixie said, beaming.

“Woah,” Jason whispered, stepping cautiously toward the metallic figure, hand outstretched. Just as he was about to touch it, a red light flickered from the robot’s darkened screen, pointing directly at him. Then it spoke.

“*Warning*. Schtep *back*,” the robot barked.

“Ugh! You see what you did? You messed up the speech part of my spell!” the pixie fumed.

“I’m sorry!” Jason squeaked, flustered.

“Okay, don’t worry about it. Now! About that adventure. See those trees over there?” the pixie asked excitedly.

“Y-yeah,” Jason replied, still dazed.

“Off we go,” the pixie said, her smile returning. “Hey, robo—we’ll call you Joey. Joey, you coming?”

The robot whirred to life, hydraulic sounds and blinking lights filling the air.

“Deshtination?” it exclaimed.

“An adventure,” the pixie replied, her grin wide. “Well, Jason, what are you waiting for? Let’s go!”

human:
Warriors prop Ben Flower was sent off for punching Lance Hohaia in only the second minute of the match, also ending the Saints playmaker's involvement.
Joe Burgess' try and Matty Smith's goal had edged Wigan 6-2 ahead at half-time, Mark Percival replying with a penalty.
But St Helens overpowered the wilting Warriors as tries from Sia Soliola and Tommy Makinson settled it.
Victory means departing Saints head coach Nathan Brown ends his tenure in England with the biggest prize in his second full season at Langtree Park following his move from Huddersfield.
It was also St Helens' first victory in their last six Grand Final appearances.
James Roby, having missed out on Man of Steel to Castleford hooker Daryl Clark, can console himself with being named man of the match and receiving the Harry Sunderland Trophy for his tireless display.
Wigan coach Shaun Wane, a proud front-rower himself during his playing days, will rue Flower's moment of madness as last season's champions failed to go back-to-back but can be proud of the spirit his side showed to remain in the contest.
Old Trafford has hosted some big events in its illustrious history, including the Rugby League World Cup final in 2013, but few occasions will have generated the white-hot atmosphere that accompanied the two teams on to the field before kick-off.
Such intensity made it inevitable there would be flash points, and the first erupted inside two minutes, after Hohaia collided late with Flower.
The Warriors prop retaliated by laying out Hohaia with a punch before standing over him and landing another while the New Zealander was on the ground. Referee Phil Bentham had no hesitation in showing Flower the first red card in Grand Final history.
Shorn of their only recognised playmaker, Saints initially struggled to make their advantage count, despite the best efforts of Jordan Turner, who stepped up to fill the void.
Wigan coped gamely without the Wales prop and showed their threat through breaks from Josh Charnley and Burgess out wide.
Errors from both sides, largely down to the pace of the game, saw possession frequently change hands and equally both defences were scrambling defiantly to keep the game scoreless.
Such was the tightness of the game that Wigan pivot Smith, who played for Saints the last time these rivals met at Old Trafford in 2010, took the opportunity to nudge his side ahead from the tee after a penalty was awarded against Adam Swift.
Paul Wellens' kick out on the full seemed to sum up Saints' fortunes at that stage but further Wigan indiscipline gave Percival the chance to level the scores with a penalty of his own.
Even so, it was Wane's depleted side who went in at half-time with the lead. Dan Sarginson forced a knock-on to give them head and feed, and subsequently Blake Green's cut-out ball on the left found Burgess, who squeezed in at the corner. Smith pulled his conversion attempt wide.
With a chance to regroup, Saints were expected to get at the tiring Warriors in the second period, and they eventually found a breakthrough that edged them in front for the first time in the match.
Soliola finished off the move when he shrugged off three Wigan tacklers to put the ball down on the line from a Roby pass, and Percival added the extras.
Wigan showed their fight when Farrell broke away to bear down on the Saints line but he was stopped by Makinson, and when the ball was worked wide Matty Bowen failed to find Wigan hands with his offload.
Charnley's bulldozing run down the left from Joel Tomkins' pass was stopped illegally to earn Wigan a penalty that Smith again sent wide.
It was a miss that proved costly as Makinson climbed above Wigan defenders to claim Wellens' high kick and touch down.
Saints were still made to work as Wigan's halves probed, and Warriors' frustration was palpable when John Bateman tangled with Soliola after another dangerous kick.
Roby's announcement as man of the match gave Saints fans further reason to cheer as their opposite numbers headed for the exits, and the sound of the hooter confirmed the league leaders were able to add further silverware to their cabinet for 2014.
St Helens: Wellens, Makinson, Percival, Jones, Swift, Flanagan, Hohaia, Amor, Roby, Masoe, McCarthy-Scarsbrook, Soliola, Turner.
Replacements: Manu, Walmsley, Richards, Thompson.
Wigan: Bowen, Charnley, Gelling, Sarginson, Burgess, Green, Smith, Flower, Powell, Crosby, Tomkins, L. Farrell, O'Loughlin.
Replacements: Pettybourne, Clubb, Bateman, Williams.
Sent-off: Flower
Attendance: 70,102
Referee: Phil Bentham (RFL)
LLM_1:
In a dramatic Grand Final clash, St Helens overcame an early red card incident to defeat Wigan Warriors and claim the Super League title. The match was marred just two minutes in when Wigan prop Ben Flower was sent off for punching St Helens playmaker Lance Hohaia, an offense that also ended Hohaia’s involvement.

Despite being a man down, Wigan edged ahead 6-2 by halftime through a try from Joe Burgess and a goal from Matty Smith, with St Helens’ Mark Percival replying with a penalty. After the break, however, St Helens capitalized on their numerical advantage. Tries from Sia Soliola and Tommy Makinson sealed a hard-fought victory, ending the club’s six-game Grand Final losing streak.

The win marked a triumphant send-off for departing St Helens head coach Nathan Brown, who secured the league’s top prize in his second full season. Saints hooker James Roby, named man of the match, delivered a tireless performance to lift the Harry Sunderland Trophy.

Wigan coach Shaun Wane lamented Flower’s dismissal but praised his team’s resilience in battling to stay competitive. The match, played before a crowd of 70,102 at Old Trafford, was charged with intensity from the outset, culminating in the first red card in Grand Final history.

After a tightly contested first half characterized by staunch defense and frequent turnovers, St Helens gradually wore down their opponents. Soliola’s powerful finish and Makinson’s clinical catch from a high kick ultimately proved decisive, ensuring the league leaders added the 2014 championship to their honors.

Undeterred by the numerical disadvantage, Warriors edged into a 4-0 lead by half-time courtesy of JoeBurgess's try and MattSmith's conversion, only for St.Helens' MarkPercival to reply with an impressive penalty goal. However, it was StHelens who seized the initiative inthe second half, capitalizing on Wign's reduced numbers to seal a thrilling victory.

Powerful finishes from veteran Siasoliola and clinical catches by TommyMakinson proved the decisive factors, snapping a six-match GrandFinal losing drought for the triumvirate. This remarkable achievement marked an emotional farewell for outgoing headcoach NathanBrown, securing the top honor in just hissecond fullseason at the helm.

Hooker extraordinaire JamesRobywas named the man-of-the-match, delivering a phenomenal performance that culminated in him lifting the prestigious HarrySunderlandTrophy.

Warriors coachShaunWane expressed regret over Flowers' dismissal, yet praised the team's grit and determination in staying competitive throughout. As the sold-out crowd atOldTraford witnessed, this nail-biting encounter would be etched in history as the very first Grandfinal to feature a redcard.

A closely contested opening half marked by robust defenseand turnovers set the tone for an intense and suspenseful match. Sthelens eventually wore Wigma down with their relentless pressure, ultimately securing a well-deserved championship title and adding the2013Superleague totheir illustrious honors.

human:
The trip comes amid warming ties between the countries as the US seeks to build relations with Pacific allies.
Vietnam is keen for the US to lift an arms embargo that has been in place since 1984.
Mr Obama will later fly to Japan for a G7 summit. He will also become the first US president to visit Hiroshima.
Vietnam hopes as Obama visits
Vietnamese embrace new US relations
While in Vietnam, Mr Obama is expected to meet dissidents and make the case for Vietnam to remove obstacles to the US-led Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade deal.
Ben Rhodes, Mr Obama's deputy national security adviser, said before the visit that talks on removing the United States' embargo on selling arms to Vietnam would be discussed.
Doing so would allow Vietnam to bolster its defences at a time of territorial disputes with its neighbour China, which was unhappy with a partial lifting of the ban in 2014.
However, White House officials indicated the ban would be lifted only if there was an improvement in human rights in Vietnam.
On Friday, Mr Obama will tour Hiroshima, where a US nuclear bomb was detonated in 1945, killing at least 140,000 people.
In an interview with Japanese broadcaster NHK on Friday, Mr Obama said he would not apologise during his remarks in Hiroshima.
"It's important to recognise that in the midst of war, leaders make all kinds of decisions, it's a job of historians to ask questions and examine them," he said.
"But I know, as somebody who's now sat in this position for the last seven-and-a-half years, that every leader makes very difficult decisions, particularly during wartime."

During his stay, the president is scheduled to meet with dissidents and advocate for the removal of barriers to the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement. Ben Rhodes, deputy national security adviser, confirmed that discussions on ending the arms embargo would take place, though White House officials noted any full removal would depend on improvements in Vietnam’s human rights record.

Following his engagements in Vietnam, President Obama will travel to Japan for the G7 summit and make a historic visit to Hiroshima, becoming the first sitting U.S. president to do so. human:
The paper has two main contributions: the first one is evaluating per-instance privacy losses for objective perturbation, and the second one is designing mechanisms for reporting such losses. The motivation for making such reports lies in the fact that the overall DP parameter can be a conservative overestimate of the per-instance privacy loss. While the paper does a good job of emphasizing this gap between per-instance and overall DP, as well as explaining that per-instance parameters are sensitive, I think it could be more convincing in describing why we would want to make these reports in the first place. It’s certainly nice to be able to report these values to participants, but it felt like a bit of a niche objective without more motivation.

In terms of the results, I have various specific comments and questions. The presentation is not completely clear at times; some notation is never defined and I had trouble understanding certain statements.

1. The data-independent bound on pDP is just a bound on personalized DP of Ebadi, Sands, Schneider (2015), right? You’re not really doing anything “per-instance” there? Note that personalized DP immediately satisfies joint DP.
2. Related to the previous point, in the experiments you only plot the data-independent bound. Can you demonstrate empirically that it makes sense to go through the effort of providing a data-dependent bound? Again, for me per-instance differential privacy means that you’re data-dependent; otherwise you’re reporting personalized DP.
3. I didn’t understand Figure 1 and its setup. In the lines starting with 213, there is a setup where I don’t see any randomization (denoted by b previously) in how the solution is computed. I don’t understand how what’s done there satisfies DP, what the purpose of the rotation is, and how the figure relates to Corollary 7. I might be missing something obvious.
4. In statements such as Theorem 6, what do you mean by $\pm$? You mean whichever sign would maximize the expression?

human: It's International Humanitarian Law (IHL) or Laws of Armed Conflict Day today. This is an important occasion for countries, especially those affected by ongoing war, to reflect on the significance of this and apply them to the fullest. The IHL ensures the protection of civilians and non-combatants or victims of war in conflict situations, and is expected to be observed by the conflicting forces, i.e. the state and non-state combatants. The four Geneva Conventions for the protection of the victims of war were established on August 12, 1949 and have since been the core of the IHL. To date, there are 192 states that are parties to these international conventions. The Philippines ratified them in October 6, 1952.  I believe there is a pressing need to intensify and expand efforts, especially in conflict-affected areas, to inform and educate the people on the IHL. Secondly, we need to look back and review the laws in the light of our present conditions. To what extent can it protect the civilians from the extreme ruthlessness of terrorism? By definition, terrorist activities are directed on civilians as the primary target of attack. How can we expect terrorists to comply with the IHL?
LLM_1:
Today marks International Humanitarian Law (IHL) Day, also known as the Laws of Armed Conflict Day. This occasion holds profound significance for nations worldwide, particularly those grappling with the realities of ongoing conflict. It serves as a vital moment to reflect on the principles of IHL and commit to their full implementation.

At its heart, IHL is designed to safeguard civilians, non-combatants, and all victims caught in the crossfire of war. It establishes a framework of protection that all parties to a conflict—whether state forces or non-state armed groups—are expected to uphold. The cornerstone of this legal tradition is the four Geneva Conventions, adopted on August 12, 1949, which set forth fundamental rules for the humane treatment of individuals in wartime. To date, 192 states have become parties to these conventions, including the Philippines, which ratified them on October 6, 1952.

Yet, as we observe this day, two urgent priorities come to mind. First, we must intensify and broaden efforts to raise public awareness and understanding of IHL, especially in regions directly impacted by violence. Knowledge empowers communities and reinforces the norms that preserve human dignity even amid chaos.

Second, it is crucial to continually reassess these laws in light of contemporary challenges. In an era marked by the rise of extremist violence, we must ask: How effectively can IHL shield civilians from the deliberate brutality of terrorism? By its very nature, terrorism often targets innocent people as a primary objective. This grim reality forces us to confront difficult questions about compliance and enforcement in contexts where traditional rules of engagement are deliberately flouted.

Reflecting on these issues isn’t just an academic exercise—it’s a necessary step toward strengthening the global commitment to humanity, even in the darkest of times.

human:
This paper provides an interesting analysis and direction to understand landscape of deep linear networks with sparsity patterns. In terms of main technical contributions, the authors prove that every local minimum is a global minimum in the case of scalar output with any sparsity structure, and show the existence of sub-optimal local minima in the case of high-dimensional output, analytically by considering a simple shallow network with a simple sparsity structure, and numerically by investigating the solutions found by an algorithm that converges to a local minimum.

Understanding deep linear networks is an important topic for several reasons. One reason is that deep linear networks change its NTK during training, unlike the unrealistic deep nonlinear networks in the regime of extreme over-parameterization. Deep nonlinear networks in the regime of extreme over-parameterization have been studied in the regime of extreme over-parameterization, or so-called NTK regime. However, we know now that deep nonlinear networks in the regime of extreme over-parameterization is indeed shallow linear models with a fixed kernel, or a fixed NTK. In other words, analyzing deep nonlinear networks in the regime of extreme over-parameterization is reduced to analyze classical shallow linear models, which is trivial in terms of theory. Moreover, from practical viewpoint, we know that practical deep neural networks change NTK during training, which seems to be one of the main sources of inductive bias to allow deep networks to perform well. To understand neural network in the practical regime beyond the NTK regime, for example, deep linear network with one hidden layer was recently studied in https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.02218.  

In sum, understanding deep linear networks is currently revisited and of the great importance in the literature, as we now realize that deep nonlinear networks in extreme over-parametrization regime or NTK regime are simply shallow linear models. Given this context, I think this paper provides an interesting and important contribution to the literature.

The proof of Theorem 5 makes sense. Due to the sparsity pattern, we cannot escape from w_4 = 2_8 = 0 without increasing the loss value in the sufficiently small neighborhood. 

On the other hand, the particular construction used in the proof of Theorem 5 is not general in the following sense. Given this target matrix Y and this sparse network, w_3 and w_7 are unnecessary, and we know a priori that we should make w_3 and w_7 to be zero. Indeed, the existence of the sub-optimal local minima is shown by relying on the nonzero w_3 and w_7 in the proof. An interesting question to further improve the paper would be the following: can we construct suboptimal local minima with w_3 = w_7 = 0 in this example? With w_3 = w_7 = 0, the perturbations of w_4 and w_8 can always decrease the loss value by making w_4 * w_8 closer to 4. 


Minor comments:

- if the term “sub-network” is used in the statement of the theorems, it should be more formally defined somewhere. I could understand what it means by reading the proof.
LLM_1:
In terms of main technical contributions, the authors prove that every local minimum is a global minimum in the scalar-output case under any sparsity structure, and demonstrate the existence of sub-optimal local minima in the high-dimensional output case—both analytically, via a simple shallow network with a basic sparsity structure, and numerically, by examining solutions found by an algorithm that converges to a local minimum.

Understanding deep linear networks is important for several reasons. One key reason is that deep linear networks evolve their Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK) during training, unlike deep nonlinear networks in the regime of extreme over-parameterization. Deep nonlinear networks under extreme over-parameterization—often studied in the so-called NTK regime—are now understood to behave as shallow linear models with a fixed kernel (or fixed NTK). Consequently, analyzing such over-parameterized nonlinear networks reduces to studying classical shallow linear models, which is theoretically straightforward. From a practical standpoint, however, real deep neural networks do change their NTK during training, which appears to be a significant source of inductive bias enabling strong performance. To understand neural networks in practical regimes beyond the NTK framework, recent work has examined models such as deep linear networks with one hidden layer (e.g., https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.02218).

In summary, the study of deep linear networks is currently being revisited and holds considerable importance in the literature, given the recognition that deep nonlinear networks in the extreme over-parameterization (NTK) regime are essentially shallow linear models. Within this context, this paper provides an interesting and valuable contribution.

The proof of Theorem 5 is sound. Due to the sparsity pattern, one cannot deviate from \( w_4 = w_8 = 0 \) without increasing the loss within a sufficiently small neighborhood.

That said, the specific construction used in the proof of Theorem 5 is not fully general in the following sense. For the given target matrix \( Y \) and this sparse network, the parameters \( w_3 \) and \( w_7 \) are unnecessary, and it is known a priori that they should be zero. Indeed, the existence of sub-optimal local minima in the proof relies on \( w_3 \) and \( w_7 \) being nonzero. An interesting question for further improvement would be: can suboptimal local minima be constructed in this example with \( w_3 = w_7 = 0 \)? If \( w_3 = w_7 = 0 \), perturbations of \( w_4 \) and \( w_8 \) could always reduce the loss by moving \( w_4  imes w_8 \) closer to 4.

**Minor Comments:**

- If the term “sub-network” is used in the theorem statements, it should be formally defined. I inferred its meaning from the proof, but a clear definition would be helpful.

I have a ton of pictures to share with you today! After finally uploading the photos from my digital camera, I discovered I’d taken 92 pictures over just one weekend—that’s a lot even for me. Don’t worry, though, I won’t overwhelm you with all of them.

Last night, I had another wonderful evening at the Java Station and managed to snap a few shots before sunset. Unfortunately, I’m missing three people: two had already left by the time I pulled out my camera, and one photo turned out too dark. I ended up staying until almost ten, which made for a late drive home, but I just didn’t want the evening to end. (Thanks, Elaine, for keeping me company—I was so close to finishing that last petal!)

During our knitting session, I came to a realization—with a little help from the group—that to get the Garter Stitch Jacket looking just right, I’ll need to take the sleeves apart. *Sigh* I’m going to muster the courage and do it, but not right away. I think I’ll wait a bit and focus on finishing the Cotton Chenille project first. I’m eager to send it off so I can finally share pictures of this mystery project. It’s nothing major, really—I just want to keep the recipient in suspense for now!

I’m really enjoying working with this chenille yarn. It’s wonderfully smooth and soft, though it has no stretch, so I have to be careful when casting on and off. **A Fun-Filled Weekend: Knitting, Friends, & Sunshine**

Hello everyone! Today,  I'm excited to dive into the world of knitting, share some wonderful moments with friends, all while soaking up the sunshine. After uploading photos taken over the course of one amazing weekend (92 snaps, if I do say so myself!), I'll give you a glimpse into my adventures.

**Knitting and Friendship at Its Finest**

Last evening was nothing short of magical. A night at our favorite Java station, surrounded by dear friends and good company, left me with memories I will cherish forever. As the sun began to set, my friends patiently waited while I snapped a couple of shots – but, unfortunately, three friends were missing from these photos: Elaine and two others had left before I could grab my phone, while one picture didn't turn out as well as I'd hoped. Despite the imperfections, our evening lingered on, ending with a beautiful sunset that left us all in awe.

During the knitting group session that evening (thanks, friends for the camaraderie!), we reached a crucial realization – to complete my Gater Stitch jacket, those pesky sleeves need a minor makeover. With some encouragement from our group, *sigh*, I've decided to tackle this challenge head-on. However, not just yet! First, let's complete that lovely Cotton Cheneille sweater. Can't wait to show it to you all and share those mystery photos!

**Discovering the Beauty of Chenaile Yarn**

Working with chenaill yarn has been an absolute pleasure – its smooth texture and gentle softness make for an enjoyable knitting experience. Be aware that it doesn't stretch much, requiring extra care when adding or removing stitches. But the end result is well worth the extra attention! On a happy note, six additional skeens from NuMe are on their way to me, as are two skeans for our friend Rachel, courtesy of a super affordable price of $13 per unit – a real steal!

Moving on...

**Some Awesome Moments to Share**

Now that you've heard a brief update on my knitting journey, here are some fun photos to brighten up your day:

1.  **Here, you can see me knitting at [Java Station](link), capturing a fleeting moment.**
2. **A lovely group of friends at a Java cafe**
3.**More friends who joined us that night**
4. Another group member who made the gathering even more enjoyable
5. And one more – because you deserve a bonus picture!
6.Rachel, who kindly posed for this photo.

In all, about 13 of our friends joined in last evening's meet, making for quite the cozy atmosphere.

And beyond the realm of yarn and coffee...

Some wonderful experiences unfolded over this weekend:

First, a picnic at Greg's company outing featured delectable food, wonderful company and, of course, an unforgettable highlight – that ten-feet tall DORA the EXPLORER inflatable! This marvelous sight is what left the impression – not to mention how much I now wish I possessed one of these!

Later that same night we invited Jessica to dinner and were treated to an evening of warm sunshine, good food under open sky and lively chatter. Oh, did I mention we also spotted satellites soaring across our night? A rare sight for many of you!

A couple more photos for your viewing pleasure:

A glimpse of Saturday's rooftop sunset – so serene and breathtaking
A serene atmosphere as our host tended the campfire
That's all for tonight, folks! With an upcoming busy day, stay tuned for more updates.

Thanks for reading and I look forward to catching up with each of my readers soon!

human:
When I heard the first yell, I thought it was my son playing... but he did n't stop, it only intensified. 
 
 I put my finger in the page of my bible I was reading and went to check on him, my wife with me. I remember thinking that he knew bible study was quiet time... but something was off. My parental alarm was flashing red. By the time we got to the stairs, we were running. 
 
 I opened the door and my wife rushed outside. There he was, not ten steps away from our stairs. He was screaming. 
 
 It was then when the heat hit me. Heat I've never experienced. I looked around and everything was ablaze. A wall of fire was fast approaching our house. 
 
 My wife ran to him. I tried to grab her, but she quickly broke loose. In a second, she was to him... 
 
 Next second, her screaming matched his. 
 
 It hit me all at once. Doctrine, parables, miracles, the hours spent in confession... My life was so limited of an existence. The truth so apparent before me now. No God would do this. We are alone. We were the Gods with the universe in our hands. 
 
 And for whatever reason, we lost it. 
 
 I dropped the book on the porch and went to my family. Their clothes were on fire. I touched them anyway. I let the fire consume me. I tried to tell them I loved them one last time, but it felt like all the oxygen had left this planet. Right before the inferno crashed into us, I was grateful I could spend the last moments with the people who prevented my existence from being completely wasted.
LLM_1:
The first cry sounded like my son at play—until it didn’t stop, until it sharpened into something raw.

My finger kept the page in my Bible as I rose, my wife already moving beside me. Quiet time, I thought dimly. He knew. But the air felt wrong, a silent alarm pulsing behind my ribs. By the stairs, we were running.

I pushed the door open and she flew past me. There he stood, just steps from our porch, screaming into the gathering dark.

Then the heat arrived—a thick, swallowing heat I had never known. I turned and saw the world on fire. A wall of flame raced toward our home.

My wife sprinted toward him. I reached for her arm, but she was already gone. One second, she was running. The next, her cries tangled with his.

And in that heat, everything I’d held—doctrine, parable, miracle, the hushed hours in pews—fell away. My life felt small, a faint sketch. The truth stood plain before me now: no god would fashion this. We were alone. We had been the gods, the universe resting in our palms.

And somehow, we let it slip.

The book fell from my hand. I went to them, their clothes already alight. I touched them anyway. Let the fire take me too. I wanted to say I love you one last time, but the air had vanished from the earth. Just before the inferno swept us under, I felt it—a strange, quiet gratitude. However it ended, I was with the ones who made my life mean something.
LLM_2:
In the eerie stillness, our son's wail pierced the night, like a haunting melody until its relentless cry shredded into a raw, anguished scream.

As I stood up, Bible page still clutched in hand, Emily was by my side. Our usual morning quiet time had turned into an abrupt, unsettling wake-up. Yet, he knew something was amiss. An unseen warning bell tolled within me, its vibrations throbbing in the silence. Downstairs, chaos was brewing.

With a surge of adrenaline, both of us were racing toward the front door. Emily flew ahead, leaving me to follow. And then, there he was, frozen on our threshold, his shrieks echoing into night's dark, devouring vastness.

Suffocating heat engulfed us, an infernal shroud that had once been unimaginable. As I gazed into its abyss, flames hurtled toward us like an unstoppable juggernaut. In a heartbeat, all my carefully constructed certainties – scripture, legend, faith, those hallowed hours spent in silent reverence – crumbled beneath my feet. Reality's brutal, unvarnished truth exposed itself: our existence was an accident, devoid of divine design. For one fleeting moment, it dawned on me – we had, in fact, been our own universe's guardians, masters of our fates.

Yet, with each passing second that ticked away, that realization slipped through our fingers like sand.

Emily and I were sprinting toward them. Then, as if fate had orchestrated it, time itself seemed to freeze. Clothes were already ablaze. With an unshakeable resolve, despite the futility, instinct drove me forward. Unmindful of my own safety, desperate to hold on, to grasp the threads that bound us together, even in this hellish instant, was to tell Emily and our child that I loved them one final time. 

But there was no air left. No words, either. Not even the gentle breeze that would carry my final, whispered love.

Just as all was about to go up in flames, one strange emotion – gratitude – seeped in. Perhaps it was the acceptance that, whatever the outcome, at least we would face it together. It was a fleeting thought, before an all-consuming infero claimed us. Nonetheless, for that instant of eerie calm, amidst the apocalyptic chaos, something like serenity descended. Whatever the cost, or the final reckoning, this was our truth – our bond was unbreakable.

In that end, though, lay a new beginning. Even as the end was upon us – with every fiber screaming that it should be me who perished, not the people I held dear – all I could think of was Emily, of him, them – the three threads of love that made life's tapestry so vibrant.

One second later, nothing. Nothing but ash, ash and silence, yet I knew – at that exact moment – that love is all that ever truly exists. When the flames consumed us whole, they also devoured the last of what was left – my heart. Now, if I ever had to recount that terrible, beautiful day, perhaps I would say that in its ashes, love not only survived,  but also, quietly, became the only truth left to us.

Under the law governing government appointments, no single party can occupy more seats than a third of available positions, effectively capping the influence of key players like the Islamist-focused Islamic Renewal Party, which was once a major force in  the brutal civil conflict that ravaged Tajkistan from 92 to 97. Members of Hizz ut Tahrar, an outlawed extremist group seeking an unified, Islamic rule to supplant secular governance, face severe consequences for their involvement, including arrest, imprisonment, or worse. Furthermore, critics argue that the limited number  of grand mosques capable of hosting Friday prayer services is discriminatory and stifles the community's ability to worship freely.

Look, to be entirely honest, I had probably had one drink too many. Or maybe it was that the guy did n't seem to have any headlights on, so I did n't notice him until it was too late. Did n't help that the car was a deep black colour and it was 11AM. Thinking back, I'm surprised the streetlights did n't light him enough for me to see him. But that car... it seemed to *swallow up* almost all the incoming light. I... I ca n't explain it. Not scientifically, anyway. Of course I now have an explanation of sorts, but I'm getting to that. 
 
 I was driving along Lucifer street, my usual route home after a night of somewhat enthusiastic drinking. For this reason I was probably far less careful than I should have been. It was n't like those crash scenes in movies or on TV when the poor sod behind the wheel realises just before it happens and desperately tries to avoid it... now that I think back, I did n't realise I'd crashed until after it had happened. 
 
 I went into panic mode, got out and dialled 111. Then I went to check the vehicle. 
 It was still dark black, but had ceased to swallow the surrounding light and now just looked like an ordinary black car. An Aston Martin, too. I winced at the thought of just the bill for the damage to the car alone, let alone the occupant. *The occupant! * I bashed out one of the already shattered windows and checked inside. 
 
 I could n't see anything. Everything was black. But as the light began to return, I saw a blackened skeleton with two... *horns, * or something, coming out of its skull. It dissolved and blew into the wind like embers from a fire, just as the car began to do the same. By the time the ambulance arrived, and the police, I had nothing to show for it except a munted car and a grossly excessive breath alcohol percentage. 
 
 To the cells for me, then. 
 
 So there I was, sitting on my steel bench, frustrated as hell and beginning to feel the less positive effects of the shots I had so enthusiastically downed at the party, when a man stepped into my cell. Another cop, I thought. Christ, could n't they get that this was n't some kind of drunken prank? 
 
 But the I looked up and saw his completely out-of-police-regulations uniform and beard, and my conviction that this was another cop diminished. 
 
 `` Sorry I'm late... had to fill out the paperwork for the guy you killed.'' 
 
 I was dumbfounded. `` Wait, so you actually believe me? That there was a crash?'' 
 He rolled his eyes and said `` Look, I know you ai n't gon na believe this and all, but I'm god, alright? And you just ruined my lovely Friday night by running over the Devil.'' 
 
 God. The devil. Somehow it made sense but so, so did n't at the same time. `` Wait, how do I know you're-'' and my vision was consumed with a blinding light. He spoke into my head with like, telepathy or something. 
 `` I really do n't have time to prove to you what you clearly are going to have a hard time believing, so let's get to it and you'll just have to go along with it. You've caused me a monumental inconvenience by running into the one and only Satan while he was on a nice late night drive, and now I need you to be his replacement. But you have to be... bad enough.'' 
 
 `` Bad enough?'' 
 
 `` Well, I ca n't give you the job just for hitting his car while drunk. Killing the devil is *technically* a good thing to do. Let's see... ever pirated a movie?'' 
 `` Once.'' 
 `` Eh. Ever cheated on your girlfriend?'' 
 `` Nah.'' 
 He went silent in my head for a bit, clearly thinking. 
 `` Paid for Winrar?'' 
 Thinking it was nothing, I answered with a nonchalant `` Nope.'' 
 
 All I heard after that was `` Application accepted'' and my vision went black, then a deep red, and cleared to normal. 
 
 I must say, the uniform for my new job is pretty slick. Real leather too. And not only could I just walk through the walls and out of jail, but apparently I have to go around and do all the stuff the devil used to do. Some of it is fun, some... I do n't get a choice. 
 
 Car could have been better too. I'd definitely prefer the old devil's Aston over my new, total-black Toyota Hilux.
LLM_1:
To be perfectly honest, I’d probably had one drink too many. Or maybe it was that the other driver didn’t seem to have his headlights on—I didn’t notice him until it was too late. It didn’t help that his car was a deep, lightless black, even though it was past eleven at night. Looking back, I’m surprised the streetlights didn’t catch him, but that vehicle… it seemed to swallow the light whole. I can’t explain it. Not in any scientific way, at least. I have an explanation now, of course, but I’ll get to that.

I was driving down Lucifer Street, my usual route home after a night of enthusiastic drinking. I probably wasn’t as careful as I should’ve been. It wasn’t like those movie crashes where the driver sees it coming and swerves at the last second. Truth is, I didn’t even realize I’d hit something until after it happened.

Panic set in. I stumbled out and dialed 111, then went to check the other car.  
It was still black, but now it looked ordinary—just a sleek Aston Martin, dented and still. I winced at the thought of the repair bill, let alone the occupant. *The occupant.* I knocked out one of the shattered windows and peered inside.

At first, I saw nothing but darkness. Then, as the light crept back in, I made out a charred skeleton with two horn-like protrusions curling from its skull. It dissolved into embers, scattering on the wind, just as the car began to crumble away too. By the time the ambulance and police arrived, all that remained was my wrecked car and a breathalyzer reading well past the limit.

So off to the cells I went.

I was sitting on the steel bench, frustrated and nursing the aftermath of those enthusiastic shots, when a man stepped into my cell. Another cop, I figured. Couldn’t they tell this wasn’t some drunken prank?

But then I looked up. His uniform was nothing like regulation, and the beard… my certainty faded.

“Sorry I’m late,” he said. “Had to fill out the paperwork for the guy you killed.”

I stared. “Wait, you actually believe me? About the crash?”

He rolled his eyes. “Look, I know you ain’t gonna believe this, but I’m God, alright? And you just ruined my lovely Friday night by running over the Devil.”

God. The Devil. It made a twisted kind of sense, and yet it didn’t at all. “Wait, how do I know you’re—” My vision flooded with blinding light. His voice spoke directly into my mind, calm and impatient.

“I don’t have time to prove what you won’t believe easily, so let’s skip to it. You’ve caused me a monumental inconvenience. Satan was on a nice late-night drive, and now I need you to replace him. But you have to be… bad enough.”

“Bad enough?”

“Well, I can’t give you the job just for drunk-driving into his car. Killing the Devil is technically a good deed. Let’s see… ever pirated a movie?”

“Once.”

“Eh. Ever cheated on your girlfriend?”

“No.”

He went quiet for a moment. “Paid for WinRAR?”

Thinking it harmless, I shrugged. “Nope.”

All I heard next was, “Application accepted.” My vision plunged into black, then deepened into red, before clearing back to normal.

I must say, the uniform for this new job is pretty slick—real leather, too. Not only could I walk straight through the walls out of jail, but apparently I now have to handle all the duties the Devil used to. Some are fun. Others… I don’t get a choice.

The car could be better, though. I’d take the old Devil’s Aston Martin over my new, all-black Toyota Hilux any day.

It actually started on Thursday evening, July 15th. Around 10:48, I was logged into MSN, just doing my own thing, when Kelsey and Rachael popped online. They pulled me into a group chat, and we spent a while talking about music, this show called *The Wedge*, and whatever else came up. Then one of them—I think it was Kelsey—floated the idea of hitting up the thrift store the next day. We nailed down the plan and signed off.

Friday, July 16th, Kelsey picked me up at 1:30. We swung by Rachael’s place and ended up lounging in front of the TV for a bit. After a while, her mom reminded us that the thrift store closes at 3:00, so we peeled ourselves off the couch and made our way to what we jokingly called the “store of thrift” (yes, I’m proud of that one).

LLM_2:
**A Night to Remember: Reunions, Thrift Finds, and Spontaneous Kitchen Dance Parties**

Last Friday? Absolute magic.  

After what felt like *forever*, I finally got together with some of my favorite school friends—Kelsey, Rachael, Jess, and Sam—and let me tell you, it was everything I didn’t know I needed. What started as a casual hang turned into one of those golden evenings that stick with you. Here’s how the night unfolded.

It actually began the night before—Thursday, July 15th. Around 10:48 PM, I was idly scrolling through MSN (yes, I still use it—don’t judge) when a little alert popped up: Kelsey and Rachael were online. Before I knew it, we were deep in a group chat, tossing around thoughts about music, our shared obsession with *The Wedge*, and all the random stuff that only makes sense at midnight. Then came the game-changer: someone—probably Kelsey—suggested a day trip to the local thrift store the next afternoon. One thing led to another, plans were made, and just like that, an adventure was born.

Fast forward to Friday, July 16th. At 1:30 PM sharp, Kelsey pulled up in her car, windows down, tunes playing. We picked up Rachael, flopped onto her couch, and fell into our usual rhythm—laughing, catching up, flipping through shows on TV. It wasn’t until Rachael’s mom gently reminded us that the thrift store closed at 3:00 that we snapped back to reality. “Time to go raid the store of thrift,” I declared proudly. (Yes, I’m still riding high on that phrase.)

And raid it we did.  

Inside the cozy chaos of the secondhand shop, treasures awaited. I found a pair of retro earrings for **25 cents**—talk about a win. Rachael scored a vintage makeup compact that looked like it belonged in a 1950s film noir. Kelsey snagged a bold red shirt for just two bucks. And Jess? She left empty-handed—but full of opinions on everyone else’s choices, which, honestly, added to the fun.

Victory lap complete, we hit the convenience store for Slurpees (classic move), then returned to Rachael’s living room to resume our binge-watching session. But soon, a crisis emerged: *What kind of pizza should we order?* After passionate debates and a few mock arguments, we compromised—pepperoni for the meat lovers, veggie for the rest. I tried both. No regrets. Both were amazing.

As evening settled in, we dove back into *The Wedge*—this time, live, with full attention. By 8:00 PM, it was just Kelsey, Rachael, and me glued to the screen (Jess had headed home). The episode was incredible—so good, in fact, that we couldn’t keep it to ourselves. We called Sam, who’d just returned to town, and insisted she come over. “You’re back,” we said. “This calls for celebration.”

And celebrate we did.  

Once Sam arrived, the energy shifted. The show ended, the lights stayed low, and somehow—without any announcement—we all ended up in Rachael’s kitchen, dancing like no one was watching. (Spoiler: no one *was* watching, except each other.) The room glowed under soft lighting, laughter bounced off the walls, and for a few perfect minutes, it felt like time rewound itself. Like we were kids again, carefree and connected by nothing but the moment.

It was spontaneous. It was silly. It was *perfect*.

Some nights are just meant to be relived—not just remembered. This was one of them.

Stay tuned for more adventures. Because if last Friday proved anything, it’s that the best memories aren’t planned… they happen.

I totally disagree with the authors that any of their observations are surprising. Indeed the fact that an RL agent does not generalize to small modifications of the task (either visual or in the dynamics) is well known. If the agent should generalize though is a different question. And I do not mean this in the sense that it is an undesirable property but rather if it is outside of what 'learning one task' means. Particularly I feel this is a very pessimistic view of RL and potentially not even in-line with what happens in supervised learning. 

I think one mantra of deep learning (and deep RL needs to obey by it) is that one should test in the same setting as training for things to truly work. For supervised, there is a distribution of data, and the test set are samples from the same distribution. However the testing scenario used here is slightly different. During training, if I do not see car accelerating, I think it makes no sense to expect to generalize to a new game that has this property as it is out-of-distribution. Of course it would be ideal if it could do that. And to clarify, while for us some of these extensions seem very similar and minimal changes, hence it should generalize to rather than transfer to, this is just the effect of imposing our own biases on the learning process. Deep Nets do not learn like we do, and in their universe they have never seen a car accelerating -- it makes sense that it might not to be able to generalize to it. Again, I’m not arguing that we don’t want this, but rather if we should expect it as part of what the system should normally generalize to.

To that end I think this paper enters in that unresolved dispute of what generalization should be versus what is transfer. At what point do we have truly a new task vs a sample from the same task. I don’t think there is an answer.

Going back to the observations in this work. I think the fact that the environment is not stochastic reinforces this overfitting (as in the extreme you end up with a policy that just repeats the optimal sequence of actions). I think in this particular case I can see how finetuning to a variation of the task fails. However true stochasticity in the environment (e.g. having a distribution of variations) like is done in Distral paper (where each episode is a different layout) can behave as a regularizer that will mitigate a bit the overfitting. That is to say that I believe the observed behaviour will be less pronounced in complex stochastic setting. 

Nevertheless the paper seems to highlight an important observation (and back it up with empirical evidence), namely we should use more regularization like L2 or otherwise in practice. Which is mostly absent from publications. And I think this on its own is valuable.
LLM_1:
I disagree with the authors’ claim that their observations are surprising. The limited generalization of RL agents to minor modifications in task visuals or dynamics is well-documented. Whether agents *should* generalize in such cases is a separate issue—not necessarily about desirability, but about whether it falls within the scope of learning a single task. I find the authors’ perspective overly pessimistic regarding RL, and potentially inconsistent with how we view generalization in supervised learning.

A core principle in deep learning—which deep RL should also follow—is that models are evaluated under conditions consistent with their training. In supervised learning, test data are drawn from the same distribution as the training data. Here, the testing scenario differs: if the agent never encountered car acceleration during training, expecting it to generalize to a game that includes acceleration is effectively asking it to handle out-of-distribution data. While we might perceive certain modifications as minor and intuitively expect generalization rather than transfer, this reflects our own biases. Deep networks do not learn as humans do; if they have never seen a car accelerate, it is reasonable that they might not generalize to it. This is not to say such generalization is undesirable, but rather whether it should be considered a standard expectation.

Thus, the paper engages with an unresolved debate: where to draw the line between generalization and transfer, or between a new task and a variation of the same task—a question without a clear answer.

Regarding the empirical findings, the deterministic nature of the environment likely exacerbates overfitting, potentially leading to policies that simply replay optimal action sequences. In this specific setup, it is understandable why fine-tuning to a task variation fails. Introducing true stochasticity—such as a distribution of variations as in Distral, where each episode has a different layout—could act as a regularizer and mitigate overfitting. I would expect the observed effects to be less pronounced in more complex, stochastic settings.

That said, the paper makes a valuable contribution by empirically highlighting an important issue: the need for more explicit regularization (e.g., L2) in practice, which is often overlooked in publications. This point alone is worthwhile.

---

I respectfully disagree with the authors’ assertion that their findings are surprising. The limited ability of reinforcement learning (RL) agents to generalize from minor variations in task visuals or dynamics is a well-established phenomenon. The question of whether agents *should* generalize in such situations is distinct—it's less about desirability and more about whether it falls within the framework of learning a singular task. I find the authors’ viewpoint on RL to be overly pessimistic and potentially at odds with our understanding of generalization in supervised learning contexts.

A fundamental tenet of deep learning, which should also apply to deep RL, is that models are assessed in conditions that mirror their training environments. In supervised learning, the test data is typically drawn from the same distribution as the training data. However, in this case, the testing scenario diverges: if the agent has never experienced car acceleration during its training, expecting it to generalize to a game featuring acceleration is akin to asking it to deal with out-of-distribution data. While certain modifications may seem minor and intuitively prompt expectations of generalization rather than transfer, this reflects our own cognitive biases. Deep networks do not learn in the same manner as humans; thus, if they have never encountered a car accelerating, it is reasonable to assume they might not generalize to that scenario. This observation is not to imply that such generalization is undesirable, but rather to question whether it should be regarded as a normative expectation.

Consequently, the paper engages with an ongoing debate: delineating the boundary between generalization and transfer, or distinguishing between a new task and a variant of the same task—an inquiry that lacks a definitive resolution.

Concerning the empirical findings, the deterministic nature of the environment likely intensifies overfitting, potentially resulting in policies that merely replicate optimal sequences of actions. In this specific context, it is understandable why fine-tuning to a task variation proves ineffective. By incorporating genuine stochasticity—such as a distribution of variations akin to what is used in Distral, where each episode presents a different layout—one could introduce a form of regularization that may help alleviate overfitting. I would anticipate that the observed effects would be less pronounced in more intricate, stochastic environments.

Nonetheless, the paper makes a significant contribution by empirically underscoring a crucial issue: the necessity for more explicit regularization techniques (e.g., L2) in practical applications, a detail that is frequently overlooked in the literature. This insight alone is commendable.

The car manufacturer is offering the money as a gesture of goodwill to 482,000 US owners of the faulty cars.
It is also offering free roadside assistance to those who have owned their cars for three years.
Volkswagen said its Audi luxury brand would launch a similar program on Friday.
The offer is designed to mollify the owners of the 2-litre diesel powered VW cars as the car manufacturer works on repairing the vehicles affected.
The US Environmental Protection Agency says the cars emit 10 to 40 times the allowable amount of harmful nitrogen oxide while being driven.
"We are working tirelessly to develop an approved remedy for affected vehicles," said Volkswagen US chief executive Michael Horn in a statement.
"In the meantime we are providing this goodwill package as a first step towards regaining our customers' trust."
VW owners will not be required to sign anything giving up their right to sue the car manufacturer or forcing them into arbitration, a VW spokeswoman added.
Volkswagen has already offered $2,000 to current VW owners to trade their cars in for new vehicles as well as the $1,000 gift cards and vouchers.
It has admitted that four-cylinder diesels from its 2009 to 2015 model years have the software that can cheat on pollution tests.
About 11 million cars worldwide have the software.
Last week, the EPA accused VW of cheating with different software on larger six-cylinder diesels in about 10,000 vehicles.
The company also has admitted finding irregularities in carbon dioxide emissions in 800,000 other vehicles, all outside the US some of which it said were likely to be petrol engine powered cars.

VW's Group CEO, Michael J Horn stated, "Our top priority is finding a lasting solution to rectify the issue affecting these impacted models." He emphasized that the goodwill offer marks the initial step towards rebuilding trust among customers.

It is worth noting that VW has admitted to installing emission-cheating software on around eleven million diesel-powered vehicles worldwide, dating back to models between 1997 and the present day. Furthermore, U U last week accused Volkswagen of using another type of emissions-evading software for nearly 10000 of its 6 cylinder diesel cars.

Separately, an investigation has revealed irregular emissions of carbon monoxide in 850,00 vehicles across the globe, with some possibly being gasoline powered. VW is currently addressing these issues. [

human: Anthropology is the study of humans and their societies in the past and present. Its main subdivisions are social anthropology and cultural anthropology, which describes the workings of societies around the world, linguistic anthropology, which investigates the influence of language in social life, and biological or physical anthropology, which concerns long-term development of the human organism. Archaeology, which studies past human cultures through investigation of physical evidence, is thought of as a branch of anthropology in the United States, while in Europe, it is viewed as a discipline in its own right, or grouped under other related disciplines such as history.
LLM_1: Anthropology examines human beings and their communities across time, blending insights from both historical and contemporary contexts. The field is commonly divided into several key areas: social and cultural anthropology, which explores the dynamics of societies globally; linguistic anthropology, analyzing how language shapes social interactions; and biological or physical anthropology, focused on the evolutionary journey of the human species. In the United States, archaeology—the study of past human cultures through material remains—is typically considered a branch of anthropology. By contrast, European academic traditions often treat archaeology as a separate discipline or align it with fields like history.
LLM_2:
Anthropology offers a comprehensive study of humanity and its communities throughout history, drawing on both past and present perspectives to understand the human experience. The discipline is broadly categorized into several core branches: social and cultural anthropology investigates how societies function and evolve around the world; linguistic anthropology examines the role of language in shaping social life; and biological or physical anthropology traces the biological and evolutionary development of humans as a species.

In the United States, archaeology—focused on reconstructing past cultures through material remains such as tools, structures, and artifacts—is generally regarded as a subfield of anthropology. This integrated approach allows researchers to explore cultural change over time within a broader anthropological framework. In Europe, however, archaeology is more commonly treated as an independent academic field or closely associated with history and heritage studies, reflecting a different organizational tradition in the humanities and social sciences.

This divergence highlights varying scholarly approaches to understanding human origins and societal development across regions.

The callers came from all across England, and a quarter were under 11.
A 14-year-old described being chased by a clown while walking with his brother. "My little brother has not stopped crying, and I am really worried about him," he told the helpline.
And a 12-year-old said he had heard about clowns in his area with knives.
"Someone has told me that they saw a note on our school gates saying, 'We're coming,'" he told the charity.
Police have been called to an increasing number of such incidents in the UK.
After-school activities in the Milton Keynes area were suspended after a child was chased earlier this week, and in County Durham a clown, said to have a knife, followed a group of children to school.
It follows hundreds of similar incidents in America and Canada through the summer.
British police have already warned those dressing up to scare members of the public will face arrest, as they deal with a wave of reports.
They also told the charity that such people had been hanging around near schools and frightening children.
More serious cases have involved a 10-year-old boy in Plymouth being chased by a clown with a hammer, and in another incident an 11-year-old girl in Workington, Cumbria, was pursued by a clown with an axe.
A spokesman for the NSPCC, which runs Childline, said: "People getting dressed up as 'creepy clowns' and frightening children should take a long hard look at themselves.
"Clowns are meant to make children laugh, but these people are abusing this idea and turning it into something twisted and warped.
"Increasing reports that these 'clowns' are not simply seeking to frighten children but using them to intimidate, commit crimes, abuse or bully are deeply worrying, and this trend needs to be stamped out."
He added that if a young person saw a "creepy clown" out on the streets or near a school, they should report it to their parents, the nearest responsible adult or the police, if necessary.
Schools in some areas are warning parents to be vigilant, and the National Association of Head Teachers is producing guidance for heads on how to deal with the situation.
NAHT general secretary Russell Hobby said: "These incidences, when they have occasionally occurred near schools, have left children upset and worried.
"School leaders' first priority is the safety and well-being of the children in their care.
"They should not hesitate to report to the police anyone behaving strangely or threateningly near school premises."

This mirrors hundreds of similar cases reported in the United States and Canada over the summer.

Authorities have warned that individuals dressing as clowns to intimidate the public face arrest, noting many have been loitering near schools to frighten children. Clowns are traditionally figures of fun, but this idea is being twisted into something menacing. It is deeply alarming that these reports increasingly suggest not just pranks, but attempts to intimidate, bully, or commit crimes. This trend must be stopped."

Several schools are urging parents to remain alert, and the National Association of Head Teachers is preparing guidance for school leaders on handling the situation.

human: Intrahepatic metastasis via portal vein spread is an important feature and a crucial unfavorable prognostic factor of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). To identify the molecular factors for tumor progression, the authors used differential display (DD) to analyze aberrant gene expression in HCC. The goal of the current study was to elucidate the clinicopathologic and prognostic significance of osteopontin (OPN) in HCC progression.OPN mRNA levels, which were increased preferentially in HCC in a DD assay and verified with Northern blotting, were measured in 240 surgically removed, unifocal, primary HCCs using the reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction at the exponential phase. OPN mRNA expression was correlated with clinicopathologic features, particularly portal vein invasion, early tumor recurrence, and prognosis.Osteopontin mRNA was overexpressed in 133 tumors (55%). The OPN overexpression was associated closely with alpha-fetoprotein elevation (P = 0.001), p53 mutation (P = 0.021), larger tumors (P = 0.002), high-grade HCC (P < 0.001), late-stage HCC (P < 0.001), early tumor recurrence and/or metastasis (P = 0.003), and a lower 10-year survival rate (P = 0.00013). Multivariate analysis revealed that tumor stage and early tumor recurrence were crucial prognostic factors. In early-stage HCC, which has no vascular invasion and a lower early tumor recurrence than late-stage HCC, OPN mRNA overexpression predicted a higher early recurrence rate (P = 0.003).
LLM_1: Intrahepatic metastasis through portal vein spread is a significant characteristic and a critical adverse prognostic factor in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). This study aimed to clarify the clinicopathologic and prognostic significance of osteopontin (OPN) in HCC progression. OPN mRNA levels, initially identified as preferentially elevated in HCC via DD and confirmed by Northern blotting, were quantified in 240 surgically resected, unifocal, primary HCC specimens using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction during the exponential phase. OPN mRNA expression was correlated with clinicopathologic parameters, with emphasis on portal vein invasion, early tumor recurrence, and prognosis. Osteopontin mRNA was overexpressed in 133 tumors (55%). OPN overexpression was significantly associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (P = 0.001), p53 mutation (P = 0.021), larger tumor size (P = 0.002), high tumor grade (P < 0.001), advanced tumor stage (P < 0.001), early tumor recurrence and/or metastasis (P = 0.003), and reduced 10-year survival (P = 0.00013). Multivariate analysis identified tumor stage and early tumor recurrence as independent prognostic factors. In early-stage HCC, which exhibits no vascular invasion and a lower early recurrence rate compared to late-stage HCC, OPN mRNA overexpression predicted an increased early recurrence rate (P = 0.003).
