!!!!!!!!!!  
EIJIIII IS SO CUTE!!!  
(Sorry, HS—I know you hate when I gush like this, but I can’t help it. Haha.)

Anyway, today was *packed*. First up: Social Studies SBQ test. Are they serious?! An 11-mark question in *10 minutes*? Do they think we’re superheroes with super-speed reading powers? Insane.

Then came the A-Maths test—hopefully I didn’t bomb it too badly. After school, I stayed back for oral practice with Wee. Surprisingly, she seemed impressed? I don’t know what to say… maybe I’m finally improving. Haha.

Next, I sat through Wee’s English lesson—which honestly felt like a waste of time. Teng Lui won the “Most Efficient Student” award by copying all the answers *before* handing in the answer key. Legend. (Also, slightly terrifying.)

After that, Pinky, Jiahao, Teng Lui, and I headed to TM and CS just to walk around and decompress before going home. Sometimes, aimless strolls with friends are exactly what you need after a chaotic day.

And now? I’m ready to collapse. What a week.

---

Back again after such a long break, and already I’m reminded why I love writing these little updates. It’s messy, it’s real, and it’s mine.

Hope your week was kinder than mine. Talk soon.

— 💤

human: To estimate the effect of dairy intake in early childhood on the acquisition of body fat throughout childhood.Ninety-nine of the original 106 families enrolled in the Framingham Children's Study with a child age to 6 years at baseline were followed into adolescence through yearly clinic visits and periodic data collection throughout each year. Dairy intake for these analyses was derived from a mean of 15 days of diet records per subject collected before age 6. A trained examiner took two measurements each year of height, weight, and triceps, subscapular, suprailiac, and abdominal skinfolds using a standardized protocol. Yearly change in body fat was estimated as the slope of these anthropometry measures from ages 5 to 13 years. Early adolescent body fat was estimated as the mean of all available measurements from 10 to 13 years of age.Children in the lowest sex-specific tertile of dairy intake during preschool (i.e., <1.25 servings per day for girls and <1.70 servings per day for boys) had significantly greater gains in body fat during childhood. These children with low dairy intakes gained more than 3 additional mm of subcutaneous fat per year in the sum of four skinfold measures. By the time of early adolescence, those in the lowest tertile of dairy intake had a BMI that was approximately two units higher and an extra 25 mm of subcutaneous fat.
LLM_1:
This study aimed to assess the influence of early childhood dairy consumption on the development of adiposity from childhood into adolescence. Data were drawn from 99 families participating in the Framingham Children’s Study, with children initially aged up to 6 years. Participants were followed longitudinally through annual clinic visits and periodic assessments. Dairy intake was calculated from an average of 15 days of dietary records collected prior to age 6. Anthropometric measurements—including height, weight, and skinfold thickness at triceps, subscapular, suprailiac, and abdominal sites—were obtained annually by trained examiners using standardized methods. Yearly change in body fat was derived from the slope of anthropometric measures between ages 5 and 13, while early adolescent adiposity was defined as the mean of measurements taken between ages 10 and 13.

Children in the lowest sex-specific tertile of preschool dairy intake (less than 1.25 servings/day for girls and less than 1.70 servings/day for boys) exhibited significantly greater increases in body fat throughout childhood. Specifically, this group accumulated over 3 mm more subcutaneous fat per year, based on the sum of four skinfold measurements. By early adolescence, those with the lowest dairy consumption had an average body mass index approximately two units higher and an additional 25 mm of subcutaneous fat compared to higher intake groups.
LLM_2:
This research investigates the impact of dairy consumption during early childhood on the progression of adiposity from childhood through adolescence. The study utilized data from 99 families involved in the Framingham Children’s Study, focusing on children initially aged up to 6 years. Participants were monitored longitudinally through annual clinic visits and periodic evaluations. Dairy consumption was assessed based on an average of 15 days of dietary records collected prior to the age of 6. Trained examiners conducted annual anthropometric measurements, including height, weight, and skinfold thickness at triceps, subscapular, suprailiac, and abdominal locations, employing standardized procedures. The annual change in body fat was calculated from the slope of anthropometric measurements between the ages of 5 and 13, while early adolescent adiposity was characterized as the average of measurements collected between the ages of 10 and 13.

Results indicated that children in the lowest sex-specific tertile for preschool dairy intake (defined as less than 1.25 servings per day for girls and less than 1.70 servings per day for boys) experienced significantly greater increases in body fat throughout their childhood. This group was found to accumulate over 3 mm more subcutaneous fat annually, as measured by the sum of the four skinfold sites. By early adolescence, children with the lowest dairy consumption exhibited an average body mass index approximately two units higher, along with an additional 25 mm of subcutaneous fat in comparison to those with higher dairy intake.

**Police Defend Officer’s Handling of Drink-Drive Case Amid Criticism**

A police force has come under scrutiny after an officer allowed a motorist who initially tested above the legal alcohol limit to leave following a second test that returned a lower result.

Devon and Cornwall Police confirmed the incident occurred when a driver—whose identity has not been released—was stopped near Cullompton, Devon. The initial breathalyser reading recorded just over 35 micrograms of alcohol per 100 millilitres of breath, the legal limit in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland.

According to BBC sources, the officer consulted a colleague and advised the driver to wait 30 minutes before providing a second sample. That subsequent test fell below the threshold, and the individual was permitted to leave without charge.

The case has drawn sharp criticism from road safety advocates. Roadpeace, the charity supporting victims of road crashes, described the outcome as “deeply concerning” and warned it could set a dangerous precedent with potentially fatal consequences.

Jeff Baker, a trustee at Roadpeace, said: “We are appalled. This sends entirely the wrong message about the seriousness of drink-driving and undermines public confidence in enforcement.”

The Police Federation, which represents rank-and-file officers, acknowledged the sensitivity of the situation but highlighted operational pressures. Nigel Rabbitts, chairman of the Devon and Cornwall branch, said: “Drink-driving is a serious offence. But frontline officers have discretion—and they must make difficult decisions, especially given current austerity measures and reduced staffing levels.”

Following an internal review by its Professional Standards Department, the force said the officer involved received “management advice and guidance” on future conduct. A police spokesperson stressed that robust action is always taken in drink-driving cases. 

“Even a small amount of alcohol affects your ability to drive,” the force stated on its website. “In this specific case, while there may be learning for the officer involved, appropriate and proportionate action was taken.”

The incident reignites debate over the UK’s drink-drive limits, which remain among the highest in Europe. Scotland lowered its limit in December last year, and Northern Ireland is currently considering similar reforms. Campaigners and policing bodies alike have called for a nationwide reduction, arguing it would save lives and improve road safety.

**Analysis: Simon Hall, South West Home Affairs Correspondent**  
This case has exposed tensions between policy, practice, and public expectation. While police discretion is a long-established principle, its application in drink-drive cases invites intense scrutiny—particularly when outcomes appear to conflict with broader safety messaging. With political momentum growing for stricter alcohol limits across the UK, this incident may fuel further calls for clearer national guidelines and greater consistency in enforcement.

I do n't understand this feeling. Every time I see her, I light up. She is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen. 
 
 I lay up at night, staring at the ceiling, thinking about her. Then, she rolls over and touches me, and I feel it all over. I ca n't help it, but I make the silliest noises when she touches my face. I ca n't help but open up to her. 
 
 Our relationship is not without it's challenges, though. There are times when I have her full attention, she laughs, and holds me. Then there are times when I feel forgotten, used up, or ignored. Just the other night, I tried to get her attention, but she growled at me, angrily poking me until I stopped. She tosses me around like I do n't matter to her, playing with me. 
 
 But I ca n't help myself. I love her. And I will be hers forever.

In the quiet dark, I lie awake, tracing the patterns on the ceiling with my thoughts—thoughts that always circle back to her. Then she turns, her hand finding me in the shadows, and a current runs through my whole being. I can’t hold back the soft, foolish sounds that escape when her fingers brush my face. With her, every part of me unfolds.

It isn’t always simple between us. Sometimes I have all of her—her laughter, her arms wrapped tight, her full focus. Other times, I’m set aside, drained of warmth, invisible. Just last night, I reached for her notice, and she snapped, jabbing at me until I stilled. She flings me about as if I’m weightless, a thing for passing amusement.

Yet I am helpless against it. I am hers. Completely. And always will be.

And yet, despite the turmoil, one inescapable truth remains: I belong to this tempestuous soul, entirely and forevermore. Entranced by the whims of fate, bound by threads both fragile and unbreakable, this is where I'll forever be – at her mercy, helpless to escape the all-consuming pull of our entwined hearts.

The results presented in Figure 4 offer a compelling illustration of DeepCTRL’s functionality and practical utility. However, a point of clarification arises from Figure 4c: the plot suggests that DeepCTRL enforces the soft rule more effectively than LDF. Given this stronger rule adherence, it is somewhat unexpected that DeepCTRL continues to outperform LDF in Figures 5b and 5c, even in regimes where enforcing the rule would intuitively compromise performance. The authors are encouraged to provide an explanation for this apparent discrepancy—specifically, whether the improved performance stems from better calibration of rule influence or other factors not directly tied to rule strength.

Regarding Figure 3, the evidence that DeepCTRL surpasses the LDF-Ratio baseline appears inconclusive. In this setting, LDF-Ratio achieves the highest performance despite minimal adherence to the energy damping rule. While its verification ratio is lower, this result raises questions about the necessity of strict rule enforcement for strong predictive performance. A clearer justification would help establish that DeepCTRL’s advantages are not merely due to rule compliance but also translate into tangible gains in accuracy or robustness.

The ablation studies included in the paper lend reasonable support to the design choices underlying DeepCTRL, offering insight into the contributions of different components.

One potentially informative baseline that is not considered is a simple convex combination of a rule-based model and a neural network—effectively interpolating between symbolic and learned reasoning at test time. Such an approach could retain key desiderata like controllability over rule influence while being conceptually simpler. The authors should discuss why DeepCTRL offers meaningful improvements over this baseline, or clarify why such a comparison was omitted.

**Minor Comments:**

- The first sentence of the abstract contains a grammatical ambiguity that slightly affects readability. A rephrasing for clarity is recommended.
- In the caption of Figure 1, “DEEPCTRL **provide** a controllable mechanism” should be corrected to “**provides**” for subject-verb agreement.
- Figure 1 would benefit from additional clarification: the meaning of the blue arrows is not immediately evident. Moreover, the violation of the monotonicity physical rule across all curves—particularly in the bottom subplot, where rule strength is supposedly maximized—is puzzling. The authors should explain why the outputs do not reflect the expected monotonic behavior under strong rule enforcement, as this may affect interpretations of the method’s reliability.

High above the Earth's atmosphere, an alien spaceship waits. 
 
 `` Okay, okay, okay, hold on -- They do *what*?'' 
 
 Brr'Kat was in shock as his second-in-command reported in on human activities. 
 
 `` They, er... Poison.. Themselves,'' Brr'Shi said. 
 
 `` Wh -- Ho -- What!?'' 
 
 `` It's true,'' Brr'Shi said. `` A lot of them will poison themselves using Substance N204, or nicotine, as known to them.'' 
 
 Rubbing his one eye, Brr'Kat tried to comprehend what this race was doing. `` And.. Do they not die? How have they not gone extinct?'' 
 
 `` Well, you see, they die after a few years --'' 
 
 Brr'Kat gasped loudly, loud enough for it to echo down the adjacent hallways. `` A few YEARS!? N204 kills us in mere minutes!'' 
 
 `` But, sir, that's not the worst of it. Sometimes, it does n't even kill them -- some of them simply do it their whole lives and die of old age.'' 
 
 Brr'Kat turned from his second-in-command to the control console behind him. Hurriedly, he began inputting new coordinates, to find a different alien race to invade. `` Nope.'' With one of his many tentacles, he rubbed his eye. `` Too dangerous. We're outta here. Tell the others. Nope, nope, nope, nope...'' 
 
 As the ship rocketed away, you could hear a faint `` Nope'' echoing until they left the solar system.

“Okay, okay—hold on. They do *what*?”

Brr’Kat stared, his single eye wide, as his second-in-command relayed the latest findings on human behavior.

“They… poison themselves,” Brr’Shi said, his voice hesitant.

“Wh—how—what?”

“It’s true,” Brr’Shi confirmed. “Many of them intentionally ingest Substance N204—known to them as nicotine.”

Brr’Kat rubbed his eye slowly, struggling to process the report. “And they survive? How has the species not gone extinct?”

“Well, they often die after several years—”

Brr’Kat gasped, a sharp sound that echoed down the nearby corridors. “Several *years*? N204 kills our kind in minutes!”

“But, Commander, that isn’t the most disturbing part. Sometimes it doesn’t kill them at all. Some live with it their entire lives and perish of age instead.”

Brr’Kat turned abruptly from his officer to the navigation console. His tentacles flew across the controls, entering new coordinates. “No,” he muttered, rubbing his eye again. “Too dangerous. We’re leaving. Alert the crew. No, no, no…”

As the ship surged away, a faint, fading “No…” trailed behind it, echoing through the void until they vanished beyond the solar system.

The news was even moredistressing:“But, Commanderalso,”the officer added, “that's not themostdisturbingspart. Sometimeitdoesn’tkill themat all.Some livewith ittheir entirelives andperishofageinstead.”

With a swift, decisive motion, Berratentangled his tentaclesthrough the consolecontrols, setting newcoordinates. The vessel surgedaway,leaving behind the distressing revelation. As they faded into thevoid, alate, lingering "No..." trailedbehind them, untilthey vanishedbeyondthesolarsystem.

In 2004, Kanye West became involved in a series of public incidents at music award ceremonies. At the 2004 American Music Awards, he left the auditorium abruptly after losing the Best New Artist award to country singer Gretchen Wilson. Following the event, West expressed his disappointment, stating, "I felt like I was definitely robbed [...] I was the best new artist this year."

In the wake of the announcement of the 2006 Grammy nominations, West commented that he would "really have a problem" if he did not win the Album of the Year award, asserting, "I don't care what I do, I don't care how much I stunt – you can never take away from the amount of work I put into it. I don't want to hear all of that politically correct stuff."

On November 2, 2006, after his video for "Touch the Sky" did not win Best Video at the MTV Europe Music Awards, West interrupted the award presentation to Justice and Simian for their song "We Are Your Friends," claiming that he should have received the honor. This outburst garnered criticism from various international news organizations. Subsequently, on November 7, 2006, West publicly apologized for the incident during his opening performance for U2's Vertigo Tour concert in Brisbane. He later parodied the event in a sketch on the season premiere of *Saturday Night Live*'s 33rd season in September 2007.

The method proposes a new architecture for solving image super-resolution task. They provide an analysis that connects aims to establish a connection between how CNNs for solving super resolution and solving sparse regularized inverse problems.

The writing of the paper needs improvement. I was not able to understand the proposed connection, as notation is inconsistent and it is difficult to figure out what the authors are stating. I am willing to reconsider my evaluation if the authors provide clarifications.

The paper does not refer to recent advances in the problem, which are (as far as I know), the state of the art in the problem in terms of quality of the solutions. This references should be added and the authors should put their work into context.

1) Arguably, the state of the art in super resolution are techniques that go beyond L2 fitting. Specifically, methods using perceptual losses such as:

Johnson, J. et al "Perceptual losses for real-time style transfer and super-resolution." European Conference on Computer Vision. Springer International Publishing, 2016.

Ledig, Christian, et al. "Photo-realistic single image super-resolution using a generative adversarial network." arXiv preprint arXiv:1609.04802 (2016).

PSNR is known to not be directly related to image quality, as it favors blurred solutions. This should be discussed.

2) The overall notation of the paper should be improved. For instance, in (1), g represents the observation (the LR image), whereas later in the text, g is the HR image. 

3) The description of Section 2.1 is quite confusing in my view. In equation (1), y is the signal to be recovered and K is just the downsampling plus blurring. So assuming an L1 regularization in this equation assumes that the signal itself is sparse. Equation (2) changes notation referring y as f. 

4) Equation (2) seems wrong. The term multiplying K^T is not the norm (should be parenthesis).

5) The first statement of Section 2.2. seems wrong. DL methods do state the super resolution problem as an inverse problem. Instead of using a pre-defined basis function they learn an over-complete dictionary from the data, assuming that natural images can be sparsely represented. Also, this section does not explain how DL is used for super resolution. The cited work by Yang et al learns a two coupled dictionaries (one for LR and HL), such that for a given patch, the same sparse coefficients can reconstruct both HR and LR patches. The authors just state the sparse coding problem.

6) Equation (10) should not contain the \leq \epsilon.

7) In the second paragraph of Section 3, the authors mention that the LR image has to be larger than the HR image to prevent border effects. This makes sense. However, with the size of the network (20 layers), the change in size seems to be quite large. Could you please provide the sizes? When measuring PSNR, is this taken into account? 

8) It would be very helpful to include an image explaining the procedure described in the second paragraph of Section 3.

9) I find the description in Section 3 quite confusing. The authors relate the training of a single filter (or neuron) to equation (7), but they define D, that is not used in all of Section 2.1. And K does not show in any of the analysis given in the last paragraph of page 4. However, D and K seem two different things (it is not just one for the other), see bellow.

10) I cannot understand the derivation that the authors do in the last paragraph of page 4 (and beginning of page 5). What is phi_l here? K in equation (7) seems to match to D here, but D here is a collection of patches and in (7) is a blurring and downsampling operator. I cannot review this section. I will wait for the author's response clarifications.

11) The authors describe a change in roles between the representations and atoms in the training and testing phase respectively. I do not understand this. If I understand correctly, the final algorithm, the authors train a CNN mapping LR to HR images. The network is used in the same way at training and testing.

12) It would be useful to provide more details about the training of the network. Please describe the training set used by Kim et al. Are the two networks trained independently? One could think of fine-tuning them jointly (including the aggregation).

13) The authors show the advantage of separating networks on a single image, Barbara. It would be good to quantify this better (maybe in terms of PSNR?). This observation might be true only because the training loss, say than the works cited above. Please comment on this.

14) In figures 3 and 4, the learned filters are those on the top (above the yellow arrow). It is not obvious to me that the reflect the predominant structure in the data. (maybe due to the low resolution).

15) This work is related to (though clearly different)  that of LISTA (Learned ISTA) type of networks, proposed in:

Gregor, K., & LeCun, Y. (2010). Learning fast approximations of sparse coding. In Proceedings of the 27th International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML) 

Which connect the network architecture with the optimization algorithm used for solving the sparse coding problem. Follow up works have used these ideas for solving inverse problems as well.

The paper introduces a novel architecture for image super-resolution, aiming to establish a theoretical link between CNN-based approaches and sparse regularized inverse problems. However, the manuscript requires significant revisions to improve clarity and contextualization.

**Major Concerns:**

1. **Clarity and Exposition:** The proposed connection is currently difficult to follow due to inconsistent notation and unclear explanations. I could not fully grasp the derivation, particularly in Sections 2.1, 2.2, and 3. The authors should thoroughly revise the text for consistency and clarity. For instance, the variable 'g' is used to denote both the LR and HR images at different points, and the description of the relationship between equations (7) and the network training is confusing. The derivation in the last paragraph of page 4 and page 5 is unclear regarding the roles of φ_l, K, and D.

2. **Context and Literature:** The paper does not adequately situate itself within recent advances in super-resolution. The current state of the art largely involves methods that move beyond simple L2 loss, employing perceptual losses or generative adversarial networks for improved perceptual quality. Key works, such as Johnson et al. (2016) on perceptual losses and Ledig et al. (2016) on SRGAN, should be discussed. The limitations of PSNR as a metric (e.g., its tendency to favor overly smooth images) should also be addressed to better frame the contributions.

**Specific Points:**

*   **Eq. (1) & (2):** The notation in Section 2.1 is problematic. Equation (1) uses 'y' for the signal, while (2) switches to 'f'. Furthermore, Equation (2) appears to have a typo in the term multiplying K^T.
*   **Section 2.2:** The claim that DL methods do not state super-resolution as an inverse problem is incorrect. Dictionary learning methods explicitly treat it as such, learning sparse representations. The description of how DL is used for SR is insufficient and merely states the sparse coding problem without explaining the connection to the cited work (Yang et al.).
*   **Eq. (10):** The ≤ ε condition seems misplaced.
*   **Section 3 - Practical Details:** The discussion on border effects and the required LR image size is noted. Given the 20-layer network, please specify the actual input/output dimensions used and clarify how PSNR is calculated (e.g., whether border regions are cropped for a fair comparison). A schematic figure illustrating the procedure described in the second paragraph of Section 3 would be very helpful.
*   **Section 3 - Training & Testing:** The description of a change in roles for representations/atoms between training and testing phases is unclear. If the final model is a standard CNN mapping LR to HR, its usage should be consistent in both phases. Please clarify this point and provide more training details: which dataset (e.g., the one used by Kim et al.) was employed? Were the two networks trained independently, and was joint fine-tuning considered?
*   **Experiments:** The claimed advantage of using separate networks is demonstrated only on the 'Barbara' image. This should be quantified (e.g., with PSNR/SSIM) and discussed—is this effect consistent across the test set or potentially an artifact of the training loss? In Figures 3 and 4, please clarify if the learned filters shown are those above the yellow arrow; their connection to predominant image structures is not immediately apparent.
*   **Related Work:** The method appears related to architectures inspired by optimization algorithms, such as LISTA (Gregor & LeCun, 2010) and its successors for inverse problems. This connection should be acknowledged and discussed.

**Recommendation:** I am willing to reconsider my evaluation upon a major revision that addresses these concerns. The revisions should focus on: (1) significantly improving the clarity, consistency, and technical correctness of the exposition; (2) properly contextualizing the work within the modern super-resolution literature; and (3) providing missing experimental details and analyses.

preserving core meaning and intent while enhancing clarity, fluency, structure, and tone to align with the conventions of professional peer-review feedback.

---

The paper proposes a novel architecture for image super-resolution, motivated by establishing a theoretical connection between convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and sparse regularized inverse problems. While this conceptual direction is promising, the manuscript in its current form requires substantial revision to improve technical clarity, contextual grounding, and experimental rigor before it can be fully assessed.

### Major Concerns

**1. Clarity and Technical Exposition:**  
The central theoretical argument—linking the network design to sparse recovery—is currently difficult to follow due to inconsistent notation, ambiguous definitions, and incomplete derivations. Sections 2.1, 2.2, and 3 in particular would benefit from a thorough reorganization and more precise exposition. For example:
- The symbol *g* is used interchangeably to denote both low-resolution (LR) and high-resolution (HR) images at different points, leading to confusion.
- The transition from Equation (7) to the network training procedure lacks sufficient explanation.
- The roles of key components such as φₗ, K, and D in the derivation on pages 4–5 are not clearly articulated.

These issues hinder the reader’s ability to verify the correctness and novelty of the proposed formulation. A clearer, step-by-step derivation—ideally with consistent variable naming and explicit connections between mathematical expressions and architectural choices—is essential.

**2. Contextualization within Existing Literature:**  
The paper does not sufficiently engage with recent developments in image super-resolution. State-of-the-art methods increasingly rely on perceptual losses (e.g., Johnson et al., 2016) or adversarial training (e.g., SRGAN, Ledig et al., 2016) to achieve visually compelling results, often prioritizing perceptual quality over pixel-level accuracy. In contrast, the reliance on L2 loss and PSNR as the primary evaluation metric limits the perceived impact of the approach, especially given well-documented limitations of PSNR in correlating with human perception (e.g., its bias toward blurry reconstructions).

A more comprehensive discussion of these advances—and a clear articulation of how the proposed method compares or offers complementary advantages—is necessary to position the work effectively within the field.

### Specific Comments

- **Equations (1) and (2):** The shift from using *y* in Equation (1) to *f* in Equation (2) for the underlying signal introduces unnecessary inconsistency. Additionally, there appears to be a typo in the term involving $ K^T $ in Equation (2); please verify and correct if needed.
  
- **Section 2.2:** The claim that deep learning methods do not formulate super-resolution as an inverse problem is inaccurate. Several approaches, particularly those based on dictionary learning and sparse coding (e.g., Yang et al.), explicitly adopt this perspective. The relationship between these prior works and the current formulation should be clarified and properly contextualized.

- **Equation (10):** The constraint $ \leq \varepsilon $ seems out of place and lacks motivation. Please explain its role in the optimization framework or reconsider its inclusion.

- **Section 3 – Practical Implementation Details:**  
  - Given the 20-layer network depth, please specify the actual input and output dimensions used in experiments.  
  - Clarify how PSNR is computed—specifically, whether border pixels are excluded to ensure fair comparison across methods.  
  - A schematic illustration of the processing pipeline described in Section 3 would greatly aid understanding.

- **Section 3 – Training and Testing Procedure:**  
  The description of differing roles for representations and atoms during training versus inference is unclear. If the final model operates as a standard feedforward CNN mapping LR to HR images, its usage should be consistent across phases. Please clarify this point and provide additional details:  
  - Which dataset was used for training (e.g., the one from Kim et al.)?  
  - Were the two subnetworks trained independently, or was joint fine-tuning applied?

- **Experiments:**  
  - The claimed benefit of using separate networks is illustrated only qualitatively on the 'Barbara' image. This observation should be supported with quantitative metrics (e.g., PSNR, SSIM) across multiple test samples to assess generalizability. Is the improvement consistent, or could it stem from idiosyncrasies of the loss function or data?
  - In Figures 3 and 4, please indicate whether the displayed filters correspond to those above the yellow arrow. Furthermore, their relationship to dominant image structures (e.g., edges, textures) should be discussed more explicitly.

- **Related Work:**  
  The proposed architecture bears resemblance to unrolled optimization frameworks such as LISTA (Gregor & LeCun, 2010) and its extensions for inverse problems. These connections should be acknowledged and analyzed to better highlight the positioning and novelty of the current approach.

### Recommendation

I recommend **major revision**. I am open to reassessing the paper after the authors address the above concerns. Key priorities for revision include:
1. Substantially improving the **clarity, consistency, and logical flow** of the theoretical development;
2. Strengthening the **literature review and contextual analysis**, particularly with respect to modern super-resolution techniques and evaluation paradigms;
3. Providing **detailed experimental clarification**, including training protocols, evaluation methodology, and broader empirical validation.

With these improvements, the paper has the potential to make a meaningful contribution to the intersection of deep learning and inverse problem modeling.

--- 

This rewritten version maintains all original critiques and suggestions but presents them in a more structured, fluent, and academically polished manner—appropriate for a rigorous peer-review setting.

Sir Tony played dim-witted sidekick Baldrick in the show and cast Byrne in his Maid Marion and Her Merry Men series.
He told BBC Radio 5 Live she had been like a mother to "her boys" on the Blackadder set.
"Patsy was just a real confident centre of all the scenes," he said.
"She had unerring skill to make the daftest, silliest thing sound absolutely real and absolutely plausible," he added.
"I was so fond of her as a person and so in awe of her capabilities that when I decided I wanted to introduce a mother to Maid Marion, my first choice was Patsy.
"I was thrilled that she took it. Even though she has done such grand work she came down to Minehead and rolled her sleeves up and was just one of the lads, as she always was, and did a great performance."
Broadcaster and actor Stephen Fry, who played Lord Melchett alongside Byrne, tweeted: "Oh lord no! I've just heard that Patsy Byrne, darling Nursie has died. Hope St Bernard has welcomed her to eternal rest. Adorable woman."
Blackadder producer John Lloyd also paid tribute to Byrne, saying she and Miranda Richardson, who played Queen Elizabeth I, were a "fantastic double act".
Byrne played Nursie - the kind but dim-witted nursemaid to Elizabeth I - in the second series of BBC comedy Blackadder in 1986.
"It's ironic that she will be remembered for that lovable, slightly idiotic person with that ludicrous drawl, but she was a proper actress. With the RSC, she played Chekhov opposite Rex Harrison, was incredibly well spoken, but she would put up with our little ways," he told 5 Live.
"The rehearsals on Blackadder were interminable, with us changing our minds all the time and she was always on top of it and she never complained. We had famous actors walk out of rehearsals because it was such a nightmare and shambles. But with Patsy there was never a peep of complaint."
Byrne died on Tuesday at Denville Hall, a retirement home for actors, in Hillingdon, north-west London.
The Kent-born actress joined the Royal Shakespeare Company after drama school and took on TV and theatre roles.
Her other roles included the ITV sitcom Watching and the classic police series Z Cars. She also made appearances in Holby City and I, Claudius, and played Mrs Nubbles in the BBC's 1979 adaption of The Old Curiosity Shop.
Byrne's death came just over a week after Rik Mayall, who shared screen time with her as Lord Flashheart in Blackadder, died suddenly at his home in London.
Blackadder ran for four series between 1983 and 1989 - with writing credits shared between Rowan Atkinson, Richard Curtis and Ben Elton. The comedy followed the exploits of Atkinson's Blackadder character through various historical periods.

---

**Tributes Pour In for *Blackadder* Star Patsy Byrne**  

Sir Tony Robinson, best known for playing Baldrick in the beloved BBC comedy *Blackadder*, has paid heartfelt tribute to actress Patsy Byrne, recalling her warmth and talent after her death at the age of 80.  

Byrne, who portrayed the endearing and dim-witted Nursie—the nursemaid to Miranda Richardson’s Queen Elizabeth I—in the second series of *Blackadder* (1986), was remembered by co-stars and collaborators as both a consummate professional and a deeply cherished presence on set.

Robinson, who later cast Byrne in his children’s series *Maid Marion and Her Merry Men*, told BBC Radio 5 Live that she had been “like a mother to her boys” during their time working together on *Blackadder*.  

“Patsy was a truly confident centre in every scene,” he said. “She possessed an unerring skill to make the daftest, silliest things sound absolutely real and plausible.”  

When Robinson created a maternal role for *Maid Marion*, Byrne was his immediate first choice. “I was so fond of her personally and so in awe of her abilities,” he said. “Despite her esteemed career, she came to Minehead, rolled up her sleeves, and was just one of the lads—as always—delivering a great performance.”

Fellow *Blackadder* star Stephen Fry, who played the foppish Lord Melchett opposite Byrne, expressed his sorrow on Twitter: “Oh lord no! I've just heard that Patsy Byrne, darling Nursie, has died. May St Bernard welcome her to eternal rest. An adorable woman.”

Producer John Lloyd also celebrated her legacy, highlighting her chemistry with Miranda Richardson. “They were a fantastic double act,” he said. “It’s ironic she’ll be remembered for that lovable, slightly idiotic character with the ludicrous drawl—but she was a proper actress.”

Lloyd emphasized Byrne’s formidable stage credentials, noting that she had performed Chekhov with the Royal Shakespeare Company opposite Rex Harrison and was “incredibly well-spoken.” Yet she embraced the chaotic, ever-evolving nature of *Blackadder*’s rehearsals without complaint.  

“Rehearsals were interminable, with constant changes,” Lloyd recalled. “We had famous actors walk out because it was such a shambles. But with Patsy, there wasn’t a peep of complaint. She was always on top of it.”

Byrne passed away on Tuesday at Denville Hall, a retirement home for actors in Hillingdon, north-west London. Born in Kent, she trained at drama school before joining the RSC, going on to build a rich and varied career across television and theatre.

Her extensive credits include the ITV sitcom *Watching*, the police drama *Z-Cars*, *Holby City*, *I, Claudius*, and a memorable turn as Mrs. Nubbles in the BBC’s 1979 adaptation of *The Old Curiosity Shop*.

Her death comes just over a week after that of Rik Mayall, who played the explosive Lord Flashheart in *Blackadder II*. Mayall died suddenly at his home in London.

Created by Richard Curtis and Rowan Atkinson, and later co-written by Ben Elton, *Blackadder* ran for four series between 1983 and 1989, following Atkinson’s cunning antihero through different eras of British history. The show remains a cornerstone of British comedy, with Byrne’s Nursie enduring as one of its most affectionately remembered characters.

---

Humans ( UAL Designation 00582-Harmless ) are a mostly bipedal creature, and of middling capacity for technology. 
 
 Their origin is unknown, but their stories, while humorous, seem to point to colonization by one or more species, namely the Arak from Hqlra. Human Theology is taught in a handful of less-prestigious Uni planets within the Realm, and is not considered to be of lasting import. 
 
 These creatures are mostly arollsi, and their term for this is water. They have bi-thread genetics based upon crrk-hago bonds ( Their terms are DNA, Carbon, and Nitrogen, respectively ) 
 
 Their capacity for irrational thought is high, and is know by many names on their home planet RGL-000834c, known to them as Earth ( or less commonly, Terra. Though Terran is known throughout the Realm as a slur and should be avoided. ) 
 
 The dominant social order would be familiar to the Arq-Hli, and Humans have unknowingly parodied this race in their art forms, calling them Ferrengi. Fortunately, the Arq-Hli have found this humorous overall, and only small factions of the'Hli want to rule them as All-High, and/or destroy them. Talks with the'Hli are ongoing as of the time of this edit, Realmic 3502-43. 
 
 While study of this species is important in our understanding of how primitive species evolve into Garrala ( their closest approximation might be Awareness ), it is highly advised to not interact with these creatures. They have been known to hold citizens of the Realm against their will, and seem to take great delight in pushing blunt objects into unconcealed orifices. Due to Realm Protocol One, any citizens of the Realm stranded on this planet will likely be left behind, as it is Realm procedure to not exchange information or technology for the lives of its citizens. Unfortunately, the protocol has been breached three times ( with a few other highly speculated but unverified instances. ) 
 
 While this is *highly* unadvisable, Humans are easily housebroken and trainable, and in theory would make excellent pets for citizens of Urgur stature or larger. Human society is considered unstable, and it is hoped that more data will be gathered on this species before its extinction.

Their origins remain obscure, though their own myths—amusing as they are—hint at colonization by one or more external races, most notably the Arak of Hqlra. Human theology is offered as a minor course of study on a few lesser-known Uni planets across the Realm, generally regarded as a fleeting curiosity rather than a field of enduring significance.

Biologically, humans are composed largely of arollsi, which they refer to as water. Their genetic structure relies on a bi-thread system built upon crrk-hago bonds (in their vernacular: DNA, carbon, and nitrogen). Notably, they exhibit a pronounced tendency toward irrational thought, a trait documented under many names on their homeworld, RGL-000834c—known to them as Earth, or, less commonly, Terra. (Caution: “Terran” is widely recognized throughout the Realm as a derogatory term and should be avoided.)

Their prevailing social order bears striking resemblance to that of the Arq-Hli, a likeness humans have unwittingly caricatured in their arts under the name “Ferrengi.” To our relief, the Arq-Hli have largely taken this imitation in good humor, though minor factions among them still advocate for conquest or annihilation. Diplomatic discussions with the ’Hli remain ongoing as of this update, Realmic 3502-43.

Although research into this species provides valuable insight into how primitive lifeforms develop toward Garrala (roughly analogous to what humans might call Awareness), direct interaction is strongly discouraged. Humans have been recorded detaining Realm citizens against their will and display a peculiar fascination with inserting blunt objects into exposed orifices. Under Realm Protocol One, any citizen stranded on Earth is typically considered forfeit, as the Realm does not trade knowledge or technology for lives. Regrettably, this protocol has been violated on three confirmed occasions, with several other incidents still unverified.

While it remains highly ill-advised, humans are notably trainable and could, in theory, serve as manageable pets for beings of Urgur size or greater. Their societal structures are volatile, and it is the hope of the Realm that further observational data can be collected before the species meets its inevitable extinction.

According to their myths, an external influence – possibly the enigmatic Araks of Xylophia – seeded their civilization. While human theology may be a peripheral subject on the periphery of Uni worlds, it's viewed as an ephemeral curiosity, devoid of profound significance within the greater Realm.

Biology reveals that humans comprise an astonishing proportion of what they term "aqua" – a substance akin to water in our understanding. At the genetic core lies a dual-threaded system, woven from the intricate bonds of c-rk and h-ag (terms we recognize as DNA and carbon). Their thought processes, however, are marked by a distinct propensity for illogical reasoning, evident in various guises across their planet, known to us as Terra or Earth (though the term 'Terrans' is a pejorative in the broader Realm).

Humans' societal hierarchy bears an uncanny resemblance – almost a caricaturized echo – of that found among the benevolent Arquians. This similarity has unwitting been reflected in human art, where they've dubbed the latter the "Ferengi." While the genuine Arqui have, for the most part, taken their imitation with good-nature, some extremist factions continue to advocate conquest. Ongoing diplomatic efforts with these neighbors aim to ease tensions and forge a lasting peace.

Despite the allure of studying this enigma, direct engagement with humans is highly discouraged due to past transgressions. They've been observed detuning Realm travelers against the will, coupled with an unsettling fascination for inserting inanimate objects within vulnerable orifice. In accordance with Realm Policy One (3503-42), any stranded Realm citizen on this planet is usually considered a lost cause, given our reluctance to exchange knowledge for human lives.

That being said, these creatures can, theoretically, be trained and domesticated – though it would be most advisable to consider them pets of beings significantly larger, such us Urgurs. Given their societal volatility, our primary goal remains the collection of observational insights, before their inevitable descent into extinction.

It's easy to forget. Lots of people do it. They forget really simple things like where they forgot their wallet or an acquaintence's name. I do n't forget, in fact, I remember quite a lot. 
 
 I'm young now, so young in fact I just began ovulating, but I know more than I should. I remember tying up my wife because she wanted to. I remember drinking with my friends and my job at a factory. I remember being a man and what it was to be a man, even though I am a little girl now. 
 
 My mother always called me an old soul, maybe it was true. Or was I insane? Can I prove it? I actually live in the same resided in when I was a man. I remember dying, or at least the last image of what the end of my life was. 
 
 It was a bright and sunny day in autumn and I was crossing the street with my wife. I remember how the wind blew her hair and she smiled at me. And then I'm lying on the asphalt. Then I'm being born into the world again, and I'm crying. Learning to walk and talk and how to express how all of this is like some sick parody of my own first life, just with the genders swapped. 
 
 My plan slowly came together. Every other Sunday my mother would have to work, leaving me in our apartment in care of my father. He would invariably fall asleep, watching Nascar in a marijuana stupor. I would go then. 
 
 I stole the money for the bus fare slowly, over months so my parents would n't notice. A couple dollars here, more there. And then everything came to fruition. I could n't wait for my mother to leave and wait tables. It took so long for my father to fall asleep. I boarded the bus and watched the scenery change until we were in my old neighborhood. nostalgia through the eyes of a eleven year old girl feels unnatural. The bars and butchershop I frequented. The grocery where I went with my wife on Sundays. 
 
 Unfortunately, I could n't very well ask anyone where my grave was. It would be too unnerving. I could n't think of any way I could try and link myself to my former self. We had nothing in common thus far and he had died when I was born. I looked in the cemetery where my former parents were buried, but I was n't there. My brother's headstone was however. I placed a rock on his and my parents' gravestone and moved on. I began to get disheartened when it was n't in the church yard I had frequented either. 
 
 My wife had never been a big fan of open casket funerals. She had always tried to think of an excuse anytime we were obligated to attend one. I had my hunch, and though I said I never would, I walked to my old home and stood on the stoop. Surely, I would be able to see it from here. I looked into the darkening picture window of my old home and saw an azure urn on the mantle. The script on the urn was faint, but I was able to make out my birth date. 
 
 I vacated the premises almost immediately. It was as if a goose had stepped on my grave. I thought I would feel triumphant, but I felt almost desperate. Desperate to be a an and to hold my wife again. As I walked to the bus stop, I stopped dead in the center of the sidewalk. 
 
 My wife was walking toward me. Quietly, quickly as she always did. Ten years older and still out of my league. My jaw hung agape and just as she was about to pass I blurted out the only thing I could think of to say: `` Harold loves you.'' 
 
 My wife slowed and then finally stopped. `` What did you say?'' She said. 
 
 `` Harold loves you,'' I repeated. My wife fell to her knees on the cement and began to wail. I found myself embracing her and crying as well. Eventually, the sniffles subsided and I left her, avoiding her questions as to why I had said what I had said. But I knew now that I was surely not imagining my last life, but I had realized it was gone now. I boarded the bus and was surprised when it rolled through the intersection I had been killed on. Surely it was a sign. 
 
 I read as the bus brought me home and hummed Beatles' tunes under my breath. An old lady asked me, `` Oh, did your mama teach you those tunes?'' 
 
 `` Yeah,'' I said knowingly. `` Something like that.''

It’s easy to forget. Most people do—simple things, like where they left their wallet or the name of an acquaintance. But not me. I remember far too much.

I’m young now, just starting to navigate the changes of adolescence, yet my mind is burdened with memories that should belong to someone else. I recall tying up my wife because she asked me to. I can still taste the laughter shared over drinks with friends and feel the hum of machinery at the factory where I once worked. I remember being a man and what that entailed, even though I now inhabit the body of a little girl.

My mother always called me an old soul. Perhaps she was right. Or perhaps I was simply unhinged. Could I even prove it? I still live in the same town that once cradled my former existence. I remember dying—or at least the last image before it all faded to black: a bright, sunlit autumn day, crossing the street with my wife. I recall the wind lifting her hair, the warmth of her smile. Then, there was asphalt beneath me, and suddenly I was reborn—crying, learning to walk and talk, grappling to articulate how this felt like a cruel parody of my first life, but with the roles reversed.

Slowly, a plan began to take shape. Every other Sunday, my mother would work, leaving me alone with my father in our apartment. He would inevitably succumb to sleep, dazed by NASCAR and the haze of marijuana. That’s when I would slip away.

Over the course of several months, I pilfered bus fare—just a few dollars here, a little more there—so my parents remained oblivious. When the moment finally arrived, I could hardly contain my anticipation for my mother to leave for her waitressing shift. It felt like an eternity before my father drifted off. I boarded the bus, watching the scenery blur and shift until we reached my old neighborhood. Viewing it through the eyes of an eleven-year-old girl felt disconcerting: the bars and butcher shop I used to frequent, the grocery store where my wife and I spent every Sunday.

I couldn’t very well ask anyone where my grave was—too unsettling, too surreal. There was no way to connect this self with the one that had come before. We were strangers, and he had died the day I was born. I scoured the cemetery where my parents were buried, but I found no trace of myself. My brother’s headstone stood solitary, though. I placed a small rock on his and my parents’ graves before moving on. Disheartened, I ventured to the churchyard I frequented, but still, I was nowhere to be found.

My wife never favored open-casket funerals. She always managed to conjure an excuse to avoid them. I had a hunch. Though I swore I never would, I walked to my old home and stood on the stoop. Surely, I could catch a glimpse from here. Peering into the dimming picture window, I spotted an azure urn on the mantle. The script was faint, but I could just make out my birth date.

I left almost immediately, a chill creeping over me like a ghost brushing past. I thought I’d feel triumphant, yet instead, a deep desperation welled within me—desperate to reclaim my identity, to hold my wife again. As I made my way to the bus stop, I froze in the middle of the sidewalk.

There she was, approaching me. Quiet and swift, just as she had always been. Ten years older and still out of my league. My jaw dropped, and just as she was about to pass, I blurted out the only thing that came to mind: “Harold loves you.”

She slowed, then stopped. “What did you say?”

“Harold loves you,” I repeated, my voice trembling.

My wife sank to her knees on the cement, wailing. In that moment, I found myself holding her, tears streaming down my face too. Eventually, the sobs subsided. I left her there, sidestepping her questions about my cryptic words. But I knew then—I wasn’t conjuring memories of my past life. I had simply come to terms with the fact that it was truly gone.

I boarded the bus, startled as it rolled through the intersection where I had met my end. Surely, that was a sign.

On the ride home, I read and hummed Beatles tunes under my breath. An elderly woman turned to me and asked, “Oh, did your mama teach you those songs?”

“Yeah,” I replied knowingly. “Something like that.”

“So… how may I help you?”

The adventurer, who had been creeping stealthily through the bushes toward the lich, froze at the sudden address.  
“I see you there, just behind the blueberries. Could you pick some for me, if you don’t mind?”

Bow in hand, a poisoned arrow nocked and ready, the low-level adventurer felt his plan unravel. With the element of surprise gone, he reluctantly gathered a handful of blueberries and stepped forward, preparing to speak. What he hadn’t noticed was the rune beneath his boot.

In an instant, he was floating, lifted by constricting beams of mana that barred all escape. The lich approached, staff in one hand, the other crackling with raw energy—the very force that now held the adventurer captive. Each step echoed with growing power, each movement a dry, crackling advance. Doom crept closer, step by mummified step. The adventurer could scarcely keep hold of his bow, let alone the berries. His eyes darted desperately for an exit—so frantically that he didn’t notice how near the lich had drawn.

Now standing barely a breath away, the lich reached out with wrinkled fingers, pried open the adventurer’s clenched hand, and guided it toward his own gaping mouth. With a wave of his arm, he compelled the fingers to uncurl, dropping the blueberries onto a rolling, rotten tongue. The adventurer watched in horror as the lich stared into his eyes—blue, bright, and still so full of life—then crushed the berries between decaying teeth, mashing them into a glowing, pasty mush.

“What ish it yoush sheek, yungk adventurerth?” the lich spewed into his face, the question flecked with berry filling that now glowed faintly blue. A chunk of jelly landed on the adventurer’s cheek.

“I seek fame, fortune, and to slay evil creatures like you! I will not yield, nor obey your wicked commands. Release me, foul demon!”

The lich responded with a wet, croaking gurgle—something between a frog’s call and laughter. From his cloak, he produced a jar and vomited into it the glowing jelly, now streaked with mucus and what might have been boogers. He sealed the lid, snapped his fingers, and the magical bonds vanished, dropping the adventurer unceremoniously to his feet.

The lich pressed the jar into the man’s hands. “I hope this fetches a good price at the market. Now leave me and my berries alone!”

Stunned and bewildered by the lich’s solitary—and strangely civil—request, the adventurer fled the cave without looking back. As he hurried away, he considered his luck: an awkward but harmless lich, and a newfound “bounty” to sell in the city. Of course, no alchemist would want snot-covered magical berries… no matter how powerful the enchanted mucus inside. He’d need a convincing lie.
LLM_2:
The language has been elevated for greater immersion, clarity, and literary flair.

**"So… how may I help you?"**

The words cut through the forest hush like a blade through mist.

The adventurer froze mid-step, one foot still half-buried in the underbrush, heart hammering against his ribs. He had been so careful—moving like shadow on moss, breath held, poisoned arrow nocked and trembling at the string. Yet here it was: not a growl, nor a curse, but a question—polite, almost gentle—spilled from the lips of the very lich he’d come to slay.

“I see you there,” the voice continued, dry as autumn leaves skittering over stone. “Just behind the blueberries. Could you pick some for me, if you don’t mind?”

His plan collapsed like rotten timber. With a slow, defeated exhale, he lowered his bow, gathered a handful of the dusky fruit, and stepped forward—boot pressing down on something unseen.

Then the world twisted.

Mana erupted beneath him—crackling violet beams that coiled like serpents around his limbs, wrenching him into the air. Escape was impossible. The bonds pulsed with cold fire, sapping strength, stealing breath. The lich approached, staff tapping softly against stone, each step a metronome counting down to doom.

He moved like death rehearsed: joints creaking, robes whispering, fingers trailing arcs of raw energy—the same force now pinning the adventurer in place. His hollow eyes glowed beneath a brow of cracked bone, fixed upon the trembling man before him. The air thickened with ozone and decay.

The adventurer clung to his bow, knuckles white—but even that grip faltered. His gaze darted wildly, searching for weakness, for flaw, for *anything*. In his panic, he failed to notice how close the lich had come.

Until he was there.

A breath away.

Withered fingers reached out—cold, papery—and pried open the adventurer’s clenched fist. A silent command followed, and the hand uncurled like a dying flower, spilling blueberries into the gaping maw below.

The lich’s tongue—a rolling, blackened thing slick with unnatural sheen—lapped them up. His jaw unhinged further than nature allowed, teeth yellowed and crumbling, yet grinding with terrible precision. The berries burst between them, crushed into a luminous paste that pulsed faintly blue in the dim cave light.

And all the while, he stared.

Eyes wide, unblinking, drinking in the warmth of living flesh, the spark of fear, the flush of youth.

Then, slowly, he chewed.

“What ish it yoush sheek, yungk adventurerth?” he asked, spraying flecks of glowing pulp across the man’s face. A wad of jelly clung to his cheek, warm and faintly throbbing.

The adventurer recoiled, bile rising in his throat. “I seek fame! Fortune! And to slay evil creatures like *you*! I will not yield—nor obey your cursed whims. Release me, foul demon!”

The lich regarded him—a long, silent moment—then let loose a sound that rattled the stones: a wet, croaking gurgle, somewhere between a frog’s call and laughter dredged from a bog.

From within his tattered cloak, he drew a chipped glass jar.

And then—he vomited.

Not blood, nor venom, but the mashed remains of the blueberries, now streaked with strands of viscous mucus, flecked with things best left unnamed. The mixture shimmered, faintly radiant, as though infused with stolen starlight. With reverence, he capped the jar, wiped it clean with a ragged sleeve, and snapped his fingers.

The magical bindings dissolved.

The adventurer dropped to the earth like discarded trash, gasping, scrambling back—but too stunned to flee.

The lich thrust the jar into his hands.

“I hope this fetches a good price at the market,” he said, voice suddenly clear, almost kind. “Now leave me—and my berries—alone.”

For a heartbeat, neither moved.

Then, without another word, the adventurer turned and ran.

He fled through bramble and root, heart pounding, the jar clutched tight against his chest. Behind him, the cave vanished into mist, its horror receding into memory.

As he broke into the open woods, sunlight dappling his face, he slowed—then stopped.

Fame? Fortune? He looked down at the jar. At the glowing, snot-laced sludge within.

No alchemist would buy this. Not unless he lied well.

But perhaps… perhaps a story could be spun.

A rare elixir, harvested from ancient ruins. A potion base of immense power. A secret known only to the desperate and the clever.

He smiled, small and crooked.

Maybe today wasn't such a failure after all.

---

### Notes on the Polish:
- **Tone & Atmosphere**: Enhanced the eerie, macabre-yet-quirky tone, balancing grotesque imagery with subtle humor.
- **Pacing & Rhythm**: Varied sentence structure for dramatic effect—short punches for tension, longer flows for introspection.
- **Sensory Detail**: Added tactile, auditory, and olfactory elements (e.g., “ozone and decay,” “whispering robes”) to deepen immersion.
- **Character Nuance**: The lich feels more enigmatic—not purely evil, but alien, ritualistic, almost domestic in his oddness.
- **Thematic Depth**: Emphasized irony—the would-be hero escaping with an absurd "treasure," forced to lie to profit from failure.

Let me know if you'd like a darker, funnier, or more poetic variation!

Hawick Knitwear went into administration last month with the loss of more than 100 jobs.
Business Minister Fergus Ewing was in the town to chair a forum looking at the way forward.
Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire MSP John Lamont said a first enterprise zone in the Borders could encourage investment.
After the meeting, Mr Ewing said that it was time to "consider the specifics" of what could be done to help the town such as refurbishing old buildings and boosting digital infrastructure.
"Let's see what in practice we can actually do - positive, practical things, I am a great believer in that," he said.
He said he would return to Hawick later in the year for a further forum to take those plans forward.
Mr Ewing added that a task force had not been ruled out if it was required.
"I am not sure that a task force would of itself provide solutions to some of the issues today which I think are far more ingrained and wide-reaching," he said.
He said there was a "sense of purpose" from the meeting to look at specifics and develop a vision of the Borders as a "great place to live and work".
Mr Lamont said an enterprise zone would offer a "range of incentives" including business rates relief, fast track planning applications, the prioritisation of high speed broadband, specific skills and training support and advice for businesses on international growth.
"Hawick needs a radical, long term and co-ordinated plan to get it back on track," said Mr Lamont.
"Meetings and warm words will simply not be enough.
"While we need to continue investing in broadband and transport in the Borders, more needs to be done to reverse the decline that we have seen in Hawick in recent years, both in the textiles industry and on the High Street."

This paper presents an algorithm that efficiently decomposes a given distribution into a disjoint mixture of a small number of component distributions, each of which admits an efficiently computable Forster transform. This decomposition serves as a key technical tool in deriving the first polynomial-time, distribution-independent PAC learning algorithm for halfspaces under the Massart noise model. Notably, the algorithm’s performance guarantee scales independently of the bit complexity of the input examples—a property not achieved by prior approaches.

The authors demonstrate that, given a distribution over the ambient space $V$, one can either (i) identify a transformation $c(x)$ such that the reweighted distribution over $c(x)x$ admits a Forster transform—even when the original distribution does not—or (ii) discover a subspace $W \subset V$ containing more than a $\dim(W)/\dim(V)$ fraction of the mass, enabling a recursive reduction to a lower-dimensional instance after appropriate rescaling.

To achieve learning under Massart noise, the authors iteratively apply their Forster decomposition framework. At each step, this process mitigates the influence of large outliers on high-density subspaces while allowing for the training of partial classifiers. These are then aggregated into a global hypothesis with strong generalization guarantees.

I find the result to be clear, original, and theoretically significant. In particular, the algorithmic realization of the conceptual insights from [HKLM20] represents an elegant and non-trivial contribution to the literature on robust learning.

I have reviewed the authors’ response and have no further questions or concerns.

Due to its theoretical focus, the work has limited direct societal impact.

No conflicts of interest.

[✓]  

Rating: 3 (Accept)

I confirm that, in carrying out my reviewer responsibilities—including writing reviews and participating in discussions—I have adhered to, and will continue to uphold, the NeurIPS Code of Conduct.

To investigate the value of PCT in Goodpasture's syndrome, we reviewed the charts of patients with Goodpasture's syndrome who were treated from 1996 to 2006.PCT (normal range<0.5 ng/ml) was measured with an immunoluminometric assay, C-reactive protein (CRP; normal range<5 mg/l) with nephelometry. Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (normal range<1:10) were measured with ELISA.During the last 10 years we diagnosed seven patients with Goodpasture's syndrome. Six out of seven patients had biopsy proven crescentic and necrotizing glomerulonephritis. Five patients had a severe manifestation with pulmonary involvement (n=3) and/or severe renal insufficiency (n=4). Mean CRP levels were 145.7 mg/l, mean PCT levels were 34.1 ng/ml. Therapy consisted of plasmapheresis (n=3), pulse cyclophosphamide therapy (n=4) and glucocorticoids (n=6). Remarkably, all patients with elevated PCT levels had life-threatening disease (n=4) and remained dialysis-dependent (as compared to with only one out of three patients with normal PCT). In two out of five patients with severe Goodpasture's syndrome, PCT levels remained high. After thorough exclusion of infection, resumption of high dose glucocorticoids normalized PCT and CRP levels.

LLM_2:
### Abstract

Procalcitonin (PCT) is frequently utilized as a biomarker to differentiate autoimmune disorders from infections; however, elevated PCT levels have also been observed in non-infectious conditions such as vasculitis. This study aimed to evaluate the role of PCT in Goodpasture's syndrome through a retrospective analysis of medical records of patients treated from 1996 to 2006. PCT levels (normal <0.5 ng/ml) were quantified using an immunoluminometric assay, C-reactive protein (CRP; normal <5 mg/l) was measured by nephelometry, and anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (normal <1:10) were assessed via ELISA. Among the seven patients diagnosed with Goodpasture's syndrome, six had biopsy-confirmed crescentic and necrotizing glomerulonephritis. Five patients exhibited severe manifestations, including pulmonary involvement (n=3) and/or severe renal insufficiency (n=4). The mean CRP level was 145.7 mg/l, while the mean PCT level was 34.1 ng/ml. Treatment modalities included plasmapheresis (n=3), pulse cyclophosphamide (n=4), and glucocorticoids (n=6). Notably, all patients with elevated PCT levels had life-threatening disease (n=4) and remained dependent on dialysis, in contrast to only one of the three patients with normal PCT levels. In two of the five severe cases, PCT levels remained elevated despite treatment. After excluding infection, the reintroduction of high-dose glucocorticoids resulted in the normalization of both PCT and CRP levels.

Yusuke Katayama played a game of cat and mouse with the authorities, leading them to make numerous wrongful arrests.
He threatened a massacre at a comic book event, as well as to attack a school attended by the grandchildren of Japan's Emperor Akihito.
Katayama's campaign highlighted the difficulties the country's police force has had in dealing with cyber crime.
"He committed the crime, and the purpose of it was [for police] to make wrongful arrests," said presiding judge Katsunori Ohno at Tokyo District Court, adding that Katayama's actions had been "vicious".
Throughout 2012, the 32-year-old used a virus to gain control of strangers' computers. He then issued threats - which appeared to come from the computer's owner - and a series of riddles that captured the attention of the national media.
Among the other threats made by Katayama - who went by the alias Demon Killer - was one to attack a plane.
The case highlighted the Japanese police's tendency to extract confessions from suspects, as four people owned up to crimes which the National Police Agency (NPA) later admitted they did not commit.
Computers belonging to each had been infected with a Trojan Horse virus, introduced via a link on the popular Japanese chat forum 2channel.
The NPA's chief apologised, acknowledging his force had been tricked by the hacker, and promising his cyber crime unit would improve.
Police held one falsely suspected person for several weeks before media and a cyber crime expert received anonymous messages containing information that investigators conceded could only have been known by the real culprit.
Katayama had taunted police in emails that sent them all over Japan.
In one message, investigators were told to go to Enoshima, an island off Tokyo, and to look for a cat that turned out to be wearing a collar on which was a memory card.
The card held details of the code and malicious program he had used to gain remote control of victim's computers.
In December 2012, the police offered a 3m yen (Â£16,822) reward for information leading to the arrest of the culprit.
But it was the cat that led police to arrest Katayama in February 2013, who was seen on CCTV footage with the animal.

Operating under the alias "Demon Killer," he also threatened to target an airplane.

The case underscored the police's reliance on suspect confessions, as four individuals admitted to crimes the National Police Agency later acknowledged they did not commit. Each victim's computer had been infected via a link on the popular forum 2channel. The NPA chief apologized, admitting his force had been deceived and vowing to improve cybercrime investigations.

Katayama taunted investigators with cryptic emails and riddles, once directing them to Enoshima Island near Tokyo to find a cat wearing a collar with a memory card. The card contained code details for the remote-access malware he used. While police offered a 3 million yen reward for information, it was CCTV footage of Katayama with the cat that led to his arrest in February 2013.

At the Tokyo District Court, presiding judge Katsunori Ohno condemned Katayama's "vicious" actions, stating the hacker's intent was to deliberately provoke wrongful arrests.

Operating under the alias "Demon Killer," Katayama made alarming threats, including warnings of a potential massacre at a comic event and an attack on a school attended by grandchildren of Emperor Akihito. These threats were traced back to the infected devices.

The case highlighted the police's heavy reliance on confessions from suspects, as four individuals confessed to crimes later found to be unrelated to them, a fact acknowledged by the National Police Agency (NPA). The malware was spread through a link posted on the popular online forum 2channel. In response to the mishandling of the investigation, the NPA chief publicly apologized, admitting that his team had been misled, and promised improvements in handling cybercrime cases.

Throughout the investigation, Katayama taunted law enforcement with cryptic emails and riddles, at one point directing them to Enoshima Island near Tokyo, where he claimed a cat wearing a collar would lead them to crucial evidence. The collar contained a memory card with code for the remote-access malware he employed. Despite offering a reward of 3 million yen for information, it was ultimately CCTV footage showing Katayama with the cat that led to his arrest in February 2013.

At the Tokyo District Court, Judge Katsunori Ohno condemned Katayama's actions as "vicious," emphasizing that his intent was to incite wrongful arrests.

Following a vital capacity maneuver (VCM; inspiratory pressure = 40 cmH₂O for 15 seconds) to recruit collapsed lung tissue, a CT scan was obtained. Patients were then allocated to either group 1 (PEEP = 0 cmH₂O) or group 2 (PEEP = 10 cmH₂O), with further CT scans acquired post-VCM. Oxygenation was measured before and after the VCM. General anesthesia is known to impair pulmonary gas exchange, frequently leading to alveolar collapse and arterial hemoglobin desaturation. While administration of high FiO₂ may reduce hypoxemia, it concurrently promotes absorption atelectasis. The hypothesis that application of PEEP at 10 cmH₂O would attenuate atelectasis was evaluated in 13 patients with American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I–II undergoing elective surgery. Atelectasis was quantified using computed tomography (CT) imaging before and after anesthesia induction, as well as following a vital capacity maneuver (VCM; 40 cmH₂O inspiratory pressure for 15 seconds) and subsequent ventilatory management with or without PEEP. These findings suggest that moderate levels of PEEP effectively limit atelectasis and support better oxygenation during mechanical ventilation with high FiO₂, thereby offering a protective strategy against perioperative respiratory impairment.

LLM_1: This study aimed to clarify the relationship between distinct co-occurring symptom patterns and the occurrence of negative work events in employed individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS). Using latent profile analysis (LPA), common disability profiles were identified by classifying patient subpopulations. A sample of 272 employed MS patients and 209 healthy controls (HC) underwent neuroperformance assessments of ambulation, hand dexterity, processing speed, and memory. Regression-based norms were derived from the HC sample, and LPA was applied to the resulting z-scores to delineate latent profiles. Multinomial logistic regression was then employed to examine differences in negative work events across these profiles. LPA identified four distinct profiles: a common profile (55%), characterized by slightly below-average performance across all domains; a broadly low-performing profile (18%); a profile with poor motor abilities but average cognition (17%); and a generally high-functioning profile (9%). Multinomial regression analysis indicated that the uniformly low-performing profile was associated with a significantly higher likelihood of reported negative work events.
LLM_2:
---

This study aimed to elucidate the association between distinct co-occurring symptom patterns and the occurrence of negative work-related events among employed individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS). Latent profile analysis (LPA) was employed to identify clinically meaningful subgroups based on neuroperformance profiles. A sample of 272 employed individuals with MS and 209 healthy controls (HCs) completed assessments of ambulation, hand dexterity, processing speed, and memory. Regression-based normative data were derived from the HC group, and z-scores were computed for each cognitive and motor domain. LPA was conducted on these z-scores to identify latent classes within the MS sample. Multinomial logistic regression was used to examine differences in the likelihood of negative work events across the identified profiles. Four distinct neuroperformance profiles were identified: a common profile (55%), characterized by mildly reduced performance across all domains; a uniformly low-performing profile (18%); a motor-impaired but cognitively preserved profile (17%); and a high-functioning profile (9%). Results indicated that individuals in the uniformly low-performing profile were significantly more likely to report negative work events compared to those in the common profile. These findings highlight the impact of global neuroperformance deficits on occupational outcomes in MS and underscore the importance of comprehensive symptom management in supporting workplace functioning.

---

human: Two rounds of Soviet purges directed by Moscow (1927–1934 and 1937–1938) resulted in the expulsion of nearly 10,000 people, from all levels of the Communist Party of Tajikistan. Ethnic Russians were sent in to replace those expelled and subsequently Russians dominated party positions at all levels, including the top position of first secretary. Between 1926 and 1959 the proportion of Russians among Tajikistan's population grew from less than 1% to 13%. Bobojon Ghafurov, Tajikistan's First Secretary of the Communist Party of Tajikistan from 1946–1956 was the only Tajikistani politician of significance outside of the country during the Soviet Era. He was followed in office by Tursun Uljabayev (1956–61), Jabbor Rasulov (1961–1982), and Rahmon Nabiyev (1982–1985, 1991–1992).
LLM_1:
During two major purges orchestrated by Moscow—first from 1927 to 1934, and again from 1937 to 1938—nearly 10,000 individuals were expelled from the Communist Party of Tajikistan across all ranks. Their positions were largely filled by ethnic Russians, who came to dominate the party hierarchy, including the top role of first secretary. This shift coincided with a dramatic demographic change: between 1926 and 1959, the Russian share of Tajikistan’s population surged from under 1% to 13%.

Notably, Bobojon Ghafurov, who served as First Secretary from 1946 to 1956, stood out as the sole Tajikistani political figure of note on the international stage during the Soviet period. His successors included Tursun Uljabayev (1956–1961), Jabbor Rasulov (1961–1982), and Rahmon Nabiyev, who held the office from 1982 to 1985 and again from 1991 to 1992.

human: Sociocultural anthropology has been heavily influenced by structuralist and postmodern theories, as well as a shift toward the analysis of modern societies. During the 1970s and 1990s, there was an epistemological shift away from the positivist traditions that had largely informed the discipline.[page needed] During this shift, enduring questions about the nature and production of knowledge came to occupy a central place in cultural and social anthropology. In contrast, archaeology and biological anthropology remained largely positivist. Due to this difference in epistemology, the four sub-fields of anthropology have lacked cohesion over the last several decades.
LLM_1: Sociocultural anthropology has undergone significant transformation, shaped by structuralist and postmodern thought alongside a growing focus on contemporary societies. From the 1970s through the 1990s, the field experienced a fundamental epistemological turn, moving away from the positivist frameworks that once dominated the discipline. This shift placed enduring questions about how knowledge is formed and validated at the heart of cultural and social inquiry. Meanwhile, archaeology and biological anthropology have largely maintained their positivist orientations. This divergence in philosophical foundations has contributed to a notable lack of cohesion among anthropology’s four sub-fields in recent decades.

A seismic epistemic shift, which took hold in anthropology from approximately the late 20th century to early 21st century, saw the traditional positivistic underpinnings that long defined the subject begin to erode. At its core, this transformation put into sharp relief long-standing questions surrounding the formation and validation of knowledge in social and cultural contexts. In contrast, sister disciplines like archaeologists and physical anthropologists have continued to adhere largely to their long-held positistic principles. As a result, a significant disconnect has developed between anthropology's four core branches in more recent years.
